Yaumatei Kubrick

venue.name: Kowloon Cricket Club
venue.description: A club known for its cricket, but also provides facilities for lawn bowls, hockey, squash, tennis and football.

venue.name: Experimental Gallery
venue.street: Hong Kong Arts Centre, 2 Harbour Rd

venue.name: State-of-the-Arts Gallery
venue.opening_times: Mon-Sat 12pm-7pm, Sun & public holidays by appointment

venue.name: The Economist Gallery

Sai Wan Ho Civic Centre Theatre

venue.street: Unit 1604, 16/F Hing Wai Centre, 7 Tin Wan Praya Rd

venue.name: Hulahoop Gallery
venue.street: G/F, 23 Sau Wa Fong, St Francis St

venue.opening_times: Museum opening hours: Mon & Wed-Fri 1pm-9pm; Sat, Sun & public holidays 10am-9pm; closed Tue

venue.opening_times: Mon, Wed-Sat 10am-6pm; Sun & public holidays 10am-7pm; closed Tue

Hong Kong University Museum and Art Gallery

venue.opening_times: Tue-Sun 10am-5pm; closed Sun and public holidays

venue.name: The Chinese University of Hong Kong Art Museum
venue.street: The Chinese University of Hong Kong

venue.name: Le Bons Brasserie
venue.description: They know their name is grammatically incorrect, but they donât care; theyâve got a huge foodie following at this French cafe. Meal for two: around $220.

venue.name: Videotage
venue.street: Unit 13, Cattle Depot Artist Village, 63 Ma Tau Kok Rd

venue.name: Kubrick
venue.street: Shop H2, Prosperous Garden, 3 Public Square St

venue.name: Club Cixi
venue.street: Shop A, G/F On Hing Bldg, 1 On Hing Terrace

venue.name: Boca
venue.description: A MOUTH OF TAPAS With its slick dÃ©cor featuring wine glass chandeliers and chain curtains, this is a regular hangout for the cashed up crowd getting into the pricey tapas, house beats and their delicious range of sangria â classic red, signature white and pretty in pink ($58). In the heart of the Soho scene looking straight down Elgin St, Boca cultivates a slightly pretentious, âget the night startedâ type atmosphere, a place for dinner and drinks before hitting the Central clubs.

venue.name: Club 97
venue.description:
The vibe
With its island style bar area, comfortable couches, and a small dance floor, Club 97 serves as both club and bar, ideal for both dancing and lounging. Take your pick between moving to the music and watching Lan Kwai Fong go by.

The drink
If you think your stomach can take it, order a Flaming Lamborghini ($60). The ultimate party drink, which resembles a tower of fire when lit, is made up of coffee liqueur, Curacao liqueur, Bailey’s and sambuca. This over-the-top drink is guaranteed to brighten up your night.

The entertainment
Club 97 is known for its musical variety. On Friday nights, Club 97’s regular DJ Thierry spins retro funk; on Saturday it’s R&B with DJ Anthony; Sunday heralds ‘Reggae Night’; and Wednesday is ‘Salsa Night’ with DJ Joseph. Take your pick.

The regulars
Beautiful people of all ages and backgrounds.

venue.name: Why Club
venue.street: Basement A, No. 8 Minden Ave, Tsim Sha Tsui

venue.name: Shouson Theatre
venue.street: Hong Kong Arts Centre, 2 Harbour Rd

venue.name: Shouson Theatre, Hong Kong Arts Centre
Studio Theatre, Academy for Performing Arts
Island Tang
venue.description: Newly introduced to the line-up of snazzy Central businessmen lunchtime hotspots, Island Tang offers an Executive Lunch for 2 ( $796) that includes a rich sampling of dim sum and fried dishes, as well as the coveted sharkâs fin soup. The interior, reminiscent of Hong Kong during the 1940s with its antique table settings and wooden lacquer furniture, sets the mood for a stylish and luxurious meal. Meal for two: $796.

venue.name: Studio Theatre, Hong Kong Cultural Centre
Hong Kong City Hall Theatre, Hong Kong City Hall
Hong Kong City Hall Theatre, Hong Kong City Hall
Academic Hall, Hong Kong Baptist University
Blue Lotus Gallery
venue.street: Unit 24, 5/F, Block A, Wah Luen Bldg, 15-21 Wong Chuk Yeung St, Fo Tan

venue.name: The Path of Heart
venue.street: 1/F Lobby and 46/F Sky Lobby, Central Plaza, 18 Harbour Rd

venue.name: The Path of Heart Ã¢ÂÂLou Zheng Gang Exhibition
venue.street: 1/F Lobby and 46/F Sky Lobby, Central Plaza, 18 Harbour Rd

venue.name: Armani/Bar
venue.description: Since its opening in 2006, this spot has seen its share of suits, models and high-profile international artists. Separated into four different sections, the wine bar is where guests should plant themselves if they’re looking for friendly conversation over a few cocktails. The drinks list consists of champagne cocktails ($90-$138) to go with free classic Italian fusion appetisers (6pm-8pm weekdays). After ten, the wine bar turns into a mini-club with resident, and sometimes international, DJs playing a variety of lounge house.

venue.name: Jockey Club Creative Arts Centre, Black Box Theatre
Gossip
venue.street: 17/F, Park Commercial Centre, 180 Tung Lo Wan Rd

venue.name: Heat
venue.description: DINE AND DANCE Two floors, slick surfaces, quality food options, and various drinks specials that don’t involve paying a commission – though Heat is on Wan Chai’s Lockhart Road, it’s cut from a different cloth than many of its neighbours. Upstairs there’s a restaurant that turns into a club in the later hours, and plays host to DJ parties at the weekends. Downstairs is more relaxed, with booth seating for large groups and suitably mellower tunes.

venue.name: Hong Kong University Museum and Art Gallery
venue.street: The University of Hong Kong, 94 Bonham Rd
venue.opening_times: Mon-Sat 9.30am-6pm, Sun 1pm-6pm; closed on public holidays

venue.name: Museum of Medical Sciences
venue.opening_times: Tue-Sat 10am-5pm; Sun & public holidays 1pm-5pm; closed Mon

venue.name: The Press Room
venue.description: They modelled Press Room after the French brasserie Balthazar in New York. Though this eatery isn't quite the same, they make a tasty attempt at the glorious New York hamburger. Moreover, they even import H&H bagels for all those die-hard bagel junkies stranded a long way from Manhattan. Meal for one without wine and service: around $250

venue.name: The Pawn
venue.description: Three floors of this old colonial was painfully restored and upgraded by the boys who brought you The Press Room and Classified in Sheung Wan. Expect British gastropub (i.e. fish and chips), and great lagers on tap. Meal for one without wine and service: around $500
venue.opening_times: Mon- Sat noon-3pm, 6pm-midnight Sun and holidays 11am-3pm, 6pm-11pm

venue.name: Takamura
venue.description: Gaze through wooden-slated windows at the massive billboards adorning the Hopewell Centre across the street while enjoying attentive service and delicately presented slices of sashimi, quality yakitori, or a selection of seasonal dishes in a pleasant but featureless setting. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Sushi Kuu
venue.description: Sushi Kuu is a tranquil escape from the rowdiness of Lan Kwai Fong. The items on the menu are not all that different from those of other sushi restaurants, but the quality of fish and the skills of the chefs here are notable. Try their rolls or toro and salmon roe chirashi. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: Sushi Hiro
venue.description: You've got to be doing something right if customers need to make a booking a few days in advance to land a counter seat at this glorified sushi spot. The chefs work in the center of the U-shaped sushi bar and only the freshest fish is on display. This also means you'll be spending big bucks to eat here, so best to book for lunch if your tastebuds say yes but your bank account says no. Meal for one without wine and service: around $1050

venue.name: Shu Zhai
venue.description: This two-floor Chinese teahouse is hidden by a large fence on a tree-lined street off Stanley Market. They serve dim sum and dan jia, which means recipes of local boat people. The restaurant's name itself means library in Chinese and that's sums up the atmosphere here: relaxed and peace-inducing. Meal for one: $200

venue.name: Shabu Shabu
venue.description:
The first thing you need to do is tell them you want shabu shabu when you are making your reservation, or else you might not be seated at a table with built-in burners. And the reason why you should come is for their shabu shabu. The Japanese light-wood décor makes this restaurant look authentic even though the dishes have been modified for the Hong Kong palate.

Reserve a private tatami room for you and your guest and don’t forget to wear your best socks as shoes are not allowed inside. You won’t have to sit on your legs the entire meal, as they’ve dug out leg room for diners. Once the sliding screen has closed, service drops to zero. You will need to swing open the doors and shout to get anyone’s attention. Standard Hong Kong service aside, their shabu shabu is just as fantastic as their original outlet in Jordon.

As with other shabu shabu joints, you get chopsticks, a slotted spoon and you cook it yourself. We suggest you drop your root vegetables and udon first in the boiling base stock. Then immediately serve the noodles with a few spoons of the clear broth before the soup gets over flavoured with meats. We would hardly ever drink the soup base at other hot pot establishments because it is usually flavoured by MSG, but here it is clean, sweet and complements the udon vey well. The small bowl of salad that tasted like a big mac was a miss, but the beef negimaki starter made up for it. The thinly sliced beef wrapped in enoki mushrooms then braised in a soy and sweet wine mix really whetted our appetites for the frozen slices of Japanese beef. The thicker cut of beef was perfectly marbled and blood red.

The quality grade meat you get here is worth the $100 per person price tag (if you order the set menu for four). The basket of vegetable (mushrooms, lettuce, cabbage) was standard and fresh. The beef balls, shrimp dumplings and veggie wontons were home-made and you can taste the difference between those and mass produced ones. A plate of assorted golden tempura arrived mid-meal, perfectly timed to give a crisp contrast to the boiled meats and vegetables. 

A small complimentary bowl of red-bean ice cream finished our meal. Good for cooling the tongue, but tasted less like red bean and more like strawberry. A  great addition to Wan Chai’s culinary scene.

venue.name: SEVVA
venue.description:
The latest project by Hong Kong socialite Bonnie Gokson, Sevva has garnered a lot of fanfare lately, and with apparent good reason. The space itself is incredible: a 360-degree balcony offers stunning views of the skyscrapers of Central and Admiralty, the harbour, and the Kowloon skyline – perfect for sunset drinks and impressing visiting friends or clients. The furnishings, meanwhile, are straight out of Elle Decor and demand appreciation for their style and easy elegance. If only the food and service matched up to their surroundings.

So often in this town, it seems many of us settle for lush and glitzy settings in lieu of high-quality dishes and decent service. The question must be asked: is dining at the newest, shiniest spot in town suitable compensation for average food and below-par service?

Things got off to a bad start when we asked for tap water, rather than the suggested mineral kind, and were promptly refused. Sure, offer us the still or sparkling varieties – it’s a waiter’s duty to maximise sales – but refusal to serve normal tap water leaves a sour taste in the mouth.

Matters did not improve as we began to peruse the menu: our waiter cautioned us against ordering the oysters, saying they had had a bad batch the previous day, but that he would check if fresher ones had been delivered. They had indeed, so, throwing caution to the wind, we each ordered the selection. More fool us. The oysters themselves were good (five, not the customary half-dozen, to a plate, $360), but the warm Kilpatrick and Rockerfeller toppings overpowered their delicate taste, while the Asian-inspired taro-crusted with saffron and curry sauce was, well, uninspiring.

Mains didn’t fare any better. We ordered a burger – perhaps not the most original choice, but you would expect that for $320 you are going to get a bloody good burger. Sadly, we didn’t. Call me a traditionalist, but a burger should have onions, salad, tomato and relish somewhere in the mix. Add cheese, bacon or even foie gras if you want to go all out, but don’t just give us a patty on mash (you’ll have to request a bun if you want one) – it’s an insult to every burger ever grilled. As for the fish bento box ($380), two of the four selections (deep-fried fish) were the same, along with prawn and mock tofu scallops. When questioned, the waiter said it was strange to get two identical items, and he would check with the chef. He never returned, and by that stage of the lunch, we didn’t care. We wanted the bill, and we wanted out.

Don’t take our experience as blind ravings about over-priced hype, for this place does have huge potential. But it really must try harder.
venue.opening_times: Mon-Thu noon-2.30pm, 6pm-midnight Fri-Sat and holidays noon-2.30pm, 6pm-2am Closed Sun

venue.name: Sergeant Chicken Rice
venue.description: Touted as the best Hainanese chicken rice by many, the small stall in a food court has become a foodie pilgrimage for tourists and locals alike. The chicken is so smooth, it deserves its own adjective, and the rice so buttery sweet you can eat it alone and feel satisfied. Meal for one without wine and service: around $40

venue.name: Sam Mok Korean Restaurant
venue.street: 2/F, Mass Resources Development Bldg, 12-16 Humphrey's Ave
venue.description: The staff will help you navigate the menu, which is filled with Korean favourites such as bulgogi, kalbi, seafood pancakes, and stewed kimchi hotpots. Mention an item not written on the menu, such as raw beef with diced Asian pears, and it's like giving the staff a secret password. From there they will recommend a whole slew of dishes created by the Korean chef and owner. Meal for one without wine and service: around $200

venue.name: Rokkaku
venue.description: The staff to customer ratio is nearly the same in this tiny Japanese diner. On most nights you'll be lucky to get a table, but the sushi bar isn't a bad alternative as the chefs behind the counter will direct you to the freshest fish available. Don't skip on their udon or tempura dishes either. Meal for one without wine and service: around $300

venue.name: Red Ant
venue.description: This is a hipster's cha chaan teng. The kitchen serves up large portions of rice, noodles and pseudo Western dishes like escargot over pasta. The environment is young and loud with grafitti walls and distressed leather furniture dotted about. Great value on afternoon tea sets. Meal for one without wine and service: around $70

venue.name: Artificial Soccer Pitch, Quarry Bay Park
Peking Garden
venue.description: The Peking duck is a tourist attraction, but it's the other dishes that brings in the locals. If you are new to Peking Garden, must-tries are their begger's chicken (24 hour advanced notice needed), Peking duck (pay a little extra for the duck bone soup) and deep-fried sweet and sour whole fish. And save room for the red bean pancake at the end. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Pak Loh Chiu Chow Restaurant
venue.street: Shop 1028D, Elements Mall, Kowloon Station, 1 Austin Rd West
venue.description: Although the stars of the menu are the abalone, cold crabs, birds' nest and shark fin, the best of the menu are the least expensive items such as their oyster omelets, clay pot soups and desserts. Meal for one without wine and service: around $200

venue.name: Cafe Lagoon
venue.street: Gold Coast Hotel, 1 Castle Peak Rd, Castle Peak Bay,
venue.description: One buffet often left off many must eat lists is CafÃ© Lagoon. It shouldnât be. One of the best seafood buffets in Hong Kong features spicy wok-fried Manila clams, braised seafood claypots, grilled eels and king prawns, and fresh raw and sushi bar. The outdoor dining area, plus cover band, makes this a destination dinner for entertaining out-of-towners (there are great sunset views) or just a pleasant Saturday evening out. Meal for two: around $700.

venue.name: Nha Trang Vietnamese Restaurant
venue.street: 2/F, Wu Chung House, 213 Queen's Rd East
venue.description: The much loved Vietnamese restaurant Nha Trang of Soho moves east into the revamping Hopewell Centre area. A favourite lunchtime spot, this is also a great option for a cheap and fulfilling dinner. Meal for one without wine and service: around $100

venue.name: Man Wah
venue.description: This place is like stepping into 1920s Shanghai. They only seat a small number of diners each night so the chef and staff can take special care of each one. The Peking duck is carved tableside and the waiter expertly removes the extra layer of fat from the crispy skin. Yum. Meal for one without wine and service: around $500

venue.name: Mak Noodle
venue.description: This family operation has been satisfying the public with their tasty wonton noodle soup for the past five generations. The secret is in their soup base made from fresh and dried shrimp and flounder. The portions are on the small side so be sure to order a few extra bowls. Meal for one: around $40. Cash only

venue.name: Magnolia
venue.description: Home cooking at its best! When you enter Magnolia's nondescript doors, you are served welcoming drinks in Lori's living room Then, you are taken to one of the three dining rooms upstairs and served the yummiest home-cooked Cajun meal you'll ever taste west of New Orleans. The menu includes Cajun barbecue ribs, jambalaya, shrimp Etouffee, smothered okra and tomatoes, homemade cornbread apple pie, pecan pie, and all those Deep South favourites. $450 per person for the set menu and it's BYOB.

venue.name: M at the Fringe
venue.description: People come here for the ultra-romantic atmosphere, the slow-cooked lamb, and the roast suckling pig. The cooking here is highly innovative and noted for its superb presentation. Housed on the second floor of the historic Fringe Club building, M is one of the most beloved restaurants in the city. Perfect for intimate parties and small groups. Check out their wonderful wine list and be sure to book in advance. Meal for one without wine and service: around $550

venue.name: Lung King Heen
venue.description: Maybe it's the location, maybe it's the stunning harbour views, but it's definitely the food that keeps diners returning. One of the only Chinese restaurants to have a sommelier and massive wine closet. Dim sum is taken to a new level with inventive packaging and the addition of luxurious ingredients to classic recipes. If you only have a few dining slots in Hong Kong, squeeze this one in. Meal for one without wine and service: around $500

venue.name: Luk Yu Tea House
venue.description: The place goes back several generations and they're all still here every day for dim sum with their morning papers. The doorman is leftover from the colonial days, as are their recipes. It is nearly impossible to get a reservation on the first floor as it is unofficially reserved for the regulars. Don't despair, the other floors are just as lovely and humming with nostalgia. Meal for one without wine and service: around $100

venue.name: Little Sheep
venue.description: Little Sheep is a winter favorite. When the mercury drops, this place fills up with hungry folk dining in front of a steaming hot pot stirring thinly sliced lamb meat. The large, noisy dining room is surprisingly comfortable. Meal for one without wine and service: around $200

venue.name: Lardo's
venue.description: The owner supplies steaks to the five-star hotels around town, and serves up the same cuts here, but for a fraction of the price. Great Angus steaks, although you can't go wrong with any choice of steak here. The venue is short on decoration but the cheerful staff more than makes up for it. Meal for one: $500

venue.name: La Mer Brasserie
venue.description: Walk past the raw bar and pick a quiet corner for a romantic outing or sit outside on their balcony if you want to people watch. The seafood tower is massive and perfect for sharing. Two suggestions: Pacific oysters and potato leek soup. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400. for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: Kenjo's
venue.description: This is one of the best place in Hong Kong for fresh sushi and sashimi. Don't bother with a menu, just sit at the counter and let Chef Kenjo feed you till you cry. He loves to drink with the customers so be sure to top him off as you top off yourself with excellent sake. Don't be surprised if you're seated next to a celeb, a politician or a CEO. Meal for one: $800

venue.name: Kaya
venue.description: YouÃ¢ÂÂll find that this place is packed with Koreans including staff from the Korean consulate, so you know it must be authentic. The reason to come is for its slow-cooked beef stew and for its late opening hours. The space is open and comfortable; try to grab a cushioned booth by the windows overlooking Times Square. Meal for one without wine and service: around $300

venue.name: Kau Kee
venue.description: The lines outside this shop doesn't lie. Kau Kee does a mean bowl of braised beef flank noodle soup. Have it with beef broth or with curry stock. Don't expect service, and don't expect to come away with a clean shirt. Meal for one: around $30

venue.name: Joia
venue.description: Joia sits in a beautiful setting with lovely open view of the rooftop garden inside Elements Mall. The cool white Italian dining rooms are small, and the setting is intimate, lit by candles and blue neon. The ground floor's Salone De Te is meant to service the flash mob lunch crowd, while upstairs is reserved for longer business lunches and celebratory dinners. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: Jasmine
venue.street: Shop G25, Festival Walk, 80 Tat Chee Ave, Kowloon Tong
venue.description: This Cantonese restaurant serves all the favourites that a Chinese mum would make, but delivers it in a fancy package in a fancy interior. The black glass and marble interior gives a false impression that this place is upscale, but the menu's pricing is quite reasonable, especially the set menu. Best to advance book here during the dinner rush. Meal for one without wine and service: around $150

venue.name: Ito San
venue.street: G/F, DCH Commercial Centre, 25 Westlands Rd
venue.description: Quarry bay is not known for its culinary excellence, but that was before Ito San came into a tiny little shop on the edge of Quarry Bay. At lunch, you will see your favourite CNN anchors milling about over a carb-free lunch. At night, the Japanese crew from Tai Koo Shing flocks here to get authentic grub. When in season, Chef Ito imports thumbnail-sized crabs for deep frying. Not to be missed. Meal for one: $400

venue.name: Isola Bar & Grill
venue.description: Italian doesn't get better than this. Everyone that stops through Hong Kong must make a trip to Isola where the service is impeccable, the food is first class, and the views breath-taking. On a nice day, grab a seat on the terrace and sip a crisp white while watching the ships sail by below. The pastas are well sauced and always al dente. Weekend brunches here are one of the things that make this town worth living in. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: Hong Kong Planning and Infrastructure Exhibition Gallery
North Kwai Chung Tang Shiu Kin Sports Centre
Tai Wo Sports Centre
venue.street: Podium Level, Tai Wo Shopping Centre, Tai Wo Estate

venue.name: Po Kong Village Road Sports Centre
Indonesian Restaurant
venue.description: This place has gone through a major face-lift since it first opened in 1968. The sons of the owner took this old favourite and turned it into a slick modern eatery complete with wicker furniture and palm trees. The menu remains the same and the same chef (who has been here since 1968) is still in the kitchen as regulars would stop coming if they dared take one item off the menu. Try their stewed beef rendang and satays. Meal for one without wine and service: around $150

venue.name: Indochine 1929
venue.description: Imagine the languid tropical vibe of French-ruled Vietnam in 1929 and that is the ambience that has been aimed for here. You can get Vietnamese food cheaper elsewhere, but without the atmosphere that makes this place so special, and without the rather good location. Everyone goes for the grilled rare beef salad and so should you. Meal for one without wine and service: around $200

venue.name: Inagiku
venue.description: Sometimes it is best to eat at the bar, and that is certainly so at this teppanyaki restaurant. They do serve a pan-Japanese menu including sushi, tempura, and sukiyaki, but everyone comes here for the at-the-table teppanyaki entertainment. Go for the set menu as it is the best value and offers the most variety from all its counters. Japanese decorated private rooms are also popular here so book well in advance. Meal for one without wine and service: around $1,100

venue.name: Hebe One O One
venue.description: Grab a table deckside and watch the boats float by at Hebe Haven. The menu is continential and has something for everyone. Oyster Kilpatrick, white truffle risotto, and slipper lobster, all made to order. The baby-strollers parked in and around the premises give you a sense of the clientele

venue.name: Habitu Ristorante The Garden
venue.description: This used to be a great place to dine al fresco with gigantic hedges shaped into cute animal sitting next to you, but laws have banned them from serving food outside. Even so, the interior is modern masterpiece, like the inside of an Italian ship. Light and airy, it's a wonderful spot for sunny brunches. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: Gough 40 Cafe Bar
venue.description: The all-white jewel box interior makes any girl feel special here. Though the 20+ seater dining room might seem small, it is well thought-out for an intimate dinner. Maybe that is why you might see a celeb or two here on any given night. Companies love to rent this place out for a formal dinner. And on a nice evening, the French doors open for al fresco dining. Meal for one without wine and service: around $600

venue.name: Golden Valley
venue.street: 1/F, The Emperor Hotel, 1A Wang Tak St
venue.description: If you know about this place, then you are already a member of Hong Kong's Sichuan chilli appreciation club. Two great dishes to try: mouth-watering chicken in peanut- chilli sauce served cold, and stewed beef Sichuan spicy style. The hot pot's not bad either. When you're done with dinner, head up one flight for KTV. Apparently, many of our local Canto-pop stars were discovered here. Meal for one without wine and service: around $150

venue.name: Gaia Ristorante
venue.street: Grand Millennium Plaza, 181 Queen's Rd Central
venue.description: Gaia is an al fresco gem. Italians swear by the pastas here, and rightly so since most of what comes out of their kitchen has come from Italy. The great wine list and romantic artwork makes this a nominee for first date dinners. Meal for one without wine and service: around $600

venue.name: Fook Lam Moon
venue.description: Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name. Loyalists have been coming here for years and many of these patrons have their own table. Fabulous dim sum is served daily. Must-tries are the roast pig and the shark's fin soup. Meal for one without wine and service: around $700

venue.name: Fish Bar
venue.street: JW Marriott Hotel, Pacific Place, 88 Queensway
venue.description: The day's catch is written on the chalkboard and the server will recommend the preparation. Feast on simply prepared seafood in a peaceful setting overlooking the hotel's pool. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: FINDS
venue.description: This is the only restaurant in Hong Kong to serve the cuisine of Scandinavia, including one of the house staples gravlax. But it's the icy-blue lounge that keeps people coming back. And they have a notable variety of vodkas and aquavits. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: Farm House
venue.description: Regulars love the innovative Chinese menu here. Most dishes are MSG-free including their famous chicken wings stuffed with sticky rice. Come here twice or thrice and the entire waitstaff will know your name. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Felix
venue.description: STARCK CONTRASTS Take the ever-darkening lifts up to the Peninsulaâs 28th floor and enter a drinking and dining world designed by Philippe Starck â a world that has panoramic views of Hong Kong Harbour, Victoria Park, and a good chunk of the rest of the city (men can even enjoy the sights in the glass-fronted bathroom while taking a slash). Expect to pay for the extravagance but also to enjoy a night of well-managed opulence.

venue.name: Duke's Burger
venue.description: This is fancy food disguised as a burger. The Waygu beef is superb, and the accompaning toppings such as Iberian chorizo or saffron onions make it like no other. The Gwen Stefani interior cost them four million bucks to create, and looks it. Meal for one without wine and service: around $300

venue.name: Double Happiness Cafe
venue.description: This tiny 14-seater serves up one of the best MSG-free set menus in Soho. For under $60 you get a two-course Chinese meal in a cute red dining room. The dumplings are divine. Wear your best socks if you opt for the cushioned floor seating. Meal for one without wine and service: around $60

venue.name: Dong Lai Shun Restaurant
venue.street: B/F, The Royal Garden, 69 Mody Rd
venue.description: They repeatedly win awards for their seasonal crab dishes even thought this place is best known for their hot pot. Beautiful dÃ©cor brings in the beautiful people. Meal for one without wine and service: around $450

venue.name: Dirty Duck Diner
venue.description: The dÃ©cor gets the thumbs up for authenticity, but the dishes could use a little more imagination. Come for the atmosphere more than the food. That said, their signature dish, Bebek Bengil, is a must-try as is their outdoor terrace. Meal for one without wine and service: around $200

venue.name: Dining Wok
venue.description:
Though Dining Wok serves Chinese food, the menu might read a bit foreign to locals. Dishes such as egg foo young may sound Chinese, but it, and all the dishes here, originated from American-Chinese kitchens. If you are seeking a nutritious meal, this is a place to avoid. Everything is deep-fried, amber-coloured, salted-to-excess perfection, and swimming in the mysterious brown sauce that seems to appear in most Chinatown recipes. It is the crispy, fatty, oily, salty, heart-clogging goodness that makes this cuisine such a tasty, guilty pleasure.

You can’t miss the Hollywood lights screaming the restaurant’s name. Incidentally, the name means “Big trouble” in Cantonese. The ground floor looks like any traditional Chinese take-away shop found in Chinatowns across the world, with the chefs working their woks in the front window. The second floor is one of three dining areas; above that are a karaoke room and a roof terrace for private dining, outfitted for barbecues. It’s super kitsch, but true to its East-meets-West schtick. 

We started with thick hot and sour soup, and wonton soup (their dumplings are not like the silky ones gourmets like, but the thicker freezer-thawed kind) – very authentic for Chinatown kitchens. An assortment of “pu-pu platter specials” such as crispy spring rolls (unfortunately, they do not serve the large thick egg rolls), prawn toasts, chicken wings, and wok-fried potstickers accompanied by gloopy sweet chilli sauce was devoured as soon as the plate hit the table. Next came “General Tso’s chicken” (named sesame chicken on the menu). The deep mahogany-coloured soy-honey sauce thickly coated each tender nugget. It would have been perfect with plain steamed rice, but we licked the dish before the rice came out.

Lemon chicken, kung pao chicken, shredded chicken with clear broad noodles in peanut sauce, and mu shu pork wrapped in thin flour pancakes all came out together. The dishes looked small, but were very filling and perfect for sharing. The highlight was the crispy beef, which didn’t taste of beef at all, but more like fried dough strips used as a delivery agent for the sweet-spicy sauce. They crunched like Cheeto sticks as we chomped them. This is junk food at its best. And as a nice American-Chinese touch, fortune cookies arrive at the end.

venue.name: Dim Sum The Art Of Chinese Tit Bits
venue.description: Once you've mastered the standard fare of dim sum, you will want to come here to take it to the next level. Fresh shrimp and shark's fin shui mai with gold leaf blessings bring in the foodie crowd. A must-try is their famous pork-chop and vegetable rice pot. Meal for one without wine and service: around $100

venue.name: Da Ping Huo
venue.description: Prepare your stomach before eating here. This private kitchen provides super spicy Sichuan home-cooking served in multiple courses. Have lots of cold beer on hand to deflame. The chef comes out and sings a Chinese opera ditty post-meal. Two seatings at 6.30pm and 9pm. Must book in advance. $280 per person for dinner set including non-alcoholic beverages

venue.name: Da Domenico
venue.description: This is the place to test if you are a serious foodie. Everything down to the salt is imported from Italy and those in the know can taste the difference. Regulars swear by this place. The cuisine is homey Italian, though for the prices you pay here you'd think you paid for a first-class ticket to Italy. Meal for one without wine and service: around $1,000

venue.name: Craftsteak
venue.description: They imported a two-ton grill from Texas to make the perfect steak. Don't bother with a menu: it's rare, medium or well done here. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Cova Ristorante
venue.description: Don't expect to see Italian men with polished shoes standing around the bar drinking espresso here. Instead they are seated at white linen tables and sipping coffee in this lavish cafeand Milanese outpost. Afternoon tea and dinners are a must. Meal for one without wine and service: around $470

venue.name: Cordurov
venue.description: If you want to stay far, far away from places you frequented with your ex, this little hideaway is just the ticket. It's a private bar so phone ahead for a reservation.

venue.name: Cococabana
venue.description: This stand-alone beachfront restaurant serves up fine French dishes with an impressive selection of rose wines. Hong Kong can be like the South of France at times and what better way to celebrate than with a bottle of rosÃ© and some wild boar stew? Meal for one without wine and service: around $400

venue.name: Chez Patrick
venue.description: Chez Patrick stunned neighbors when the fine French diner first opened on the same block as the Central wet market. Nobody thought anyone would pay top dollar in a neighbourhood where alley cats owned the streets. But the restaurant prevailed and audaciously opened its second outlets in Wan Chai- this time near a waste depot. Meal without wine and service: around $700

venue.name: Chez Patrick
venue.description: Chez Patrick stunned neighbors when the fine French diner first opened on the same block as the Central wet market. Nobody thought anyone would pay top dollar in a neighbourhood where alley cats owned the streets. But the restaurant prevailed and audaciously opened its second outlet in Wan Chai, near a waste depot. Gallic class. Meal for one without wine and service: around $700

venue.name: Captain's Bar
venue.description: There's no male institution quite like Captain's Bar at the revamped Mandarin Oriental. MO spent US$140 million on a facelift of the hotel but didn't dare touch the beloved Captain's Bar, with its frothy mugs of beer served up in chilled sterling silver. A nightly jazz band comes on around 9pm.

venue.name: Caprice
venue.description: Who else would import the entire team from George V hotel in Paris to man their kitchen and dining room apart from the Four Seasons? Expect a meticulously thought-out menu, an impressive wine list, and gorgeous views of the harbour. They also serve the most expensive cup of coffee in Hong Kong, perhaps all of Asia, the Kupi Luwak. Meal for one without wine and service: around $1,200

venue.name: Brunch Club
venue.description: This is the quieter sister of the well-known Brunch Club on Peel Street. In Causeway Bay, they do the same all-day breakfast spread, but with less comfy couches to lounge around in. The tight space is made to feel airy with its all-white interior and lofty ceilings. Great for, well, brunch, but also good for freelancers in search of a place to park on free WiFi. Meal for one: around $70

venue.name: Bombay Dreams Indian Restaurant
venue.description: Famous for their lunch and weekend buffets, Bombay Dreams serves up all the Indian classics along with addictive dosas- fresh for each customer. Meal for one without wine and service: around $250

venue.name: Black Sheep
venue.description: The Black Sheep is a bit pricey by Shek O standards, but neverthless people still flock here for brunch and afternoon snacks. The cuisine is continental, and portions are large. Meal for one without wine and service: around $340

venue.name: Bizou Bistro
venue.description: If itÃ¢ÂÂs the sunny Californian cuisine you're craving, then head to Bizou.Their daily roast chicken is fresh out of a rotisserie, and their weekend brunch is a thoughtful treat. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Bistro Manchu
venue.description: Super spicy Manchurian dishes such as diced chicken with peanuts and chilli are served up at this Northern Chinese bistro. Their boiled dumplings are not to be missed. Meal for one without wine and service: around $200

venue.name: Nan Lian Garden, Xiang Hai Xuan Multi-Purpose Hall
Artist Commune, Unit 12, Cattle Depot Artist Village
Macau Museum
venue.street: No 112 Praceta do Museu de Macao

venue.name: Macau Museum of Art, 4/F Gallery of Chinese Painting and Calligraphy
Bayside Brasserie
venue.description: Great for lazy Sundays by the seashore. The coffee shop menu is nothing to brag about, it's the atmosphere you come here for. Filled with families on sunny days, get here early to wrangle a seat with a view. Meal for one without wine and service: around $150

venue.name: Babycakes
venue.description: Horizon Plaza is turning more and more into a family destination. And now babies have their own bakery to play around in. The café is equiped with padded play area and parents can keep a watchful eye while enjoying their mochaccinos. They have 16 different cupcakes to choose from, and each comes in adult or baby sizes. $12 for two bite-sized cupcakes; $25 for regular muffin size.

venue.name: Lecture Hall, Hong Kong Science Museum
China Club
venue.street: 14/F, Old Bank of China Bldg, 1 Bank St

venue.name: Antique Bar
venue.description: Think Feather Boa but larger and less crowded. Great warm interiors surrounded by antique shop finds. Try their wide range of "vintage cocktails", including the Angel's Tit.

venue.name: Anthony's Ranch
venue.description:
The bar
For those craving a bit of true Southern hospitality, look no further. Classic country hits are on the stereo, while the walls are lined with old pistols and historical memorabilia, including black-and-white Native American portraits. Beers on tap include Stella, Hoegaarden, Erdinger and Guinness, while shots range from Limoncino (vodka, sugar, fresh lemon juice and Limoncino) and schnapps shooters ($30), to refreshing margaritas ($55) – all brought out to you by staff sporting cowboy hats.

The restaurant
Dude ranch this is not. Texan-styled smoked ribs, bbq chicken, and fatty side dishes keep the locals happily fed. The outdoor seating will be very popular in the summer months, so ask for them when booking to insure you get seated where you want. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Friendship Thai Food
venue.description: Before we start, we must admit we have a soft spot for retro Thai cuisine. Here at Friendship, first-timers have to try their signature spicy fried crab, while another must-try is the pineapple seafood fried rice, sweet and salty at the same time. In fact, almost everything here is great. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: Anthony's Catch
venue.description: The menu changes almost daily reflecting the dayÃ¢ÂÂs market catch at this American-seafood eatery. After the diner rush, chef/ owner Anthony will usually come out to chat it up with the customers. Always a good laugh. Meal for one without wine and service: around $300

venue.name: Amber
venue.street: Landmark Mandarin Oriental, 15 Queen's Rd Central
venue.description: Amber is great for power lunches and intimate dinners. The dramatic chandeliers create the formality of the dining room and the atmosphere. Their international dream team of chef, manager and sommelier pays special attention to each of their guests. Whatever you do, order the truffle mashed potatoes. Meal for one without wine and service: around $1,000

venue.name: Amaroni's Little Italy
venue.street: 132, Unit LG, Festival Walk, 80 Tat Chee Ave
venue.description: This is the quintessential spot to get a proper Italian-American meal like they have in Soprano's New Jersey. Family-sized portions of chicken parmesan, osso bucco, stuffed mushrooms and larger-than-life Caesar salads makes this place great value. Best to book as walk-ins usually wait for ages. Meal for one without wine and service: around $170

venue.name: Agnes B. Le Pain Grille
venue.street: UG/F, Festival Walk, 80 Tat Chee Ave
venue.description: The tables, chairs, absinthe dispenser, mussels, mustards, even the butter are all imported from France to make this brasserie authentically French. Uber designer agnes b filled the menu with all her favorites and Hongkongers have been lining up every seating to get a taste. If you are not that hungry, stop by anyway for cakes- so good! Meal for one without wine and service: around $200

venue.name: Afterschool
venue.description: Old classroom furniture gets a second life at this cute cafe in the heart of Causeway Bay. Primary school desks scratched with student's rants act as tables and the menu is presented on Chinese character practice notebooks. It's wonderfully kitsch and you'll see lots of people lingering about with a cup of joe and their school work here. And free Wifi!

venue.name: 798 Unit & Co Gastropub
venue.street: 12/F, Times Square, 8 Matheson St, Causeway Bay
venue.description: This bistro serves up gastropub favorites such as fish and chips wrapped in faux newspaper, steak frites and pecan pie. Yes, you are eating inside a shopping mall, but the designers have done an incredible job transporting diners out of an arcade and into an airy, lofty eatery. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

No name, signs or arrows points you to the entrance. Enter the small dark alleyway and look for a key pad. Enter the secret code. Walk through the door and you will step into an unexpected open air patio. Inside, the bar and lounge area provides an intimate atmosphere resembling a chilled out house party. Trace your steps on the way out because chances are you will want to return to this hideout. Door code is "1818" at the time of this report

venue.name: Vivo
venue.description:
Vivo could pass for Tivo’s identical twin. Conceptualised by David Yeo of the Aqua Group, the two restaurants are almost mirror images of each other, both in ambiance and in decor, down to the lighting and the bathroom sinks.

Wondering about this intriguing combo, we decided to find out what is going on. And we learnt that Yeo still holds a stake with the Aqua Group, but Vivo is the first of the many dining outlets Ankh-Concepts, Yeo’s own brainchild, is planning to launch. While Vivo has a facade that opens onto Elgin Street, it doesn’t share the party spillover the drink-crowd-focused Tivo has on Wyndham Street due to its lack of pavement space. So it concentrates on food instead.

The upscale menu is continental with Mediterranean influences, with snacks such as pizza and calzones featured prominently. We ordered the scallop carpaccio, a seared morsel with sliced truffle and sea urchin emulsion (actually it’s froth, $128), and a four-cheese calzone, with taleggio, parmesan, gorgonzola and smoked mozzarella ($148) to start.

The pizza ovens next to the bar produced wonderful aromas of cheese on freshly baked breads, which made the calzone taste somehow better as our senses were heightened.

The medium-rare beef tenderloin with sweet potato mash and veal jus ($198) was beautifully presented, but not exceptional. We must note they served a decent sized portion for under $200. Finally, a dessert of banana soufflé ($78) was just right for our meal as it wasn’t too filling nor heavy, just a bit of sweetness to cleanse the mouth. Average meal for two without drinks or service: around $800.

Alan Wong

venue.name: Wagyu
venue.description: The menu says steaks, but the crowd says hob-nob. Lots of networking is accomplished on the street outside Wagyu. The spill-over crowd is filled with executives and their hanger-oners. The steaks are fantastic, but it's the Wagyu hamburger that tops the most-ordered list. Meal for one without wine and service: around $500

venue.name: Wang Fu
venue.description: There is not much on the menu except dumplings, noodles, and soya milk. But they serve the best dumplings, la mein and soya milk drinks around. Not as cheap as the $10 dumpling next door, but the variety and quality of dumplings is why diners are willing to pay more here. The shop is small and a bit of an eye sore, but pass the decor for good-hardy eats. At lunchtime, be prepared for long lines. They also sell freshly made dumplings for home use. Meal for one without wine and service: around $40

venue.name: Watermark
venue.description: Fine dining on the water doesn't get better than this. Roasts with foie gras, oysters on the half-shell, and the best waterfront Sunday brunch in Central. Take note that the glass walls are not sealed. That is because the entire building shakes when a ferry pulls into the dock. Meal for one without wine and service: around $500

venue.name: Ye Shanghai
venue.street: Marco Polo Hong Kong Hotel, 3 Canton Rd
venue.description: You could easily eat like an emperor at Ye Shanghai. The food is authentically Shanghainese with freshwater crabs, xiao long baos, and an assortment of other regional favorites. The dark, moody dÃÂ©cor sets this place from other outlets, making it a more romantic dining space. If youÃ¢ÂÂre overwhelmed by the choices, go for the set menu, as it contains a little of everything from the Yangtze River Delta region. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Yin Yang
venue.description: If you can't make it out to Yuen Long to try out the much talked about Cuisine X, chef/owner Margaret Xu has brought her new dining concept to Wan Chai. The menu is made up of all organic ingredients, some brought in from her farm in the New Territories. If the dedicated followers of Cuisine X is any indicator of that of the new Ying Yang, then you must book way in advance. Set meal for one without wine and service: $560

venue.name: Zest
venue.description: There aren't too many places where you can get 30-hour sous vide pork belly with pea puree and hot bacon dressing in Hong Kong. Though Zest is not exactly El Bulli, they do perform science experiements on their ingredients, which for foodies is a real culinary treat. Note: every dish is under $200. Meal for one without wine and service: around $400
venue.opening_times: Mon-Fri noon-11pm Sat 9.30am-midnight Sun and holidays 9.30am-10pm

venue.name: Zoe Cafe & Cake Shop
venue.description: Rarely do ground-floor cafés that sit among skyscrapers get so much natural light. But this spot got lucky and the owners have made great use of the space. Their signature dish is the Zoe, a hazelnut sponge cream cake with nuts and a chocolate base. They are also famous for their French 1459 layered mille feuille (cream slice), but unlike the classic they use custard not cream.

venue.name: Zuma
venue.description: This multi-floor London import is a haven for Hong Kong's white-collar types. But atmosphere alone is not enough to keep the moneyed crowd coming in night after night. The performance of the Japanese roboyaki grill and the special attention you get from the knowledgable staff adds up to a wonderful night out. On a nice evening, ask for a table outside to enjoy the city lights. Meal for one without wine and service: around $800

venue.name: Fai Restaurant (Group) Limited
venue.description: A family restaurant by night, a celebrity hangout by late night. This hotpot restaurant is known for its quality beef, fresh seafood, and buzzing atmosphere. The dÃ©cor is typical Chinese banquet, and the air-conditioner is on full blast. Bring a sweater and lots of cash as this place is also the most expensive hotpot spots in town. Meal for one without wine and service: around $350

venue.name: Mi-Ne Sushi
venue.description: The first thing you will notice is the huge line outside at all hours of the day. Good news for a restaurant serving fresh fish. The conveyor belt delivery system coupled with cheap prices and pop-rock atmosphere keeps this place packed with college kids and day shoppers who've spent more than their allowances. Meal for one without wine and service: around $150

venue.name: Modern China Restaurant
venue.description: Expect an hour's wait if you are coming during peak dinner time. The extensive pan-Chinese menu, dark-museum interiors and affordable prices make Modern China the most sought-after seat in Times Square. Grab a ticket, continue your shopping, and in no time flat your table will be ready. If you're starving, mention you don't mind sharing a table to the hostess. Modern China provides a fun geography lesson on culinary China. Meal for one without wine and service: around $100

venue.name: Pho Hoa
venue.description: Vietnamese pho should be in its own category. The bowl of noodle soup is not only a meal in itself, but a healing, soul-satisfying kiss in the stomach for many. The menu lists Viet favourites such as deep fried spring rolls, Viet-style curries served with French bread, and every combination of pho possible. Meal for one without wine and service: around $60

venue.name: Islam Food
venue.description: People come from all corners of Hong Kong for a helping of Islamic beef burgers. They also come here for the lamb curry and beef brisket noodles. Cheap as chips and tasty as hell if you are willing to wait. Meal for one without wine and service: around $50

venue.name: Maxim's Palace
venue.street: 808-828 Grand Century Pl, 193 Prince Edward Rd West
venue.description: Here at Maxim's Palace you'll see a lot more local specialties not served in their City Hall branch. The Palace is just as grand but doesn't offer the views of the harbour. On any given weekend, you will have to come a bit early and wait for the a table. Meal for one without wine and service: around $100

venue.name: Golden Harvest Mong Kok
venue.street: G/F, Grand Century Place, 193 Prince Edward Rd West,

venue.name: Golden Harvest Hollywood
venue.street: L3, Plaza Hollywood, 3 Lung Poon St,

venue.name: Golden Harvest Tsing Yi
venue.street: Shop 5, G/F, Maritime Square, 33 Tsing King Rd,

venue.name: Broadway Cyberport
venue.street: Shop L1 - 3, Level 1, The Arcade, 100 Cyperport Rd,

venue.name: Broadway Kowloon Bay
venue.street: Phase III, Amoy Plaza, 77 Nga Tau Kok Rd,

venue.name: Broadway Olympian City
venue.street: UG68, Olympian City 2, 18 Hoi Ting Rd,

venue.name: Broadway Palace APM
venue.street: Shop No. L6-1, Level 6, APM, 418 Kwun Tong Rd,

venue.name: Broadway Tsuen Wan
venue.street: L1-L3, Tsuen Wan Plaza, 4-30 Tai Pa St,

venue.name: Broadway Yuen Long
venue.street: Sun Yuen Long Centre, 8 Long Yat Rd,

venue.name: Chinachem Paris London New York
venue.street: Hong Lai Garden, Ho Pong St, TMTL 280,

venue.name: MCL Metro
venue.street: G/F, Metro City Plaza II, 8 Yan King St,

venue.name: MCL 4D Extreme Screen
venue.street: Shop 059, L6, Terminal 2 (Sky Plaza), Hong Kong International Airport,

venue.name: UA Citygate
venue.street: G-6/F, Citygate, 20 Tat Tung Rd, Tung Chung

venue.name: UA Cityplaza
venue.street: 5/F, Cityplaza, 18 Tai Koo Shing Rd, Tai Koo Shing

venue.name: UA Sha Tin
venue.street: G/F, New Town Plaza, 18 Shatin Centre St, Sha Tin

venue.name: UA Times Square
venue.street: G-2/F, Times Square, 1 Matheson St, Causeway Bay

venue.name: UA Tuen Mun
venue.street: Shop 3201, 3/F Tuen Mun Plaza Phase 1, Tuen Mun

venue.name: UA Whampoa
venue.street: L2, Whampoa Plaza, Whampoa Garden, 7 Tak On Rd, Hung Hom

venue.name: Century Cinema
venue.street: 73 Broadway St, Mei Foo Sun Chuen,

venue.name: Fanling Theatre
venue.street: 1 Luen Fat St, Luen Wo Hui,

venue.name: Sha Tin Race Course
venue.description: Home of the world's richest day of turf racing, the world's first retractable roof over a parade ring, and the world's longest Diamond Vision Television screen.

venue.name: L16 Cafe & Bar At The Park
venue.description: On sunny days, this outdoor cafe is packed. It is the only restaurant located in Hong Kong Park and is always filled with tourists and nearby office workers. The food is Thai, with some standard cafe fare throw in. Service is a tad slow, but the food hits the spot. And on most days, you'll see a wedding party inside, as this eatery is also located next to the marriage license office.

venue.name: L'Aterlier de Joel Robuchon
venue.description: Little helpings of wonder would be an appropriate description for the 8-course degustation menu at Robuchon. If you don't want to shell out the bucks for dinner, they do one of the best power breakfasts in town starting at 7.30am.

venue.name: V Best Teahouse
venue.description: Not all Chinese dishes are crated equally. At V Best, you can dine on healthy, MSG-free creations from a kitchen second only to your Chinese mother's. The main event is their smoked duck breast, but do try their fish with sweet-corn sauce, steamed meat pie, and sauteed shrimp with glass noodles. A great find in Soho's dining Disneyland.

venue.name: Yachiyo
venue.description:
We’ve tested enough ramen noodle shops in Hong Kong and Japan to say that Yachiyo could very well be the most authentic we’ve tasted on Hong Kong Island. And to be sure, we invited two of our Japanese chums to dine with us. A small, complimentary dish of green beans and pickled bamboo shoots whetted our appetites. We started with a platter of chopped raw octopus marinated in wasabi ($30), which was not the prettiest thing to look at, but it tasted sublime.

The char siu ($30) is not like other char sius you may have had in Hong Kong; here it is not dyed red but marinated in a light soy-spring onion liquor. Perhaps not what you would think of when visualising ramen noodle shop fare, nevertheless these small dishes are commonly found around Japan.

When the steamy bowl of Shoyu ramen (soya, sake, sesame oil base) ($55) arrived at the table, it radiated tempting salty nori-like aromas into our happy faces. The broth was milky from the process of boiling the pork bones, while the noodle had a pleasing elasticity on the bite. Slices of char siu, bamboo shoot, and chopped green onion decorated the top of the bowl, and a side of homemade prawn and scallop gyozas ($33) perfected the duality of this classic combination. The spicy miso Tsukemen ($55) provided enough heat to linger, and the cold spicy sesame noodles ($55) were loaded with crisp veggies and just the right amount of sauce to coat, but not cover, everything.

If we had to pick one dish to highlight it would have to be their Hokkaido milk ice cream ($28-30). They have pumpkin (served in a thick slice of pumpkin), ginger, vanilla, green tea (skip this one was it tasted of powder). Just the thing to cool and sweeten the tongue after a flavourful meal.

venue.name: Burger Republic
venue.description: This is not, as some had hoped, the burger chain from Melbourne. But you can still get your burger fix here, and a good one, too. They serve the classics with a bit of a Latin twang, such as the Spicy J-Lo, a beef burger made with jalapeÃ±o peppers. They also have âanti-burgerâ options, such as fish and chip and spicy hot wings.

venue.name: Applegreen
venue.description:
Billing itself as “the house of salad”, Applegreen falls somewhere between an American diner, a fine-dining healthy-eating boutique and an Italian franchise. It looks like the latter, with white, clean walls and light wood tables. It’s functional, unfussy, and with little touches of cosiness. 

Appetizers consist of some American classics, such as the Potato Boat (a stuffed potato with cheese, apple-wood bacon and sour cream, $68), and buffalo wings (covered in hot sauce and a blue cheese and celery dressing, $68), and some Asian standards, such as Thai lettuce wraps (chicken strips, carrots, cucumber, and noodles, $78), and spicy Ahi tempura roll (seasoned with green onion, ginger, garlic and spicy soy sauce, $78.)

The made-to-order guacamole with homemade, warm tortilla chips ($78) was super fresh and generously portioned. Though chunky and robust, it was slightly under seasoned, as were the tortilla chips, and needed more lemon to cut through the oiliness of the fruit.

A huge variety of salads, both warm and cold, are on offer. The Steakhouse salad is a 6oz US prime rib-eye, served with a base of mixed greens, red onions, blue cheese and Italian dressing ($128). The IKA salad, (house greens, deep fried spicy squid, tomato, cilantro), was delicious, its gutsy lime and peanut Thai dressing offering taste that the starter perhaps lacked. The greens were slightly clumped together with a second dressing that they didn’t need, and so appeared wilted. But this was hearty, honest and full of flavour.

If you want to eat light, choose the Salad Cart – customers are given a dim sum-style order form to tick, specifying the leaves, meats, vegetables, cheeses and dressings to create a tailored dish, ($88 half portion, $148 full portion). This is a welcome option for those who want their salad healthy and light.

For those not in the mood for salad, there are a number of pasta dishes to choose from, (try Lousa Dirty pasta, with Cajun Jambalaya with seafood, spicy sausage and chicken, $108), and also steak, miso salmon and shrimp dishes, ($132-$228).

The cubed chocolate fudge brownie with good vanilla ice cream ($28) is perfectly judged, light but satisfying, at once chewy and crunchy. To top that, unlimited refills of fresh squeezed lemonade, soda, iced tea (all $28), hot tea ($18) and rather disappointing Columbian coffee ($28) are available.

Applegreen provides genuine service, fresh produce and a flexible, exciting menu. Good for a quick lunch or a mid-week evening meal, Applegreen combines enough factors to make it a satisfying, and certainly original dining experience. It’s a winning concept, and with more attention to the finer details of the food, could be excellent.

venue.name: Magushi
venue.description: Itâs barely out of its wrapper and people walking by Brunch Club on Peel St are wondering if this is a new nightclub. Well, no, itâs not exactly a nightclub, but you can drink here and eat the robatayaki specials. This upscale izakaya of sorts is very welcome in the work-late, play-later town of Hong Kong

venue.name: Gold Teppanyaki
venue.street: G/F, 80 Queenâs Rd East, Wan Chai
venue.description: Itâs nice to be entertained while youâre dining. The chefs behind the teppanyaki table donât do the usual knife tossing tricks, but they do produce wonderfully cooked meals at the table. Some items are a bit pricey for what you get, such as the single scallop, while others are a steal, such as the giant shrimp which is the size of a lobster. The best value is their set menu, though, which includes a bit of everything. Be prepared to spend the entire evening there as they tend to take their time. Meal for two without wine and service: $1,400.

venue.name: Khana Khazana
venue.description: Khana Khazana has a way of making meat-eaters not miss the meat. This second floor restaurant gives diners unfamiliar with meat-free dining enough flavour to make them reimagine the idea of vegetarian cuisine. When available, the tandoori cauliflower is ridiculously good. Meal for two without wine and service: $250.

venue.name: Din Tai Fung
venue.street: 3/F, Silvercord, 20 Canton Rd, Tsim Sha Tsui
venue.description: This Taiwanese import is having the same problem Crystal Jade had a few years ago, with long lines of customers hovering around reception hoping to get a taste of a juicy Xiao Long Bao. The formula isnât that different from Crystal Jade: bao (with many more versions), la mein (much dryer, and tastier) and small eats to accompany the noodles and dumplings. Meal for two without wine and service: $160

venue.name: Xi Yan Flavour
venue.street: Shop 1207, Elements, Kowloon Station, West Kowloon
venue.description:
Food columnist and TV celeb chef Jacky ‘Xi Yan’ Yu opened Xi Yan Flavours in West Kowloon’s Elements Mall last month, the latest branch in his ever-expanding empire. Yu was first celebrated for his well-crafted Chinese sauces, which used traditional French techniques and a melting-pot take on Chinese cuisine. However, the worldwide Xi Yan family of restaurants have, sadly, now become a mass brand, meaning they’ve lost some of their original charm.

Flavours is decorated in Yu’s signature Chinese contemporary design; think G.O.D. fashion meets Communist red. The space is roomy, though the tables are set a little too close for comfort. Indeed, while a neighbouring diner slurped and sweated over a bowl of spicy dan dan noodles, bits of it flew over to our table.

The food portions are small, and the menu follows Xi Yan’s successful formula of combining Thai and Malaysian styles with Chinese cuisine. Most favourites remain on the menu, such as greenhouse tomato with sesame sauce ($38) and pickled Chinese gooseberry ($32), though the Sichuan spicy chicken ($108) seems to have been toned down for the Elements location, so if you’re a fan of the original, best request a hotter version.

The braised golden abalone in Japanese sake and soy sauce ($138) is worth ordering as well; the sweet liquor aroma of the sake heightens the fresh taste. But it is Yu’s desserts that are especially renowned, so make sure you leave sufficient space for their famous lychee ice cream ($42), an extremely good way to refresh your taste buds after a big savoury meal.

KC Gourmet

venue.name: Coco Thai
venue.street: G/F, West Blk, Island Rd, Deep Water Bay
venue.description: Coco Thai has taken over Café Uno, given it a clean sweep and added some modern furnishings, but kept the outdoor seating, hot dogs and hamburgers for the kids. The menu has Thai favourites such as minced meat with chilli and basil, Thai salads, curries and fresh coconuts drinks. All good things for when the weather swelters. Meal for two without wine and service: $200.

venue.name: Bar of Soup
venue.description: When Soup Senses stopped delivering to offices around town, many were at a loss. Good thing Bar of Soup came along. Six fresh soups are on offer each day, and although they tend to be on the pricey side, they all are homemade and without MSG. They also bake their own breads. One worth trying, if only by curiosity: the So Wu bread is made with a Chinese herb that is believed to bring blackness to the hair. Meal for two without wine and service: $80

venue.name: Mochicream
venue.description: Those with a sweet tooth will love this new addition to Sogoâs food hall. Mochi is a Japanese glutinous rice dessert and for those who donât find this description appetising, the assortment of cream and flavoured jam fillings will surely change your mind. Meal for one: around $15

venue.name: Top Deck at Jumbo
venue.street: Rooftop, Shum Wan Pier, Wong Chuk Hang
venue.description: Now that the hot weather is back, best to book your Sundays at Top Deck’s all-you-can-stuff Champagne buffet. There’s something for everyone, but the food is secondary to sitting out with your friends for hours in the sun drinking unlimited bubbles. Book the marquee table under one of their grand tents for you and a group of friends. Meal for two without wine and service: $600.
venue.opening_times: Tues-Thurs & Sun: 11.30am-12am, Fri-Sat & Holidays: 11.30am-1am, Brunch: Sun 11.30am-4.30pm

venue.name: Shiro
venue.description:
Historically, Admiralty has always been lacking in Japanese dining options – Pacific Place diners were forced to choose between the über expensive Nadaman and the very mediocre Kikuzen. However that is all changing, with the recent arrival of Roka, and now Shiro. Decked out in stylish black and white, Shiro’s combination of bar and table dining offers good seating choices for both groups and singletons on the go. Reservations made, we arrived at 1pm sharp to find customers spilling out all over the mall, many hovering over the overwhelmed hostess. Ready to throw a hissy fit if our table was not ready, we were surprised to be seated within five minutes, with plenty of (unnecessary) apologies for the delay by the staff.

While most think of Shiro as a sushi bar (they boast fish direct from Tsukiji), there are quite a few choices of cooked dishes, too. We started with a sashimi combination platter ($158), an excellent presentation of sake (salmon), meguro (tuna), hamachi (yellow tail), ama ebi (sweet shrimp), and kampachi, an ocean or farm raised type of yellowtail that is being touted by sushi chefs around the world as the next big thing. While we’ve certainly had tastier cuts at Tsukiji, the selection at Shiro is still extremely fresh, although the meguro was a bit bland. We also prefer kampachi that has been raised in Kona, Hawaii, as it has a sweeter taste and a softer texture.

In the mood for something more filling, we continued with some of the menu’s teishoku (set meals), opting for the teriyaki chicken ($138) and assorted tempura with udon ($168). Our expectations for the teriyaki were low, as this is traditionally a lazy dish for most chefs – broiling a piece of chicken thigh and drizzling sauce over it. But at Shiro it was prepared to perfection: succulent chunks of chicken had been marinated thoroughly in the house teriyaki sauce and then grilled, with their edges slightly burnt by the caramelised soy base sauce. And although it was served with just a miso shiro soup and very plain white rice (may we suggest using at least California calrose if Japanese imported rice is too expensive, but please don’t serve a plain, soggy variety), the chicken deserves full marks.

The tempura platter was solid too, with a mixture of large shrimps, green peppers, shitake with a light batter coating, and an appropriately warm ponchu dipping sauce. The accompanying udon had a thick, chewy texture, but for a classy place such as this we would’ve been more impressed with the Inaniwa variety.

The service was decent considering the wait staff were working non-stop. Requests were swiftly fulfilled and the impressive hostess addressed us by name. However, when the bill came, we were surprised that the tea and rice refills, which usually come complimentary at most fine Japanese restaurants, cost $10 and $20 per person respectively. Apart from that minor inconvenience, though, we will definitely be going back to Shiro.

Leslie Chan

venue.name: Hakka YeYe
venue.description:
Hakka food has a bad rap for being greasy, fatty and meaty. Hakka Ye Ye is trying to challenge that. Yes, they fry up the usual smoky chicken wings ($56), crispy pork nuggets ($42), and braised pork belly with preserved vegetables ($88), but dishes here are handled with care – and not delivered swimming in a pool of their own excreted fat.

The salt and pepper fried tofu ($88) tasted of soft potato chips, in a very good way. Nicely salted, it was impossible to just have one. The minced pork stuffed tofu served in a clay pot ($88) was also a hit. Ignoring the plentiful sweet and sour dishes on the menu, we went for something cleaner – and more difficult to make: the stir-fried egg white with sautéed shrimp ($112), traditionally soft boiled in a liter of cooking oil, was pure pleasure, especially with a little serving of black vinegar. We ate it over bowls of red rice. Surprisingly, a simple plate of stir-fried baby bok choy ($68) came out overly greasy, while the chicken and cashew ($85) was nothing to write home about – but a good starter dish if you are new to Hakka cuisine.

By far, our favorite was the golden pumpkin coated with salted egg yolk ($88). The easy house sav blanc went very nicely with our meal. However, take a pass on the watery red bean soup that follows the meal, and satisfy your sweet tooth elsewhere.

venue.name: Halls 1A & 1B, Hong Kong Convention & Exhibition Centre
MoMo Cafe
venue.street: 2/F, 167 Connaught Rd West, Sai Ying Pun
venue.description: Momo CafÃ© is a welcome addition to this part of town, where Asian options far outweigh Western fare. Spring chicken, rack of lamb, beef tenderloin, pizza, sandwiches and carrot cake all head the menu with some Asian dishes sprinkled throughout, such as Malay satays. At lunchtime they serve a hardy and affordable soup, salad and pasta set. Meal for two without wine and service: $300.

venue.name: Lot 10
venue.description: This little corner bistro is celebrating its fourth anniversary this month. They were one of the first to turn Gough St into the eating destination that it is today, serving Western fare in a cutesy patriotic French atmosphere. On a decent day, grab one of the tables outside and watch the lunchtime hacky-sack players destroy each other in the yard. Meal for two without wine and service: $600.

venue.name: Koh Tomyums
venue.description: Tomyums has left Wan Chai for the sunnier climes of Discovery Bay’s D Deck complex. Same great menu as before, with a few smart ‘family-friendly’ additions. If only they’d put back the grilled king prawns back on the menu. Note to self: wear close-toe shoes to avoid the stroller hit-and-runs. Meal for two without wine and service: $200.

venue.name: La Baguette
venue.street: G/F, Sincere Western House, 42 Davis St, Kennedy Town
venue.description:
The food at this tiny, tucked away French/Italian eatery in the backstreets of Kennedy Town is immensely satisfying, the setting unpretentious, atmosphere down to earth, and service discreet and informed. With only six tables, one of them a black leather booth for no more than four people, it’s certainly cosy, but yet feels far from cramped. Red mosaic tiles and dark furnishings give it a modest European feel, which lends itself well to the candle light and smooth jazz. Food is given pride of place here, the semi open kitchen taking up about half of the available space. The cuisine consists of original takes on classic dishes, created with care and precision by a team of immaculately dressed young chefs.

After enjoying complimentary warm bread (fresh from the neighbouring bakery) with olive oil, we tried the foie gras accompanied with duck confit in pastries. It was probably the best liver we have ever had, a moment of crispness before it disappeared in a melty moment ($148). Next up were the warm asparagus salad with smoked mackerel and smoked salmon with rocket and horseradish (both $75). Whoever puts together the menu has a great eye for detail and matching flavours, the plates were perfectly balanced. The filet steak with peppercorn and polenta fries was well-cooked and again, presented beautifully, ($148) as was the delicious lobster risotto with scallops ($180). We enjoyed their Emmental cheese burger with pickles, Dijon mustard and homemade fries ($80), and their stone-baked pizzas are popular in the area, ($90-$140) For dessert, the apple crumble was a slight disappointment, topped with a dry, biscuit crumble that was too savoury and bland ($55). However, the crème brulee with mixed berries ($48) was better, and the coffee was tasty, strong and nutty, obviously stocked by someone who cares.

If you want to eat food prepared with skill and originality in relaxed, classy surroundings, served by experienced waiting staff, you must try La Baguette, and if you’re a Kennedy Town resident, it may well become a regular haunt.

Sam Yates.

venue.name: Lamcombe Seafood
venue.street: 47 Main St, Yung Shue Wan, Lamma
venue.description: If you are looking for somewhere a little more secluded that the restaurants on Yung Shue Wanâs main street, check out this private seafood restaurant serving steamed grouper with ginger strips, garlicky prawns and other treasures from the sea. Meal for two without wine and service: $250.

venue.name: Blue Bird
venue.description: Great $66 Japanese dinner sets including soft shell crabs, spankingly fresh sashimi, miso soup and a small salad. There are only two types of Japanese beers, but thereâs a decent sake list.

venue.name: Han Ah Rum Korean Restaurant
venue.street: 6/F Causeway Bay Plaza One, 489 Hennessy Rd
venue.description: Korean barbeques are known for their smoke filled dining room but Han Ah Rum's efficient air filtering system won't have you smelling like Bulgogi. Great selection of Namul (side dishes) such as korean pancake, vermicelli, sweet potato and several types of kim chee. Try their hand cut noodle in clam soup if you want something light and delicious. Dinner for one without service $200.

venue.name: Akamaru
venue.street: APM, 418 Kwun Tong Road, Millenium City 5
venue.description: Who would've thought a $10 bowl of udon would be so satisfying? Akamaru uses imported Japanese flour and make their thick, chewy udon noodles fresh daily. Add on loads of extra toppings such as tempura, sweet potato, tonkatsu and more. Try to avoid dinner rush hours as the queue is long, and avoid going with a large group - it's bar service. A meal for one without service, $50.

venue.name: Exhibition Hall, Hong Kong Film Archive
Tam Kung Temple
venue.street: Shau Kei Wan Man St E

venue.name: Soccer pitch in the playground of Pak Tai Temple
Makumba Africa Bar
venue.street: G/F Garley Building, 48 Peel St, Soho

venue.name: Chinese Fine Art Gallery, 4/F Hong Kong Museum of Art
Gecko Lounge & Wine Bar
venue.description: GREEN FAIRY TALES Hang around at this bar for long enough and you’ll probably pick up a bit of French lingo. You’ll also more than likely witness some live entertainment, with musicians performing right beside you. When the regulars aren’t jamming and DJs aren’t spinning, late-night focus group gatherings offer everything from fetish discussions to poetry readings. And for those who want to meet the green fairy, they serve absinthe.

venue.name: T T Tsui Gallery, University Museum & Art Gallery, University of Hong Kong
Meeting Room 301 B, Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre
Fun Corner, "Hong Kong Story" Gallery 8, Hong Kong Museum of History
Y-space
venue.street: 3/F, Flat B, Wah Fung Industrial Ctr, 33-39 Kwai Fung Crescent

venue.name: Tai Kok Tsui Spoarts Centre
venue.street: 5-7/F, Tai Kok Tsui Municipal Services Building, 63 Fuk Tsun St

venue.name: Choi Hung Road Beach Volleyball Court
The Cavern
venue.street: G/F, Lan Kwai Fong Tower, 55 D'Aguilar St

venue.name: Gallery Benten 17
venue.street: G/F, 17 Wa in Fong East, 12 Shing Wong St

venue.name: Wong Nai Chung Crescent Garden
venue.street: Wong Nai Chung Rd. Wong Nai Chung Crescent Garden, '

venue.name: Inner Harbour district, Sam Kai Vui Kun (Kuan Tai Temple), Hong Kung Temple, Red Market and Iao Hon
Tap Seac Gallery
venue.street: 95 Av do Conselheiro Ferreira de Almeida

venue.name: 4th floor Theatre, Macau Tower Convention and Entertainment Centre
Hall 3, Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre
Gourmet Burger Union
venue.description:
Gourmet Burger Union is a take on the Gourmet Burger Kitchen in the UK. Everything from logo to menu is suspect familiar to its UK counterpart. Their classic burger, a good size Aussie beef patty with chucky onion and crisp lettuce is the tried and true, but it was the sticky relish that stood out. $48

What out tasters said: “This place is known for their exotic burgers, but the plain beef burger is quite boring.. and dry.  Unimpressive and instantly forgettable… better if you design your own and load them up with toppings… Patty too big for bun.

 
Meat: 5/10
Bun: 5/10
Topping: 6/10
Value: 2/10
Overall: 3/10 $48 is too expensive for a burger that tastes of little. The cooks pressed the hell out of the patty during cooking, squeezing out all the juices that make the patty taste great.

venue.name: Live House
venue.street: Rm L215, 3/F, Phase 2, Kwun Tong Industrial Bldg

venue.name: Star Hall, Hong Kong International Trade and Exhibition Centre
Lei Yue Mun Plaza
venue.street: 1/F Lei Yue Mun Plaza, above Yau Tong MTR Station

venue.name: Concert Hall, Hong Kong Cultural Centre
Outdoor Theatre, Tai Po Waterfront Park
Club Cixi
venue.street: Shop A, G/F, On Hing Bldg, 1 On Hing Tce

venue.name: Drama Theatre, Academy of Performing Arts
City Hall Theatre, Hong Kong City Hall
Lyric Theatre, Academy for Performing Arts
Drama Theatre, Hong Kong Academy of Performing Arts
McAulay Studio, Hong Kong Arts Centre
Lyric Theatre, Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts
Ngau Chi Wan Civic Centre Theatre, Ngau Chi Wan Civic Centre
venue.street: 2/F, Ngau Chi Wan Complex, 11 Clearwater Bay Rd

venue.name: Tuen Mun Town Hall, C.A. Hall, Tuen Mun Hall
Sheung Wan Civic Centre Theatre, Sheung Wan Civic Centre
Grand Theatre, Hong Kong Cultural Centre
Kwai Tsing Theatre Auditorium, Kwai Tsing Theatre
The Viceroy
venue.street: 2/F Sun Hung Kai Centre, 30 Harbour Rd

venue.name: Wasabisabi
venue.description: Red glass panels and a lit catwalk tempt you into Wasabisabi, where the décor is plush and the food is testament to its seven year stay in Times Square. For the month of February, chef Tatsuya Iwahashi prepares a four-course winter sake dinner. We loved the Rihaku rose sake paired with the giant botan prawns, and the home-made plum wine with the hot red bean pudding. Tasting menu for two: $1,596.

venue.name: AgnÃšs B. CinÃ©ma, Hong Kong Arts Centre
The Embassy
venue.street: Unit 309, Phase 2 Unit 309, Chai Wan Industriail City, 70 Wing Tai Rd

venue.name: Zee Stone
venue.street: G/F Yu Yuet Lai Bldg, 43-55 Wyndham St

venue.name: Exhibition Gallery, Tsuen Wan Town Hall
Fa Yuen Street Public Library
venue.street: Extension Activities Room, 4/F Fa Yuen St Municipal Services Bldg, 123A Fa Yuen St

venue.name: The McAulay Studio, Hong Kong Arts Centre
Exhibition Hall, Sheung Wan Civic Centre
venue.street: 5/F, Sheung Wan Municipal Services Bldg, 345 Queen's Road Central

venue.name: 2/F-3/F, Gallery of Special Exhibitions, Macau Museum of Art
Macau Museum of Art
venue.street: Av Xian Xing Hai, s/n, NAPE

venue.name: Poor Space
venue.street: No. 3A, Rua de EspectaÃ§Ã£o de Almeida

venue.name: Lab Yellow
venue.street: Flat A1, 8/F, Yeung Yiu Chung (no.5) Industrial Bldg, 34 Tai Yip St

venue.name: New Asia Amphitheatre, New Asia College, The Chinese University of Hong Kong
Star Cafe
