venue.street: B/F, 40-42 Carnarvon Rd, Tsim Sha Tsui
venue.description: Tell people youâre looking for tomato soup in a building referred to as Kowloonâs four floors of whores, and youâll probably be labeled crazy, or worse. However, those in the know make the arduous journey to sit in this underground storage area, with accompanying scrawny alley cats, to feast on instant noodles in a yummy tomato-broth base. This place is ghetto by definition â you are literally sitting next to rice bags piled to the ceiling, dimly lit by bare bulbs â but thatâs all part of the charm.

venue.name: Spasso
venue.street: Shop 403, Level 4, Ocean Centre, Harbour City,
venue.description: The guys from DiVino and Goccia have crossed the harbour to open another Italian wonder. The food: well-done Italian for the unfussy. The wine: the list will intimidate, but those in the know are in for an Italian treat. Ask for a table outside, harbour-side. Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Sabatini
venue.description: Being miles away from Central, and in a four star tourist hotel, doesn't stop business big wigs from regularly lunching at this Italian institution. Start off your hearty meal with a warm basket of foccacia, moving next to the delightful spaghetti with olive oil and chilli, before digging into the savoury veal scallopini and polishing off the home made tiramisu. If this isn't the closest thing to Italy, at the very least it's the best outside of Little Italy in New York. Meal for two: around $700.

venue.name: The Bay
venue.description: When diners want a sunset alternative to Lantau’s over-populated The Stoep or the super-remote One-Thirty-One in Sai Kung, The Bay restaurant in Mo Tat Wan on Lamma Island is a good one to explore. The only way to get there is by ferry from Aberdeen’s Fish Market, sampan, or a 20-minute hike in. Once there, take in the gorgeous water views and warm sunsets at one of their family-sized tables. The bi-lingual menu features fresh-fresh seafood Mediterranean style. Fresh mussels steamed in white wine shallots sauce, bouillabaisse, grilled prawns with cherry tomatoes, sardines with pine nuts and parsley to name just a few dishes to look forward to. Great chops as well. There’s a private beach (golden and clean) right outside the back deck to frolic around. And if you go during the daytime, take a stroll to nearby Tung O, the tiny village where Chow Yun-Fat comes from. . Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Azure
venue.description: This posh supper club sits perched atop the LKF Hotel, with excellent views of the city. The menu is modern French, as is the décor. It’s great for first dates or impressing out-of-towners. Take your post-meal grappa outside on their patio if it’s a clear night. Meal for two: around $1,200.

venue.name: Antique Tea Room
venue.description: Nicely done scones, madeleines, cakes and delectable macaroons make for a nice alternative to Tai Cheong Bakeryâs famous egg tarts (located across the street). Tea for two: around $100.

venue.name: Il Bel Paese
venue.description: You could easily walk past this Italian delicatessen and think they just sell cold cuts and the random takeaway antipasto. But explore past the deli counters, and up the stairs youâll find a quaint dining loft for parties of two. Upturned wine barrels double as tables, and diners sit amongst imported Italian produce. And the food: no-fuss, homemade goodness. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: D.Diamond Restaurant and Bar
venue.street: Roof Garden, Elements, 1 Austin Rd West,
venue.description:
We’re always a little wary of restaurants described as ‘fusion’, or those hung up on a gimmick, so it was with a degree of caution that we approached this Italian-Japanese restaurant, a culinary spinoff from Canadian jewellery merchant Damiani. Predictably, the décor in the restaurant and upstairs bar is plush and chic, with diamonds glinting from behind protective glass – but can the food compare with its surroundings?

Taking Italian cuisine as its starting point, the menu offers an intriguing selection of options with a distinctly Japanese twist. Starters were a mixed bag: the grain-fed pork belly with Cerignola olives, black truffle and smoked ricotta ($138) had clearly benefited from its 36-hour cooking time – the fat was wonderfully soft and buttery. However the prawns with lemon-chilli dust, eggplant, semi-dried tomatoes and campari reduction ($168), were a little too bitter for our – and, we suspect, most people’s – tastes.

The main course of seared tuna topped with foie gras and green peppercorn yamamomo sauce ($248) led to immediate regrets. The first was that we’d ordered it medium-rare instead of rare – cuts of tuna this fresh should have only the most passing acquaintance with the frying pan. The second was we’d neglected to order the foie gras as a stand-alone starter. ‘Melt in the mouth’ is one of the most overused clichés in the gastronomic lexicon (along with ‘uncovered gem’), but this morsel truly deserved the accolade, the lightly seared exterior giving way to a rich liquid centre as it eased off the fork.

Conversely, my companion was left slightly underwhelmed by her choice. There was nothing wrong with her clam linguine ($138) per se: the clams were juicy and well cooked, while the pasta in vermintino, garlic and parsley was al dente to a tee. My feeling was she envied the decadent flavours emanating from my plate. Sorry my dear, next time perhaps.

The small but well-selected wine list further enhanced the meal – which is more than can be said for the cumbersome cutlery clearly designed for style rather than ease of use. This minor gripe – and my partner’s mistaken order – aside, D.Diamond is an uncovered gem (oops).

David Cooper

venue.name: One Thirty One
venue.street: 131 Tseng Tau Village, Shap Sze Heung,
venue.description: Take your lover to this converted village house and romance them with glowing orchid sunsets. A European-style set menu is prepared by chef Gary Cheuk, and requests can be accommodated upon booking. Bookings must be made in advance; no walk-ins. Meal for two: around $1,800.

venue.name: Dai Wing Wah
venue.description: The man who owns this joint knows his rice, which explains why his restaurantâs fatty pork over rice (rice is specially shipped from China, because he thinks Thai rice is too silky for the dish) keeps Hongkongers from all over coming back time and time again. Meal for two: around $100.

venue.name: Chilli N Spice
venue.street: Shop R1 G/F Marina Magic Shopping Mall, Gold Coast,
venue.description: Unlike other Chilli N Spice outlets across town, this one specialises in line-fresh seafood and vegetables cooked to order. This seaside eatery showcases an enormous selection of live seafood embedded on ice. Itâs lively and filled with hungry seafood lovers looking for something other than the filthy tanks of Sai Kung and Lamma. As the name suggests, they are heavy on the chilli and spices, Thai cuisine seems to rule here, but diners can ask for seafood dishes to be prepared otherwise. Meal for two: around $240.

venue.name: Fai Gor Seafood Hot Pot Restaurant
venue.street: Full Sing Court, 82-84 Fuk Lo Tsun Rd,
venue.description: A family restaurant by night, a celebrity hangout by late night. This hotpot restaurant is known for its quality beef, fresh seafood, and buzzing atmosphere. The dÃ©cor is typical Chinese banquet, and the air-conditioner is on full blast. Bring a sweater and lots of cash as this place is also the most expensive hotpot spots in town. Meal for two: around $700

venue.name: Ming Court
venue.description: Besides the delectable dim sum, this elegant restaurant in bustling Mong Kok is known for its twist on a perennial classic - yeung chow fried rice with sea cucumber, which apparently was the way Chinese emperors preferred it. Meal for two: around $400.

venue.name: Pepper Lunch
venue.description: If you think juicy, marbled steak served on a custom made sizzling platter is too good to be served at a food court, think again. A famous chain back in Japan, Pepper Lunchâs first Hong Kong eatery features the same tasty rib eye and sirloin as its Tokyo counterpart. Paired with teppanyaki style vegetables, their secret sauce, and served with rice instead of potatoes, this is the best value a $100 bill will buy. Meal for two: around $180.

venue.name: Nadaman
venue.description: Japanese restaurants abound in Hong Kong, but Nadaman's consistency and reputation as the outpost of Tokyo's top restaurants is undisputed. The Chirashi don is the must-order, while the Kobe Beef Sukiyaki is cooked to perfection at your table. Meal for two: around $1200.

venue.name: Zen Chinese Cuisine
venue.description: Mall restaurants often don't get the credit they deserve, but Zen's contemporary Cantonese cuisine has won them loads of accolades and loyal diners. Points go to the stylised decorations with the right restraints. While dim sum lunches are packed with the usual office crowd, the evening menu, with one of the best crispy skinned chickens in Hong Kong and stir friend garoupa, steals the show. Meal for two: around $500.

venue.name: Lawry's
venue.description: This lushly decorated outpost of the famous Los Angeles original is carnivore heaven. However, while the slow roasted prime rib is juicy and succulent,there is not much else on the menu. Start off with a cold and crispy âspinning bowlâ salad, and watch your prime rib carved at tableside. Medium rare is best. Meal for two: around $900

venue.name: Lo Chiu
venue.description: This Hillwood Road stalwart has been serving some of the best Vietnamese favourites since the 1970s. Their minced prawn on sugar cane is one of the heartiest you can find in the SAR, as are their large pots of curried chicken. Generous portions and good value aside, the second generation operators have ensured their casual and efficient service is continued. Meal for two: around $120.

venue.name: Bowl's Cafe
venue.street: G/F, 117 Ap Lei Chau Main St.,
venue.description: On the surface, it's a nondescript little coffee shop in an unremarkable neighbourhood. But what makes Bowl's cafe stand out is that for a mere $40, you get the same service and quality of places that charge three times the amount. The high blue ceiling reminds you of the Mediterranean, while waiters in crisp white shirts serve up a perfect cup of borscht with piping hot garlic bread, and savoury homemade spaghetti bolognesewith al dente pasta and tasty chopped tomatoes. Throw in a freshly ground coffee, and you still get change from $50. Meal for two: around $80.

venue.name: Tsuen King Circuit Sports Centre
venue.street: 38 Mei Wan St, Tsuen King Circuit

venue.name: Near Tai Koo Shing and City Plaza
Asia Fine Art
venue.street: Sik On St, 99 Queenâs Rd East

venue.name: Osage Soho
venue.street: Lower Ground Shop 1, 45 Caine Rd (Corner Old Bailey St)

Cultural Centre, Rm AC2, Level 4, Administration Bldg
LiveHouse
venue.street: 3/F, Phase 2, Kwun Tong Industrial Building, 472-484 Kwun Tong Rd

venue.name: Flat 310
venue.street: Flat 310, 3/F, Century Centre, 44 Hung To Rd

venue.name: 3/F Gallery
venue.street: Macau Museum of Art, Av Xian Xing Hai

venue.name: Mul-ABC Room, City Univeristy of Hong Kong
Star Hall, HK International Trade & Exhibition Centre

Concert Hall, Academy for Performing Arts
Cultural Activities Hall, Sha Tin Town Hall
McAulay Theatre, Hong Kong Art Centre
The Jockey
venue.street: G/F, 33 Wong Nai Chung Rd, Happy Valley,
venue.description: Happy Valley's favourite watering hole is popular with locals and passers-by, serving all the expected British pub classics as well as an all-day breakfast on weekends and public holidays. A cosy dog-friendly pub with outdoor seating, The Jockey is a great place to spend a lazy Sunday with friends. Meal for two: around $300.

venue.name: Ippen-an Ramen & Bar
venue.description: This 26- year- old noodle shop was the first of its kind to serve just ramen on its mains menu, so it comes as no surprise that its namesake dish is also its best. People flock to all four Hong Kong outlets for the generous portions of mushrooms, cabbage, pork and seafood on chewy ramen in their signature broth.

venue.name: Duo
venue.description: This warm and comfy Spanish and Italian diner adds gloss to the ever expanding gourmet row along Hollywood Road. Located right next to Classified and M1NT, this newcomer should have curious foodies checking out their sumptuous salad island during lunch time, and their causal Mediterranean menu in the evenings. Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: OVOlogue
venue.description:
The part of Wan Chai around Queen's Road East, Johnston Road and Ship Street is going through a revival reminiscent of New York's meatpacking district earlier this decade. The combination is similar – in the Big Apple, chic eateries such as Pastis, Buddhakan and Highline clustered around Ninth Avenue, while old walk-ups were transformed into stylish yuppie apartments. In Wan Chai, the arrival of expensive boutique apartments like Zenith and J Residence paved the way but the real defining moment came with the opening of several cool restaurants – The Pawn, Bo Innovation, and Le Fouchon wine bar.

Now there is OVOlogue. The OVO group, perhaps best known for its minimalist Asian furniture emporium on Queen's Road, is making its first foray into F&B. Taking over the entire ground floor of Wo Cheong Pawn shop, the historic building where The Pawn is also housed, OVOlogue is directly connected to the group’s newest furnishing outlet next door.

As one would expect, OVOlogue rates high on décor and ambience. Retaining the original green shutters, a discreet glass door leads to a spacious, high-ceiling dining room, with a muted palette of slate grey accented with warm wooden furniture. The sparsely placed tables are perfect for quiet conversations, while the attention to detail is immaculate (adorable ceramic cups, chic utensils and stylishly dressed wait staff always signify a good beginning).

The Cuisine of OVO is contemporary Chinese, more in line with Hutong than Heng Fa Lau. It also has a split personality – you can get Cantonese dim sum in the afternoon but the main courses are Sichuan and Shanghainese (Jiangnan region).

We started off with a fragrant Fujian jasmine tea ($15) which had a delicate aroma and light, polished taste. Tempted by the waiter, we ordered two fresh soya milks ($32). They had a creamy texture with perfect semi-sweetness, and were worth the expensive price. The dim sum menu is also extensive, but everything seems to have a twist. Besides the traditional har gow (shrimp dumplings, $42), xiao long bao ($38) and stir fried flour rolls with XO sauce ($38), there are an array of new concoctions, such as extra long spring roll with shrimp and peach ($42), and emperor dumping with shrimp, fish roe and caviar ($38 for one piece).

 The risk with reinventing the classic lies in fixing something that ain't broke. And dim sum and novelty don't work. Every one of the xiao long bao, steamed in tin foil cups instead of lettuce, broke upon lifting, while the expensive crab roe topping did nothing to salvage the glutinous, soggy skin. The spring roll appeared impressive, fried to a perfect golden brown and long – more than eight inches – but the combination of small shrimps, shreds of chives, chunks of peaches and the drizzling of a sauce that tasted like Thousand Island dressing ruined a quintessential Cantonese delicacy. The flour rolls in XO sauce fared better, slightly spicy and served with sliced red pepper and bean sprouts. The waiter presented the emperor dumpling with pride – served in its own wicker basket. The shrimp filling was juicy, but at $38 a single piece, it's hard to indulge with inhibition.

Our meal began to change course when the main fares arrived. The Sliced Chicken in Sesame Sauce $98 was done to perfection. The creamy base, slightly sweet and mixed with tender slices of boneless chicken, makes for a great summer dish, as the dish is served chilled. The Sweet and Sour garoupa ($118) was flaky and coated with just the right amount of flour, while another delectable and simple dish was the stir fried asparagus $78.

Dessert again was brilliantly presented. The milk tarts with bird's nest are a luxe version of a Hong Kong classic, but I'd forgo the expensive topping of bird's nest any day of the week for a fluffy, flaky crust in place of the crumbling cookie shell.

In sum, food aside, the one thing truly outstanding about OVOlogue is their service. Wait staff are cheerful, attentive, and they anticipate customers' need. They refill the water often, change your plates at the right moment and even discreetly remind you to eat certain dishes while they are hot. Overall, OVOlogue needs to fine tune their dim sum, or, in the meantime, skip it and order from the other half of the menu for an otherwise great experience. Leslie Chan

venue.name: Pierce Chicken
venue.street: Food Court, Harbour City, Ocean Terminal,
venue.description: If you havenât tried the fried chicken chain giving KFC a run for their money, time to stop by one of their outpost for a nibble. They recently opened a food shack at Harbour City dishing out spicy âwing-zingsâ, garlicky chicken wings, and honey-dipped âhalf birdsâ. The chickens, imported from US farms, are free of MSG, and are served deep fried while still juicy and tender inside. Think of it as Junk food for the soul. Meal for two: around $100.

venue.name: Mandarin Grill & Bar
venue.description: This handsome restaurant is one of the best places in town to take food lovers. The menu is elegant, filled with luxury foods such as traditional roasts, fresh seafood, and a great oyster menu. Of all the oyster bars weâve tried, this has to be the top spot in the city for them based on variety and taste. Meal for two: around $1,100.

venue.name: China Tee Club
venue.description: China Tee Club is a private members club with a wink. You can book a table for afternoon tea for a fee of $10 per person. Scones, muffins, and tea sandwiches are on offer. Though the name suggests they are a tea club, they do great Hainan chicken rice with Chinese soup. However you need to be a member (they occasionally allow non-members to dine there if tables are available, but call in advance). The breezy colonial dining room is a nice hideaway if you are looking to escape the Central crowds. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: The Stoep
venue.description: BEST BEACHSIDE DINING Weâre welcoming the summer with a beach favourite. Take a boat ride to Lower Cheung Sha Beach on Lantau Island for a day by the seaside, and when youâre hungry, roll over to this beachside shack for a taste of South Africa. Order the mix grill for a platter of South African spiced BBQ, and do try their great homemade grainy breads, be sure to take home a loaf or two. Meal for two: around $300.

venue.name: Dijon by Pauline Coyne
venue.description: Enjoy a romantic candle-light dinner with your love in this superb French restaurant. Signature dishes include French style roasted pork (crispier and less oily than its traditional Chinese counterpart). With only 18 seats, every table enjoys its privacy. Shame the house red and desserts are mediocre. Meal for two: around $500.

venue.name: The Cheesecake Cafe
venue.description: This café is absolute heaven for any cheesecake lover, with over 30 types of cheesecakes to choose from – ranging from the classic original to Lychee Green Tea varieties. Take slices home for the kids, and pick up some nicely wrapped Meringues, too. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: Chao and Hak
venue.street: Shop U26, U/F Fitfort, 560 King's Road,
venue.description: Unlike typical brightly-lit Chinese restaurants, Chao and Hak uses dark-coloured tones and circular booths to create a tranquil and serene environment. There is also a special counter for customers who want to take away the fabulous Chiu Chow food. For something unusual, try their rice fried with specially prepared âshrimp oilâ. For something light to finish up, we recommend jelly made with lychee and rose â sweet and healthy. Shop U26, U/F Fitfort Rd. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: The Glasshouse
venue.street: Shop 13, Choi Sai Woo Shopping Centre, 45 Braemar Hill Rd,
venue.description: Diners can admire magnificent rolling hills from this restaurantâs outdoor dining area. Thereâs nothing like this in Hong Kong, designed as a glass-house complete with pond, swimming pool and deck, the place positively sparkles at night. If you donât mind spending a little extra, allow us to recommend the hotpot ($400, feeds three). Meal for two: around $150.

venue.name: Little Egret Restaurant
venue.street: Kerry Lake Egret Nature Park, 2 Hung Lam Drive, Tai Po Kau,
venue.description: Polynesian tapestry, Native American pottery, East African Masai sculpture... Little Egret is a must-go for the globe-trotter. Housed in a two-level Mediterranean-style building, the 6,000 sq ft restaurant shines with eco-glamour. Parents don't need to worry about naughty kids; theyâll be kept busy in the âdiscovery shipâ and education booths. The food is just as exotic and multi-cultural as the dÃ©cor, including Thai curry, Hawaiian shrimps, Mexican taco, roasted African chicken and French escargots (with herbs from their own garden). The restaurant hosts lots of parties and weddings, so call ahead for a reservation. Meal for two: around $400.

venue.name: Mi Casa Chilean Oyster Bar
venue.description: From the fact that walk-in diners can't get a seat and reservations are a must, Mi Casa is popular with oyster-lovers (try the oyster platter, $298). Non-seafood must-eats include Australia M9 Wagyu and apple sherbet. Upon request, the two friendly restaurant owners will let you know when new oysters arrive. Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Macro Bistro
venue.description: Macroâs all-you-can-eat chocolate âhot potâ is highly popular and quite cheap ($48 per person). Alternatively, enjoy a cup of English tea and finger sandwiches between the hours of 2pm-6pm for a little bit more. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: Wooden Table Home Kitchen
venue.description: The best time to visit this place is late afternoon. Immerse yourself in the relaxed atmosphere, listen to some slow jazz, and indulge in the restaurant's afternoon tea buffet. Chocoholic alert â you just have to try the dark chocolate brownie and chocolate mousse. Other popular sugar fixes include puddings, cheese cakes, waffles and ice-creams. Meal for two: around $350.

venue.name: Taiwan Beef Noodle
venue.description: Traditional Chinese tables and landscape paintings of China set the mood here. While they serve assorted Taiwanese style snacks, make sure you try their signature dish: chicken with ginger, green onion, garlic and sesame sauce in pot (known as "the chicken with three sauces"). Meal for two: around $120.

venue.name: Tin Hau Laksa
venue.description: The laksa here is simply fabulous, a perfect balance of coconut and curry. Their bak kut teh with tender pork ribs is strong in flavour, filling the room with herbal aroma. The Hainan chicken rice is another popular choice. Finish the meal on a lighter note with a cup of chrysanthemum tea. Celebrity watch: Actor Daniel Wu and model Lisa S are regular customers here. Meal for two: around $110.

venue.name: A-Link+
venue.street: C. C. Wu Building, 302-308, Hennessy Rd

venue.name: Cultural Centre, Rm AC1, Level 4, Administration Building
Santa Lucia Restaurant and Lounge
venue.description:
Hidden away on the 38th floor of the newly opened Hotel Panorama, the Santa Lucia Restaurant and Lounge is going through a quiet and dignified identity crisis.

Sure, the floor-to-ceiling view of Victoria Harbour, touted as one of Santa Lucia's best assets, is impressive, but is it a lounge? Is it a restaurant? The trendy music and extensive cocktail list seem to point towards the former, but the crisp white tablecloth and detailed menu lean towards the latter. As to the lighting, is it trying to be intimate or functional? The candles, overpowered by neon lights, can't seem to decide. And then there's the menu...

Although billed as 'modern European', some Asian classics have still managed to squeeze themselves among the impressive list of dishes (which was unfortunately also full of typos). However modern the cuisine, any restaurant presenting its menu as European would have a hard time justifying Santa Lucia's Japanese Kurobuta pork, cold soba noodles, coconut ceviche and lemongrass sorbet.

But thankfully, chef Nathan Hogan – of Hotel LKF/Azure fame – knows what he's doing. Our starter of cornmeal crusted foie gras on potato rosti was just melt-in-the-mouth enough to match the crunch of the accompanying root vegetable crisps, and the raisin compote presented in the belly of a small toasted brioche provided just enough sweetness to counterbalance the liver's intensity. Deciding to stay within the limits of European cuisine, we also opted for the classic lobster bisque with cognac and tarragon crème fraîche, which was thick and creamy, with hidden chunks of lobster creating a pleasant textural surprise.

Our waiter had recommended we try the rib-eye tenderloin beef and we soon understood why – the meat was tender and its jus flavoursome, while the soft squash gratin and crunchy asparagus made the perfect plate pals. We also tried the lamb, which was perfectly rosy and offered us some much awaited Mediterranean flavour in the form of mint risotto, tomato confit and lemon crumb crust.

Each of the meal's flavours was given the respect it deserved, each texture preserved, and on the whole the food picked up the slack for the clueless waiters and confused atmosphere. And although the lemon meringue pie's meringue was a little too much on the foamy side, the overall culinary experience was good enough to make us just want to sit back and enjoy the intensity of the ingredients while the ambience, view, and menu tried to figure out who they really wanted to be.

Jessica Morris

venue.name: Fire
venue.description: You canât take it too seriously when whimsical W Hotel opens a fine dining restaurant. It is in fact fine dining, but done with a wink. Fire offers the best of flame-licked meats and other roasted goods. Do give the grilled watermelon a go, and if itâs your first time try out the baby suckling pig. Meal for two: around $2,000.

venue.name: Shama
venue.street: Shop 48 G/F, Chungking Mansions, 36-44 Nathan Rd
venue.description:
Compared to the dozens of similar CKM (Chungking Mansions) South Asian eateries, the recently opened Shama is a tad on the expensive side. But you’re paying to avoid an onerous (and, in the summer months, aromatic) CKM elevator ride which, for many, is a premium worth paying. This ground-floor eatery is typically cramped for the locality, with seating for no more than about ten people dining in comfort. But Shama does deliver all the usual Anglo-Indian favourites: chicken tikka masala (small portioned but delish, $48), rogan josh (again, small portion, $48), lamb kormas ($45), tandoori-cooked chicken tikka ($50), nans (plain $8, butter $12) that are crisp and fluffy in all the right places, and – something of a rarity in this predominantly Islamic vicinity – nicely chilled draft Carlsberg ($32).

Shama’s warm coloration of russet reds and ochres is also extremely calming and cosy to sit in. Who comes here? Mostly, soft-spoken merchants and traders discussing ‘Chindia’ trading possibilities (there’s usually a conspiratorial hush here), the odd Western tourist peering earnestly into the Hong Kong Lonely Planet Guide, residents from CKM’s West African enclaves, and some social anthropologists on research assignments. If you want to wimp out on the CKM elevator experience then come to this ground floor eatery for a treat minus the body heat. In sum, Shama is a fine place to enjoy a leisurely meal and collect one’s thoughts in an unhurried sanctuary of calm.

venue.name: Iroha
venue.street: 1/F, Cameron Plaza, 23-25A Cameron Road, Tsim Sha Tsui
venue.description:
The bright and airy ambiance of Iroha is a welcome respite from normal yakiniku shops, which usually prefer a dark, watering-hole feel. Instead, this neat and cosy restaurant offers three seating areas: cheerily lit private booths, tatami matting, and a large exclusive room for 12 people. As one would expect, various types of Wagyu cuts are available, and while all of them are superb, the nakaochi karube ($230) is undoubtedly the star of the show. This beautiful marbled short rib is as tender, succulent and tasty as any meat can be, something steak lovers should definitely fall head over heels for.

The thick cut Wagyu beef tongue ($200) from the a la carte menu is another delicacy that should not be missed. With astounding flavour, it just melts in your mouth – pure heaven. However, be prepared to spend. The price of most dishes is generally on the steep side, but you do get what you pay for, and a meal here is well worth every penny. Trust us when we say the quality and variety on offer, especially the extensive choice of Wagyu cuts, is simply unbeatable in Hong Kong.

KC Gourmet

venue.name: Simpatico
venue.street: Shop 19, 1/F, Peak Galleria, 118 Peak Rd, The Peak
venue.description:
Simpatico is simply irresistible. On a crystal clear twilight, we were seated in the comfortably modern dining room, which opened onto their much sought after outdoor terrace. Their open pizza kitchen was pumping out a delightful fresh bread scent, perfuming the entire restaurant. The dishes here are rustic Italian comfort food.

We ordered the capricciosa pizza to start. Generous helpings of sausage, artichoke, mushroom, and black olive dotted every slice. The bread was chewy and super fresh, the crust thin and crispy. Another starter of beef carpaccio with walnut, artichoke and pecorino cheese warmed the palate. When we finally got to ordering our mains around 8pm, we were told many of the dishes we wanted to order – we had been eyeing our neighbors dishes with envy – were sold out, including the spaghetti vongole, roast spring chicken with rosemary, and the ink ragliolini with lobster and zucchini. Instead, we went for the fresh pappardelle with Bolognese ragu, and the tagliatelle with broad beans and crispy ham. Our compliments to the chef, both sauces were silky and sublime.

The wine list is mostly on the Italian side, but we ordered an Australian Pinot Noir, which we regretted shortly after opening. Still, our poor selection couldn’t distract from what was in all, a highly pleasurable evening out.

venue.name: Lardos Steak House
venue.street: G/F, 4B Hang Hau Village, Tseung Kwan O
venue.description:
Lardos is inconspicuously tucked into a street teeming with steamboat restaurants in Hang Hau Village. The no-frills shop front with a parking-lot view may initially, and worryingly, appear to be another local chain Steak Expert. But just beyond the door, the sight of flames licking a 36-ounce rib-steak promises a gastronomic feat for any hungry Rugby jock, and dispels any doubts that Lardos is authentic.

We’re convinced it’s the only place in Hong Kong to enjoy great steak without the fuss of dressing up. Such unpretentiousness extends to the menu: cuts from Australian, United States, Japanese, and Argentinian cattle are simply put, well marbled and juicy. Reputedly the owner, Henry Theil, supplies most of the five-star hotels and top clubs in town with his steak, and the price at Lardos can be less than half what you’d pay elsewhere. As a gravy, we recommend the black pepper sauce for an extra kick, and would forgo the bland béarnaise. Among the sides, we were delighted by large, luxuriously plump New Zealand green-lipped mussels in white wine, which arrived speedily and with sauce to spare for dipping warm French bread and thick-cut steak fries. Traditional trimmings, such as the creamed spinach (overly pungent with nutmeg), mushrooms with garlic and butter, and mashed potatoes, provide solid accompaniment for the steak. Washing it all down with a fresh and perfectly chilled Stella Artois, we were satiated and cheery. The unimpressive simple salad with thousand island on the side, tawdry foil wrapped butter patty, and cup of water clearly straight from the tap, were all found forgivable in a rare and surprisingly altruistic moment from a critic feeling every yia men well spent. Meal for two: around $500 including drinks.

Ciara Tan

venue.name: Cafe Locomotive
venue.description:
Over the past two years Tai Hang’s Wun Sha St has gone from a dimly lit residential street filled with tired looking walk-ups to something of a Soho in the making, with plenty of stylised eateries popping up all over the place. Among them Vietnamese eatery Café Locomotive sits proudly, with all the buzz of a current culinary darling, its queue spilling right out onto the street and the bodyguards of high-profile Rolls-Royce owners standing rigidly at the entrance.

We were lucky to get one of only three bench seats inside the small dining room, which seats about 50. Nostalgically decorated as a classic train carriage, with a fake "luggage rack" filled with old suitcases, its muted mustard walls, ceiling fan and rattan chairs all create an old world charm. But décor can only do so much for a restaurant's reputation; Vietnamese eateries abound in Hong Kong but most are bastardised with Chinese dishes.

Vietnam's signature Pho noodles with beef are generally reduced to a murky soup seasoned heavily with star anise, fish sauce and ginger to mask its lack of flavour. This is where Café Locomotive shows its difference – the Pho Dai, Vietnamese noodles with raw beef ($38) is a large, savoury bowl with a mildly sweet broth that comes from hours of simmering with copious amount of beef brisket and bones. The kick from the star anise, cinnamon and ginger is there, but the richness of the broth combined with silky, al dente noodles and paper thin beef with just the right amount of fat is perfectly balanced. Topped by a helping of crispy garlic and raw onions, this meal in a bowl costs just $38 and for double the price we also tried the super-sized Locomotive Special ($63), a pho containing all of the above plus a generous helping of tendons, brisket and meat balls. However, two of Vietnam's most popular appetisers – spring roll ($33) and minced pork wrapped in rice paper ($38)– failed to impress. The spring rolls were appropriately short and thin but weren’t wrapped tightly enough, so that too much oil had seeped between the layers during frying. The pork was even more disappointing, with the rice paper being too thick and the accompanying brown dip tasting too much like Teriyaki. The Brownie points total was boosted by the shredded chicken and cabbage salad ($62), though, as the chicken shreds were tender and moist and the cabbage was crisp and refreshing.

Café Locomotive’s service suffers from the small size of its kitchens and any requests that don't relate to food are quickly forgotten, too. Luckily, the fresh lime soda is made with plenty of lime and just the right amount of sweetness, so it makes the wait worthwhile. Our dinner ended on a positive note nonetheless, as the desserts were much more sophisticated than most of the competition’s. We tried the crème brulée ($39), which had a perfectly soft and creamy texture and a surprising hint of ginger. And thanks to the crispy biscotti sprinkled with cinnamon served alongside, this meal was all in all an entirely civilised affair.

Lesile Chung. Meal for one: around $180.
venue.opening_times: Open Mon-Fri 11.30am-3pm, 6pm-11pm; Sat, Sun & public holidays 11.30am-11pm.

Extension Activities Room, Shek Tong Tsui Public Library

Hong Kong Cultural Centre Grand Theatre
Hong Kong Cultural Centre Concert Hall
Pak Vai Plaza

venue.name: Venue, time, and ticket prices to be announced
N-Set Music
venue.street: Flat 310, 3/F, Century Centre, 44-46 Hung To Rd

venue.name: Concert Hall, Academy of Performing Arts
River Trade Golf, Area 46, Junction of Mong Fat St. and Lung Mun Rd., Tuen Mun, New Territories
McAulay Studio Theatre
venue.street: Hong Kong Arts Centre, 2 Harbour Rd

venue.name: River Trade Golf
venue.street: Area 46, Junction of Mong Fat St and Lung Mun Rd

venue.name: Frog Face Fish
venue.description: Wyndham Streetâs seafood restaurant Frog Face Fish have teamed up with Petuna, one of Australiaâs famous fish supplier. The restaurant hosts âGourmet Fish and Chipsâ each Tuesday, and features items like Petuna trout, mushy pea puree, truffle aioli and confit fingerling potatoes. Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Alfonso III
venue.description: For those who have tried this small Portuguese restaurant, there is no need to go anywhere else. Afonso III serves up some of the most traditional Macanese dishes. Try the hearty vegetable soup followed by a cod-fish dish, any cod-fish dish as they are all great. Thereâs usually a cod fish choice on the daily special board, so if you are lost for all its choices go for that one. Be cautious of the large family-style portions while you are ordering. Remember one main dish feeds four.

venue.name: A Petisqueira
venue.description: Famous for its generous Iberian-sized portions and wide variety of Macanese dishes, you will see many families dining at this spot. The Portuguese owners of this Taipa institution will help guide you through the menu if you have any trouble. A word to the wise: the vinho verde goes well with all the seafood here, with the cod dishes providing the most memorable pairing.

venue.name: Bambu
venue.street: Shop 1033, The Venetian Macao, Cotai Strip
venue.description: Diners here take âall-you-can-eatâ to the max. If thatâs your kinda sport, you will be in a room of your type. The lobster is usually the first to be grabbed. But the managers know this and have a constant refill so everyone gets some. They serve Chinese, Thai, Indian, Japanese, and Malay dishes at the hot tops so picky eaters can pick and choose.

venue.name: Boa Mesa
venue.description: This new, casual coffee shop is like a slice of Lisbon in the heart of Macau. Itâs the kind of place where you expect to run into homesick Portuguese filling up on authentic comfort food such as soul-warming soups, chargrilled chicken and chocolate mousse. Itâs a little tricky to find, being a short climb up a side street next to McDonaldâs near the Leal Senado square.

venue.name: Cafe Bela Vista
venue.street: 2/F, Mandarin Oriental Macau, Avenida da Amizade
venue.description: The attractive, Portuguese-style architecture and interior are a reminder of Macauâs colonial past. The buffet is never ending, breakfast bleeds into lunch, then lunch into dinner. They do tend to close earlier than most other eateries in town (9.30pm) so to get the most out of the dinner buffet, get there early.

venue.name: Cafe Deco
venue.street: G/F, Grand Canal Shops, The Venetian Macao, Cotai Strip
venue.description: The Fritz Lang-inspired decor is impressive and this place is open 24/seven. Mornings see one of the most impressive buffets in town, serving Western and Chinese favourites from waffles to dim sum. Thereâs also an a la carte menu offering an international mix of dishes from Indian curries to chocolate sundaes. On a game or concert night at the nearby arena, expect to find the bar bursting at the seams. The only spot for all-day dining inside The Venetian.

venue.name: Clube Militar
venue.description: You canât miss this fading beauty while driving along the road of casino city. The elegant pink lady sits amongst the best of them, next to the Lisboa, Wynn, Star World and Leal Senado square. The club has a reciprocal arrangement with the Foreign Correspondents Club, but offer reservations for dinner to the public. Be sure to snag a window view seat in this colonial grand dame. One note to mention: the womenâs washroom downstairs is haunted and it is advised for lady-guests to enter in packs.

venue.name: Fat Siu Lau
venue.description: Although this might be Macauâs oldest restaurant, you would never know it was built in 1903 following last yearâs ill-advised art deco facelift. Now it looks so modern and pop-y that it has lost its old-world charm, and with it, most of its original customers. All that remains is the name and a new clientele of wealthy mainland Chinese. However, the Portuguese food is as good as ever, especially the seafood.

venue.name: FogoSamba
venue.street: Shop 2412, Grand Canal Shops, The Venetian Macao, Cotai Strip
venue.description: The staff at this Brazilian barbecue will continuously come by with large skewers of roast meats carved table side. You can eat as much as your stomach can take. And when you need something more than meat, you can fill up your plate at the upscale salad bar. The ground-floor bar is a succession of power dancers showing off their classroom-trained tango.

venue.name: Fernando's
venue.description: Fernandoâs is an institution. Every taxi driver will know exactly where to take you. Donât expect to be seated right away if you go on a Friday or Saturday night. People start queuing up around 5.30pm to grab a table. Luckily thereâs a bar out the back where diners can snack on plates of chorizo or play a game of foosball while they wait. Inside, diners linger over clams in clam and tomoato sauce, mopping up the garlicky liquid with warm crusty bread. An order of caldo verde, char-grilled pork ribs, along with a bottle of cheap-but-tasty vinho verde, try a bottle of Aveleda, will erase all the waiting-time misery. And, as they say, "hunger is the best spice". Nearby Hac Sa beach and offers a good option for a lesuirely stroll after your feast.

venue.name: O Manel
venue.description: This small, Portuguese-run brasserie serves up great deep fried cod balls made with large flakes of cod, mashed potatoes and parsley. The Cantonese-speaking owner will translate todayâs special. Sausage fans will appreciate their grilled linguica, the Portuguese cousin to the Spanish chorizo. O Manel is not as famous as Fernandoâs but it is just as good, and they take reservations so no more waiting for hours to get a table.

venue.name: O Santos
venue.description: Look for this restaurant on the street in Taipa with all the cookie shops. Delicious Portuguese favourites such as bacalhau (salted cod fish), garlic prawns, and Portuguese-style salad all make their appearance on their menu.

venue.name: Roka
venue.street: Unit 1015, Level 1, The Grand Canal Shoppes, Venetian Macau
venue.description: The Venetian has its own version of London's famous Japanese bar-restaurant, Zuma. The great lounge area is perfect for sidelining gamblers and having a drink with a little cosmopolitan scenery. The best private dining room on the casino floor by far. Must-try dishes: anything robata, sushi and sashimi platters, Alaskan king crab legs with yuzu butter, tuna tartar with caviar and quail yolk, and green tea soba. Desserts are good, but skip it was they are nothing outside the box.

venue.name: Restaurante Perola
venue.street: 3/F, Sands Casino, 203 Largo de Monte Carlo
venue.description: Even though this restaurant is situated inside the theme park that is the Sands hotel and casino, the food is fantastic and authentically Macanese. Recommended dishes include minchee made with minced meat, potatoes, and onions served with a big fried egg on top (very Macanese). It is said this is a good cure for hangovers, much like a full English fry-up. Also try the crab curry seafood cataplana and some Super Bock, a Portuguese beer, to wash it all down. Gets crowded so call ahead to book.

venue.name: Restaurante Litoral
venue.description: Ask any taxi driver where to have the most authentic Macanese food and they are likely to take you here, located in the Inner Harbour district. Donât plan on going unless you have a booking or arrive before 5.30pm. This elegant restaurant tends to be packed every night with hungry tourists looking to taste the real thing. The real thing being African chicken so sweet and flavourful that people tend to order a dish per person even though it is suppose to be family-style. Also try the ribs or stir-fried clams and sop the sauce up with warm Portuguese buns. The wine list is superb and includes some of the best wines from the Iberian Peninsula. On weekends, have the number of a cabbie ready as you could, quite literally, wait hours for one to drive by.

venue.name: 360 Cafe
venue.description: Opened in 2001, this is Macauâs only revolving restaurant, perched high atop Macau Tower, near the observation deck. It takes over 1Âœ hours for the restaurant to make a full spin. The food is tourist-friendly, offering something for everyone from Southeast Asian favourites, morsels of Cantonese, Macanese and Continental dishes. Don't go only for a feast, but also take in the stunning views. Not only is it Macauâs only revolving restaurant, but it is also its only non-smoking one. Reservations highly recommended on weekends.

venue.name: Cinnebar
venue.street: Casino Level, Wynn Macau, Rua Cidade de Sintra
venue.description: They’ve replaced Tryst nightclub with a softer, plusher lounge for guests looking for something other than gambling at the Wynn. The bar has good value single malt whiskies so be sure to try out a few. They also feed you Japanese tapas throughout the evening to keep you put.

venue.name: M Bar
venue.street: Lobby level, MGM Grand Macau, Avenida Dr Sun Yat Sen
venue.description: This small, understated bar located at the end of the hotel lobby is one of the most plush in Macau. The decor features Chihuly glass sculptures, a grand chandelier, high-back arm-sofas and velvet curtains. The live vocal and piano duo plays jazz every evening and gives this place the feel of a Fitzgerald novel.

venue.name: Okada
venue.street: Casino level, Wynn Macau, Rua Cidade de Sintra
venue.description: The Wynn Macau imported a sake sommelier from Japan to man their Japanese eatery Okada. The sake menu is vast and there is an art to choosing the right sake for each course, but if you are having trouble, Sachii Imamura will be happy to make a recommendation. Do start with their saketinis and try one of their dessert sakes at the end of your meal. The food is traditional Japanese served in a modern zen dÃ©cor steps outside the gambling floor of the Wynn.

venue.name: Whisky Bar
venue.description: This bar is a rare oasis of calm in the midst of the sensory overload that is the Macau gambling scene in general, and the StarWorld hotel in particular. The âmenâs clubâ bar boasts 89 different whiskies, include three rare bottles of Macallan 1946 (only 50 bottles are available worldwide). But if youâre not a feeling particularly like a high roller, then the Glenmorangie 18 yrs is a nice, and affordable, sipper.

venue.name: Bar Florian
venue.street: Level 1, The Grand Canal Shoppes, The Venetian Resort-Hotel, Baia De Nossa Senhora De Esperanca, Estrada Da Cotai
venue.description: Smack in the middle of the Venetianâs mammoth casino hall is a lovely Italian cafÃ©. The all-day bar is a great spot to linger over your whisky of choice or enjoy a simple espresso before jumping back on the blackjack tables.

venue.name: Blue Frog Bar & Grill
venue.street: Shop 1037, Level 1, Grand Canal Shoppes, The Venetian Macao, Cotai
venue.description: This relaxed American-style bar is an import from Shanghai, where it already has seven locations. In the Paris of the Orient, Blue Frog is one of the cityâs hottest, late-night bars, though during the daytime it becomes a family favourite. Whatever time you roll up, order their famous Montana burger, a foot-long stack of meat, tomato, onion rings, bacon and pickles. Meal for two: around $800.

venue.name: Henri's Gallery
venue.description: This fisherman-themed Macanese restaurant claims to serve the best African chicken in the enclave, though much of its reputation comes from the fact Gourmet magazine once wrote a glowing review for the place in the 1980s. Still, to this day diners flock to Henriâs out of the way location to taste its famous chicken. Taxis are not readily available, so either arrange a private car, or bring bus money. Meal for two: around $500.

venue.name: Morton's of Chicago
venue.street: Level 1, Grand Canal Shoppes, The Venetian Macao, Estrada da Baia de N. Senhora da Esperanca, Cotai
venue.description: When gamblers are celebrating their big winnings, they come here for steaks, lobsters and all things obscenely expensive. Suitably, this famous American steakhouse chain is the most profitable restaurant at the Venetian. From the menu, we recommend the 24oz porterhouse or the 20oz New York sirloin. But if your winnings werenât anything to brag about, there are always complimentary filet mignon sandwiches during their daily 5pm-7pm happy hour. Meal for two: around $1,400.

venue.name: Tou Tou Koi
venue.description: Getting a table in this Macau institution is almost impossible if you don't have a reservation. This 70 year-old restaurant has an elegant, newish dÃ©cor, but the recipe for their decades old braised sharkâs fin with chicken and Chinese ham, served in a huge tureen, has the most sublime and rich white broth. For a less decadent meal try their dim sum lunch. Meal for two: around $400 (much more if you want sharkâs fin).

venue.name: Fat Burger
venue.street: Grand Canal Shops, The Venetian Macau, Cotai Strip
venue.description: Tourists and locals flood this nostalgic burger joint on the famous Las Vegas strip and with the opening of the Hong Kong branch nowhere in sight (the hoardings are still up on its proposed Wan Chai location), the next best thing is to try it in Macau. Fat Burgerâs juicy patty, topped with fresh relish and tomatoes, is comfort food at its best. Throw cholesterol caution to the wind and add a crispy bacon topping. Meal for two: around $80.

venue.name: Imperial Court
venue.street: 1/F, MGM Grand Hotel, Avenida Dr Sun Yat Sen, Nape
venue.description: With so much razzmatazz surrounding the opening of the MGM Grand, youâd expect something similarly over the top with their signature Chinese restaurant. A dramatic dining environment with dark wood and high ceiling makes Imperial Court a good place to entertain â even children. The menu is predominantly Cantonese, but they also make an exquisite Peking duck. If youâre really trying to impress, invite the in-house sommelier to recommend a wine to go with every course. Meal for two: around $800.

venue.name: Yee Shun Milk Company
venue.description: Long before Lord Stowâs Portuguese natas (egg tarts) became Macauâs signature dessert, Macanese were flocking to Yee Shun Milk Company for their silky steamed milk pudding. The decades-old shop in the historic Leal Senado town square is still serving their all-time favourite, ginger steamed milk pudding. In the evening, be prepared to share tables and stand in line. Dessert for two: around $50.

venue.name: Antonio
venue.description: One man is single-handedly buying up all the decrypted colonial homes in Taipa village, and converting them into fine restaurants and bars. And itâs exactly what this newly glam city of steel, black glass and marble needs: a bit of old world charm. Antonio Neves Coelho, a man of many merits and charms (married three times and counting), enjoys his life (restaurateur four times and counting). In the kitchen he does a mean gambas ao alhinho (thatâs shrimp with a head of crushed garlic, $85), ovos Mexidos com espargos verdes e chourico (salty scrambled eggs, pork sausages and asparagus) that works really well alone or on warm bread rolls ($75). And a must have: Queijo de carbra gratinado, temperado com azeite e mel, servido em pao torrado com alface e vinagre balsamico (goatâs cheese gratin with honey over carob toast, $105), as well as being a mouthful, it is incredibly addictive. The acidic goat cheese was smoothed with a lacquer of honey. This combination on toast was the perfect starter. Our main, Arroz de Marisco Ã âAntÃ³nioâ servido em tacho de barro (Antonioâs seafood rice for two, $310) came out like wet paella, a broth brimming with prawns, clams, scallops, mussels and ample monkfish. Point of note: the spice levels are adjusted by your nationality. When waiters take your order, a box is ticked to indicate your ethnicity. Salty if the customer is Portuguese, no salt if Japanese, spicy if Chinese, and âfor expats, I always serve them fish and chips,â says Antonio. Ours came out salty and spicy. It was served in a pretty copper pan from the chefâs hometown, as is every other item on the menu. Alan Wong Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Inagiku
venue.description: With almost every casino in town boasting its own branded eatery, StarWorld needed to catch up to stay in the game. To do so, theyâve brought in upmarket Japanese teppanyaki restaurant Inagiku. The diner is not a far departure from Hong Kongâs own Inagikus, serving up pricy sushi platters, kaiseki, and tempuras. Meal for two: around $1,200.

venue.name: Lord Stow's Bakery
venue.street: Rua de Tassara, Coloane Town Square, Macau
venue.description: Unless you are staying on the Cotai Strip, be prepared to spend 100 patacas on a cab ride to sleepy Coloane. Stop at the town square and head to where a large crowd is congregating, and youâll find the legendary Lord Stowâs small bakery, churning out dozens of sweet, savoury Portuguese natas (egg tarts). Eat one on the spot to enjoy the flaky crust, and take a dozen home for your friends.

venue.name: Naam Thai
venue.description: Naam is an oasis from the singing slot machines and gambling traffic. The peaceful modern interior is a great backdrop for Thai curries, tom yum soup and spicy and refreshing salads. Natural daylight floods the space with light, with the added bonus of pleasant green views. Meal for two: around $400.

venue.name: Paris
venue.street: 11 Avenida de Kwong Tong, Edificio Triumph IV (across from the Macau Jockey Club), Taipa
venue.description: Paris has a piano, boudoir, red velvet ropes and gold everywhere. Think Moulin Rouge meets Macau. There is also French onion soup, pate, tripe and French pastries. Did we mention the Parisian influence? Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Robuchon A Galera
venue.description: Before setting up shop in the Landmark, Joel Robuchon opened a restaurant in the Hotel Lisboa in 2001. It was the first noticeable move towards a Las Vegas-style dining scene in Macau. Diners can choose from his modern French a la carte or degustation menu, with a stellar wine list. Meal for two: around $1,800.

venue.name: Noodle and Congee Corner
venue.description: The show here is not so much the gambling floor this diner looks over, but the chefs behind the glass wall throwing long strings of noodle across the room into a large boiling vat, shaving dough into a bowl from a plated hat (itâll make sense when you see it) and other circus tricks involving pasta. You choose your own adventure here, mixing up different noodles with your choice of soup base and meats. If the noodle show wasnât enough, the tea ceremony is not to be missed, either. Meal for two: around $160.

venue.name: Khyber Pass
venue.street: Block E, 7/F E-2, Chungking Mansions, 36-44 Nathan Rd
venue.description: CHEAP EATS Great cheap, Indian fare, with large bottles of Tsingtao on hand to take the zing out of the vindaloo. Plain tables, simple chairs, no-fuss service with a smile, and an awesome gents (think: urinal in a closet). Get your fingers into piles of the generous garlic naan, and scoop up the many excellent and affordable curries, with a wide range of veggie and meat options. Meal for two: around $120.

venue.name: One Harbour Road
venue.street: Grand Hyatt Hong Kong, 1 Harbour Rd,
venue.description: This grande dame has truly special pan-Chinese dining, complete with beautiful sunsets over Victoria Harbour. Well, that is until the reclamation is complete and new buildings are put up, so enjoy it while you can. On their menu, they have medicinal Chinese double-boiled soups, great for when the weather changes. Meal for two: around $800.

venue.name: Stone pot
venue.street: Shop 37, UG/F, City Walk, 1 Yeung Uk Rd,
venue.description: This one-pot wonder has lots of people coming out to the just opened City Walk in Tsuen Wan to see what the noise is about. Great bak kut tehs, Chiu Chow style deep-fried shrimp balls, and spare ribs cooked in dark vinegar. Meal for two: around $150.

venue.name: Waterfront Bar & Restaurant
venue.street: G/F, 58 Yung Shue Wan Main St, Lamma Island.
venue.description: Duck down a hidden lane off Main Street to find this seaside late-nighter, which not only does big breakfasts for the hungover, but also a range of hearty western meals at night, including a decent pumpkin soup, cottage pie, and standard surf and turf options. Also a nice place to enjoy a drink as the sun goes down. Meal for two: $200.

venue.name: Wagyu Lounge
venue.street: LG/F, Hollywood Commercial House, 3-5 Old Bailey St
venue.description: It’s like Wagyu, but a lounge… The interior is lined with high top tables and plush leather couches, with a rectangular shaped bar on the left. A DJ booth is on hand for occasional DJs to spin or for an iPod to do the work, while the Mojitos are delicious and the shots strong. Meal for two: around $500.

venue.name: Aspasia
venue.description: Pasta dishes and seafood are celebrated on this menu by Master Chef Roland Schuller. He reinvents Italian favourites by keeping what makes this cuisine so lovable (fresh produce, tenure skills, understanding of al dente) and adds modern elements using non-traditional ingredients. However, with its luxe Alice in Wonderland theme, the interior design is anything but traditional. Meal for two: around $1,000.

venue.name: Petrus
venue.description: This restaurant has stood the test of time. With over 20 years in business, they are doing something right. Classical French fare with excellent service and a romantic atmosphere make this the quintessential spot for popping the question. Meal for two: around $1,200.

venue.name: Graze
venue.street: G/F, Chaoâs Bldg, 143-145 Bonham Strand, Sheung Wan
venue.description: CHEAP EATS This quaint cafÃ© is further evidence of the gentrification of Sheung Wan. The bright and happy space serves small cafÃ© eats such as English muffins, sarnies, healthy salads, hearty sandwiches, and great bakery items. They are also one of the few spots where you can grab a fruit smoothie and chai tea latte in this part of town. Warning: their double chocolate cupcakes are for die-hard choco eaters only. Meal for two: around $120.

venue.name: FINDS Cafe
venue.street: Rooftop, Elements Mall, 1 Austin Rd West
venue.description: This cooler-than-thou cafe lines the courtyard of Elements Mallâs Civic Square. This place transforms itself throughout the day, from breakfast pit stop to afternoon nibbles to after work happy hour host. A wide variety of Scandi tapas, or as they say âScapasâ, is on offer. Try their signature hot balls made with salmon, shrimp, chillis and capers. They even have a foie gras and chicken version with truffle dressing. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: Lobster Bar
venue.street: Level 6, Island Shangri-la, Supreme Court Rd
venue.description: Someone once said, âIf a bar can attract women, then the men will follow.â This is certainly the case at this hotel bar, which is decorated to look like a grand dameâs boudoir. The cocktails are measured- perfectly, and the beers come in frosted pewter mugs. Go for drinks, stay for the dinner, you simply have to try their lobster tartar. Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Ayuthaiya
venue.street: Shop G23, Festival Walk, Kowloon Tong
venue.description: The Thai chefs place much emphasis on spices and herbs at this well-situated mall resto. Signature dishes include crispy soft shell crab with black peppercorn, sprigs and lemongrass, scallops on half shell with pomelo, mango, spicy lime lemon, baby lobster sashimi with raw garlic, green chili, and Nahm Jim. Meal for two: around $400

venue.name: The BBQ Shop
venue.street: Shop 1, G/F, Lee King Mansion, 83 Electric Rd, Tin Hau
venue.description: CHEAP EATS At this tiny barbeque shop with marvellous ingredients, recommended items include sirloin steak seasoned with wine, spicy tiger-pawns with lemon-grass, salted soft chicken bones and roasted scallops. With only 15 seats, a little bit of waiting is necessary, but most definitely worthwhile. Meal for two: around $100

venue.name: Bibimbap
venue.street: 3 Fuk Lo Tsun Rd, Kowloon City
venue.description: Go through the black gate adorned with a Tai-Chi symbol and you will enter the world of traditional Korean bibimbap. Using a combination of Thai and Japanese rice, the bibimbaps with beef, pork and seafood taste equally great, or try the tofu bibimbap for a more vegetarian style. All ingredients are imported from Korea, which explains the authentic taste. Meal for two: around $250.

venue.name: Jolly Thinkers
venue.street: 14/F, Capricorn Centre, 155 Sai Yeung Choi St North, Mong Kok
venue.description: BOARDGAME CAFÃ As one might expect, the highlight here is the cafÃ©âs numerous board games â with over 300 different types (including role playing, detective, war, strategy, and party) available, suitable for two to ten players. Staff will happily teach customers the rules to unfamiliar games. Consider it the more intelligent, and social, alternative to the computer. Meal for two: around $80.

venue.name: Keung Kee
venue.street: G/F, Fu Chau Building, 485-491 Un Chau St, Cheung Sha Wan
venue.description: CHEAP EATS Keung Kee is a typical Hong Kong style cha chaan tang. For light snacks, try toast with silky milk tea. For lunch or dinner, choose from the rows of char siu (roasted pork), goose or chicken hanging in the display window. Another recommendation are the traditional Chinese soups, boiled for a couple of hours to produce (supposedly) great health benefits. Meal for two: around $100.

venue.name: Korean BBQ Restaurant
venue.description: Korean style all-you-can-eat BBQ buffet with plenty of appetizers, hot dishes, meat and seafood. For first-timers, the manager will show you how to barbeque properly â with thinner meat on the outside and thicker pieces closer to the heat. To wash it all down, pick the hot and slightly-bitter ginseng soup to sooth your throat. Unfortunately, not many desserts are available except jelly and salad Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: IR 1968
venue.street: Shop 701, The Menu @ Level 7, New Town Plaza, Phase 1, Sha Tin
venue.description: AUTHENTIC INDONESIAN CUISINE The outlandish Southeast Asian dÃ©cor gives you an idea of the food served at IR 1968, a branch of the original in Causeway Bay, where, as name suggests, theyâve been producing Indonesian dishes for over 40 years. Try Pepes Ikan (spicy fish with banana leaf), and the very traditional Gado Gado (a gorgeous portion of Indonesian salad, assorted Asian vegetables, bean curd, boiled egg, and served with peanut sauce and prawn crackers. Great on the stomach and budget. Meal for two: around $300.

venue.name: Fish & Co.
venue.street: Shop 709, The Menu @ Level 7, New Town Plaza, Phase 1, Sha Tin
venue.description: FISH N CHIPS You might be eating inside a mall, but some of the best restaurants are located where the shoppers are these days. At Singaporean-owned Fish & Co, they do a decent English fish and chips with tartar sauce and a wedge of lemon. They also have a bunch of western dishes such as prawn fettuccini with a chilli cream sauce, and some surprisingly decent cocktails. Meal for two: around $300.

venue.name: Civic and Municipal Affairs Bureau, Temporary Exhibitions Gallery
Teppan
venue.street: Shop 706-707, The Menu @ Level 7, New Town Plaza, Phase 1,
venue.description: If you’re looking for dinner and a show, Teppanyaki is always a nice combination of both. The chef here recommends the grilled A3 Wagyu as your main, but there is also a great seafood selection. If you’re looking for something raw, try the assorted seafood chirashi or salmon sashimi, which has received rave reviews from diners. Meal for two: around $400.

venue.name: Macau Tea Culture House, Lou Lim Leoc
Cafe Vergnano
venue.description: CAFFEINE BREAK This is not your usual coffee shop. The rich dark interiors remind us of a New York Brasserie, and besides waiter service (surprise) and the creamiest cup of cappuccino in town, their afternoon tea sets are excellent value for money. $68 buys you a cuppa, three Italian style finger sandwiches and a rich tiramisu served in an espresso cup. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: Chesa
venue.street: The Peninsula, Salisbury Rd, Tsim Sha Tsui
venue.description: CHEESY GOODNESS Fondue, better known in Hong Kong as "gweilo hotpot," isn't very popular in this town,Â but if you want authenticity, then check out one of the Peninsula Hotelâs more low profile restaurants. Chesa is decked out like a Swiss chalet and still serves up one of the most fragrant and flavourful , not to mention creamy, cheese dips anywhere. Meal for two: around $900.

venue.name: Amigo
venue.street: G/F, 79 Wong Nei Chung Rd, Happy Valley
venue.description: CELEBRATION CENTRAL They may have relaxed the dress code (no tie required)Â but they still do the personalised matchbooks when you make a booking at this institution. The lobster bisque is out of this world and the lamb chops with mint jelly has been consistently good for more than 30 years. Meal for two: around $1,200.

venue.name: Forum
venue.description: BIG SPENDER Thereâs probably too much hype about Yeung Koon-yat, the "abalone king," who has made this restaurant famous around the world. While his abalone is excellent, Forum's other favourites, like crispy skinned fried chicken and rice wrapped in lotus leaves, are lip smacking good and won't leave a huge dent in your wallet. Meal for two: around $1,500. Up to $10,000 if you order abalone.

venue.name: Sushi Qube
venue.street: 41 Wyndham St, and the entrance is located around back. Central.
venue.description: FANTASTICALLY RAW You pretty much have to know someone who knows someone to find this place, tucked away in a back street of Lan Kwai Fong. But those who do find it are rarely disappointed. Let the chef be your guide, and be open to eating everything he places on your sushi block â though do ask for a toro and spring onion roll, which is off the menu. Meal for two: around $2,400.

venue.name: Sportful Garden Restaurant
venue.street: 1/F, Tai Tung Bldg, 8 Fleming Rd, Wan Chai
venue.description: GREAT CANTO Fook Lam Moon it is not, but Sportful Garden serves up a pretty tasty braised abalone and traditional Cantonese fare like steamed spot garoupa, goose web and aÂ fantastic old style chicken in rock salt. What makes it extraÂ yummy is the extra crispy chicken skin is crispy. Meal for two: around $500 (without abalone).

venue.name: Izote
venue.description:
The two man Mariachi band entertained us as we awaited our order. It was a quiet rainy evening, and the chef came out in his whites to belt out songs from his home country. It was like a private concert with the three tenors.

Our meal was similarly serendipitous. The lack of authentic Mexican fare in Hong Kong had made us cynical about dining at Izote. But friends who have lived in Mexico had been raving about this place, so we took one of them along with us to test it out. A complimentary basket of three coloured tortilla chips came out with four dipping sauces: mild, medium, hot and very hot (the latter known colloquially as ‘death’).

Our appetizer of ceviche de pescado (seafood ceviche $135) was filled with octopus, monkfish, shrimp and onion served in a tomato-citrus base. Though satisfactory, we were slightly disappointed to learn the fish was parboiled and not ‘cooked’ by the acid of citrus, as it is done traditionally. But our building disappointment was saved by the chile poblano con queso ($85), a cheesy concoction filled with mushrooms and peppers served in made-to-order warm tortillas like the ones served in southern Mexico.

When they arrived, the chicken burritos ($165) caused a lot of food envy from other diners. The burrito was filled with tender meat, coriander, tomato, cheese and black bean frijoles, which all melted into one big pleasurable eating mess. We made a slight detour and ordered the monkfish pico de gallo ($190) which was plated western style on a stack of chips. Not Tex-Mex, but more a modern invention to charge more money for Mexican food. The fish was meaty, full of bounce to the touch, super fresh and had a slight vinegary tingled from the pico de gallo (fresh chopped tomato, onion, and chiles).

The taste of Mexico and the charming band added up to a night to remember. Izote is a bit pricey considering the type of food it serves, but in a town short of proper handmade tortillas, we were willing to pay the premium for an authentic meal.

Alan Wong

venue.name: Australian Milk Company
venue.description: CHEAP EATS Anyone can cook eggs, but no one does it better than the Australian Dairy Company. The breakfast set ($30) consists of fluffy and moist scrambled eggs served with rich buttery thick toast, and comes with a plate of macaroni along with char siu in chicken broth. This meal is breakfast for many Hongkongers, but it is served around the clock, and the portions are enough to satisfy hungry dinner pangs. There are other popular eggs and milk based dishes on the menu (such as the steamed egg and milk dessert) but the breakfast set is the raison d'etre of this fast paced cha chaan teng. Meal for two: around $60.

venue.name: Ning Bo Residents' Association
venue.street: 4/F, Yip Fung Bldg, D'Aguilar St, Central
venue.description: SHANGHAINESE This hidden dinner-only diner, catering mostly to Zhejiang transplants, serves xiao long baos, glistening abalone, and chewy sweet tong yuen (sticky dessert balls in ginger soup). No English spoken, so bring a Chinese-speaking friend if your Cantonese skills arenât up to scratch. Meal for two: around $440.

venue.name: Ba Sushi
venue.street: Shop 1-5, G/F, King Dao Bldg, 14 Burrows St, Wan Chai
venue.description: For some people, quality sushi is measured by opulent settings and finely-sliced fish flown in from Japan daily. For others, consistency and value matter more. Ba Sushi falls into the latter category. With a wide array of sushi rolls on offer, from a reliable California roll with crab roe to zucchini tempura to soft-shell crab with avocado, and sashimi that never disappoints, this place does the simple things right – and for cheap. One can enjoy a hearty meal of miso soup, a sushi roll, and two pieces of sashimi for about $40. Japanese beers served in chilled metal mugs are a nice touch. Meal for two: around $120.

venue.name: Castro's
venue.description: CUBAN FIESTA Elevated above the busy TST bar strip, sit on high top stools while looking over the bar crowds below. You'll find people from all walks of life at this joint and enough liquor behind the round bar to tempt even the biggest party poopers to stay and enjoy the night with their buddies. Bust out the tequila and cut the cigars â it's a fiesta all day at this old kick back.

venue.name: Temporary Exhibition Gallery of the Civic and Municipal Affairs Bureau
Yu Yu Sushi
venue.description: This is the newest conveyor belt sushi spot to open on the budding restaurant row surrounding J Residence. All the usual suspect sushi and sashimi items are here, but diners can enjoy grilled sushi pieces, âPeking duckâ sushi, and grilled pollock roe stuffed chicken wings. Meal for one: around $100

venue.name: The Coffee Place
venue.description: The owners of The Place have added this little coffee shop to their fledgling empire, right next door to their original premises. Located across the street from The Merton and a stoneâs throw from Manhattan Heights, The Coffee Place dishes out western casual fare such as chicken potpies, ham and cheese toasties, and New York cheesecakes. Meal for two: around $100.

venue.name: Irelandâs Potato
venue.description: The humble chip makes perfect winter comfort food, served with beloved toppings like cheese and sour cream. For the more adventurous, try the cinnamon icing, wasabi mayonnaise or fruit cream. Meal for two: around $80.

venue.name: Toi
venue.description: If youâre tired of sushi, or if teppanyaki just doesnât do it anymore, try the newly opened Toi for some much needed variety on Japanese cuisine. They describe it as âHokkaido rice pizzaâ and, though the authenticity is debatable, scrumptious toppings on a crispy rice base makes for an innovative afternoon snack. Meal for two: around $200.

venue.name: Tofa
venue.description: This newbie right off Gough Streetâs dining row is an instant winner and serves up Chinese cuisine turned on its head. Their Cointreau spareribs are a nice twist on the traditional sweet and sour, and their stormy chicken is deep-fried, garlicky goodness. Meal for two: around $300.

venue.name: Cafe Costa
venue.street: 3/F, Lane Crawford, IFC Mall, 8 Finance St,
venue.description: Inside Lane Crawford IFC is a little-known cafÃ© that serves a casual version of Isolaâs talented Italian menu (they are managed by the same company). CafÃ© Costa delivers mainly lighter fare such as Caesar salads, pastas and a great afternoon tea set. On a sunny day, grab a seat outside on their terrace for an espresso and melted chocolate pudding. Meal for two: $300.

venue.name: Sahara Mezz Bar
venue.description: This shisha bar is filled with folks seeking midweek (or weekend) release in a dimly lit Moroccan setting. The very sharable plates of Moroccan cigars, lamb tagines and super-smooth hummus are all crowd pleasers. Various flavours of shisha are also available: try the apple. Meal for two: around $250.

venue.name: Tree Cafe
venue.description: Itâs smart of the sleek, modern-meets-country home furniture outfitter to open its own little cafÃ© inside Horizon Plaza. Tree now occupies the entire top floor (25,000 sq ft!) and theyâve carved out a nook for hungry furniture shoppers to grab a bite while trying out their furniture. Shepherdâs pie, lasagna, and sandwiches are the order of the day here. Meal for two: around $100.

venue.name: GoGo Cafe
venue.description: Sandwiched between a row of mechanic shops on Caroline Hill Road lives this humble little white box, where the menu is western comfort foods such as salmon-avo pasta salads and crÃšme brulee. They veer off into Asia with only one dish â a very yummy mentaiko with spaghetti main. With such an impressive list of tea concoctions. They have board games as well. Meal for two: around $170.

venue.name: Hunan Garden
venue.description: Though the name might suggest death by spicy Chinese food, this place is Maximsâ pan-China gem. The light and airy colonial atmosphere is pleasant on the eye and the menu features all the favourites from other Maxims joints. Peking duck, sweet and sour pork, beef and scallions, and a wonderful Chinese cabbage served in superior stock are musts for any first-timer. Meal for two: around $400.

Goccia
venue.description: Arrive at the right time and you could snag a couch located in the back of the bar, but once it gets busy, be ready with the excuse meâs. The high-top tables along the wall are so close to the bar that it makes it difficult to move once busy, but the staff wonât hesitate to calm your nerves by pouring a few glasses of wine, champagne or shots. The electro house tunes behind the DJ booth arenât half bad and neither is the crowd, who can be heard carrying on conversations in various romantic languages.

Yat Tung Heen
venue.street: Basement 2, Eaton Hotel, 380 Nathan Rd, Jordan,
venue.description: Itâs that time of year again, when we start to see tied-up crabs lining the shelves of outdoor refrigerators all over town. Yat Tung Heen will be serving these crabby goodies all month long â order the perfectly steamed whole hairy crabs, and a basket of crab âcreamâ pork dumplings. Meal for two: around $600.

venue.name: Spice Market
venue.street: 3/F, Marco Polo Prince Hotel, 23 Canton Rd,
venue.description: This pan-Asian food tour disguised as a buffet is a great starter spot for those unfamiliar with the flavours of Southeast Asia (ie tourists and newcomers). We love it for its massive display of comfy Asian foods, as well as some Western fare to please the out-of-towners. Meal for two: around $700.

venue.name: TSMK
venue.description: This Chinese crystal seller, more known for wedding gifts than for its food, has jumped on the lifestyle bandwagon and opened its first restaurant in the Elements Mall. Though the menu can look a bit fusion-confusion, the food here is unique, mixing Shanghainese, Hunan, and Italian ingredients – and cooking techniques. Try their stuffed pigeon, pork belly braised with a lacquered soy-vinegar marinate or their Taiwanese beef noodle soup made with pan-fried Angel hair pasta. Meal for two: around $500.

venue.street: 27/F, Cheung Kong Center, 2 Queen's Rd Central
