venue.description: This place is expensive, but well worth it. Come for the vegetarian goose, the freshwater shrimp stir-fried with Longjing tea leaves, then come back for hairy crab when itâs season.

venue.name: Xihu Supreme
venue.description: Crispy prawns caked with salted egg yolk, Chinese greens braised in milky fish stock, xiao long bao; these are some of our favourite things.

venue.name: Chinese Legend
venue.street: Shop No. 1, G/F, Sam Shing Market, Sam Shing Estate
venue.description: Buy your seafood from the market nearby in Sam Shing then ask the chefs at the restaurant to prepare it for you however you like. Be sure to order their excellent black bean sauce razor clam.

venue.name: Dragon Inn Seafood Restaurant
venue.description: The âKFC-style baked half lobster and cheeseâ is worth a shot just for the name. The âsnails stewed in spicy wineâ are must-tries too.

venue.name: Hak Ka Hut
venue.street: Shop 3B, 3/F, Phase 1, City Landmark, 68 Chung On St
venue.description: This restaurant has a special $1 âjumbo ginger and scallion chickenâ promotion. But youâve got to order other dishes as well. The âChinese caterpillar fungus dumplingsâ served here are a tonic, and the signature âsteamed pork with salted vegetableâ shouldnât be missed.

venue.name: Heichinrou
venue.street: Shop 208, Level 2, Plaza Hollywood, 3 Lung Poon St
venue.description: This restaurant serves up elaborately prepared dishes like the âgolden crispy tofuâ and âstir-fried prawn with broccoliâ. The service is excellent and if you wait more than 15 minutes for a table you get a 20 per cent discount on your meal.

venue.name: Laguna Chiu Chow Restaurant
venue.description: This private kitchen makes delicious classic chiu chow dishes such as marinated goose, oyster pancakes, and frozen crab.

venue.name: Seafood Island
venue.description: This place specializes in fishing village-style cuisine. The âsea crab steamed with red pepper and egg whiteâ is worth the trip here alone, as is the fried rice with sea urchin.

venue.name: Sportful Garden
venue.street: Shop 312, Nina Tower, 8 Yeung Uk Rd
venue.description: This restaurant specialises in luxury dishes such as sharkâs fin and abalone, but the dim sum is also killer. The âeight treasure ginger pig feetâ is worth trying.

venue.name: Chan Seng Kei
venue.description: This restaurant is most famous for its duck with orange peel. But you need to get there early or call ahead â they only make a limited number of ducks since they take 16 hours to cook.

venue.name: Kira
venue.street: Crown Macau, Avenida de Kwong Tung
venue.description: Excellent cuts of wagyu are grilled to perfection in front of you on hot tables. They also do great seafood seasoned with nothing but sea salt.

venue.name: Splash
venue.street: Four Seasons Macau, Estrada da BaÃ­a de N. Senhora da EsperanÃ§a, S/N
venue.description: Rose by the pool sir? This breezy outdoor cafÃ© serving sandwiches, steaks, and salads is located at the edge of the Four Seasonsâ pool. You can be served inside the dining room or in one of their many semi-private cabanas. Yes, this is the good life.

venue.name: Jaspa's Beach Club
venue.description: If youâve been on too many Jaspaâs junks and want something different, try hiking to the catererâs beach club instead. Itâs a 20-minute stroll from the taxi drop-off point in Sai Kung Country Park to Pak A Village. Here, an old Chinese restaurant has been converted to include all the signatures of the Jaspaâs brand. Expect pizzas, steaks, salads and hearty Aussie fare.

venue.name: Pizza Express
venue.description: The newest outlet of this pizza chain opens on the top floor of Festival Walk. The triple-height ceiling and glass wall facing Lionâs Rock affords stunning views of Kowloon, and their âoutdoorâ seating offers a restful spot to dine on pizza pies.

venue.name: Soho Place
venue.description: This newcomer serves up a Canto-classic menu such as stir-fries, rice and noodle dishes, and classic soups. Nothing too creative, but good homey dishes.

venue.name: Sora ti.te.mo Cafe
venue.street: Shop G189, G/F, Amoy Plaza Phase 2, 77 Ngau Tau Kok Rd
venue.description: This is the newly opened branch of the popular cafe that started out at Megabox. The east-meets-west cafe serves Japanese-interpreted western food such as pastas and soups.

venue.name: Sushi Que-Be
venue.description: This place used to be called Sushi Qube, but with the addition of a letter, the new owners have reinvented the place. Well, sort of. The menu is the same and the dÃ©cor, yup, exactly the way it was before it changed hands. Even the prices are the same: expensive. But Sushi Qube was much loved so diners will be happy to have them back.

venue.name: Bafang Yunji
venue.description: For $26 you can get ten freshly prepared dumplings in baton style, filled with pork and vegetables. The crispy, slightly chewy skin and fresh filling makes this dumpling the most satisfying meal â hence why it's one of the more popular outlets in Food Republic. Take a batch to go; they offer a nifty take out paper box that you can place in a microwave.

venue.name: CafÃ© Deco
venue.description: Taking advantage of the spectacular Peak view, this restaurant gets rave reviews for its steak, seafood, and ethnic fare. The views are absolutely killer on a sunny day or clear night. Bar none to all the restaurants that boast views from the Peak. Great for large gatherings, holiday parties and corporate events.

venue.name: Golden Bauhinia
venue.street: Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre (enter Expo Galleria Entrance)
venue.description: With excellent service and an extensive a-la-carte menu, Golden Bauhinia is a great place to try for your next dim sum brunch. Donât miss the abalone and shrimp rice flour or scallop dumplings.

venue.name: Fan Tang
venue.description: This plushy bijoux restaurant serves modern interpretations of much loved Cantonese favourites. You can taste the TLC in their steamed chicken with rock salt, steamed garoupa, and even the humble sweet and sour pork. They use no MSG and very little oil. Fittingly, everything is served in rather small portions.

venue.name: Fook Yuen Desserts
venue.description: This North Point dive has a queue forming every evening for their glutinous rice ball dumplings. The chewy exterior bursts with sesame or peanut filling. Slurp them with the accompanying soup flavoured with rock sugar and ginger. Also try other treats like red bean soup, steamed milk custard, or tofu fa with mixed fruit. Did we mention it's cheap as chips: $14 for five rice ball dumplings.

venue.name: Peak Lookout
venue.description: Perfect for a group that canât decide what to eat, this place has it all. The extensive menu features Asian favourites, classic Western dishes, a raw bar, open-flame charcoal barbecue and great burgers. The nostalgic ambience is perfect for an intimate meal or leisurely lunch with friends.

venue.name: Pierre
venue.description: Gallic super-chef Pierre Gagnaireâs establishment serves up daring dishes featuring seemingly odd combinations, including popcorn soup, meatballs in beef mousse, and a red pepper dessert. Each course consists of several smaller dishes, offering a unique dining experience.

venue.name: Rose Restaurant
venue.street: Hung Kei Mansion, 5-8 Queen Victoria St
venue.description: If not for their $18 dishes, this place would be another Tsui Wah. We tried their stewed chicken with âthree cupsâ sauce served on a sizzling platter and fish-flavour eggplant stewed in a claypot and couldnât believe all the food that came out for $18 a dish. , Central

venue.name: SiJie Sichuan
venue.description: Youâd never guess that one of the best Sichuanese restaurants exists inside this nondescript office tower. The mother runs the kitchen making some of the spiciest dan dan noodles known to man while the son and daughter run the floor. Expect to get sloppy.

venue.name: Yixin Restaurant
venue.description: This Canto institution has a cheery yellow dining room, and fans come for the soya chicken (the most tender we've tried), pan fried pork patties with mince salted fish, and their excellent selection of seafood. Prices arenât particularly cheap but it's real value for money.

venue.name: Big Wife Noodle
venue.description: The signature Taiwanese beef noodle soup is served in a savoury broth with melt-in-your-mouth beef brisket. The deep-fried chicken gristle is served crispy and seasoned heavily with salt and pepperâa killer accompaniment for a bowl of steaming hot noodles. Free soy drink for each order over $28.

venue.name: Bridal Tea House
venue.description: The cafÃ© inside the Bridal Tea House hotel is probably one of the cheapest east-west meals you can get. $22 buys you brunch on Sundays. Beat that Micky Dâs.

venue.name: Festive China
venue.street: Shop 29, LG1, Festival Walk, 80 Tat Chee Avenue
venue.description: The welcoming staff at the front counter might be dismissive during busy hours, but if you can get past that, you’ll have a wonderful pan-Chinese meal. Beautiful southern-China double-boiled soups, flavourful Peking ducks and well-balanced chilled mock duck spring rolls can be found on the menu. Keep in mind their dubious reservation policy though; they take bookings, but you will still have to wait once you arrive. $600.

venue.name: Inaniwa Udon Nabe Japanese Restaurant
venue.street: Shop 2002, Level 2, Elements, 1 Austin Road West
venue.description: If you’ve been searching high and low for bouncy, chewy yet silky smooth udon in Hong Kong, Inaniwa is the place for you. The Japanese suppliers of the handmade udon are in their seventh generation and their recipe is sworn to secrecy. If udon’s not your thing, the restaurant also offers a Japanese hot pot menu. $400.

venue.name: Itacho Sushi
venue.description: This place specializes in sushi combos, tempura sets, salads, and cold green tea noodles; basically all your Japanese standards in a Zen setting.

venue.name: Mui Kee Cookfood Stall
venue.description: Best for a large group of friends looking for a good time on the cheap. The Chinese twisted cruller stuffed with cuttlefish is a house creation. Also try the fried spareribs with preserved bean curd, its meat wrapped in a crunchy crust. The iced beers are served in kitsch Chinese ceramic bowls â wonderful.

venue.name: Pho Tai
venue.description: When only a big bowl of pho will do hit up this bright and humble shop for a Vietnamese filler. The sets are great value and thereâs a huge variety to choose from, from curries to noodle soups.

venue.name: Qi Ji
venue.description: Crab roe congee is common in this âhood, but often itâs mixed with pumpkin to look like itâs loaded with coral roe. Not here. The fatty roe colours the blank congee and flavours this comfort dish. Large hunks of crabs are cooked with it as well.

venue.name: Spoon
venue.description: Chef and restaurateur Alain Ducasse gives diners the freedom to mix and match food by selecting an entree, its sauce, and accompanying sides. To sample the best of everything, opt for the Sexy Spoon, a special multi-course tasting menu. They also offer wine master classes. Call for booking.
venue.opening_times: InterContinental Hong Kong, Lobby, 18 Salisbury Rd

venue.name: Flying Pan
venue.description: Who else is going to feed you four eggs, four pancakes, four sausage links, and four pieces of toast all on one plate? Itâs packed on the weekend, so come early or late.

venue.name: Hung Fok Seafood Hot Pot Restaurant
venue.description: Choose a variety of swimming sea creatures from their many tanks. Get seated in front of a carbon BBQ and start grilling. Or choose the hot pot option and order extra plates of fatty beef; the pot is steaming with fragrant fish broth. Be careful not to let the live prawn and abalone jump off the plates.

venue.name: Rainbow Seafood
venue.description: If youâre departing from Central, thereâs a free boat ride that will ship hungry passengers to Lamma Island to feast at this outdoor, live seafood restaurant. Steamed catch of the day and black bean clams are the usual suspects, but if theyâre in season, order up the âpee-onâ shrimps and asked for them to be fried with salt and pepper. A fun escape for an evening of island dining.

venue.name: Shanghai Puopuo
venue.street: Shop 3207, 3 Tuen Lung St, Tuen Mun Town Plaza
venue.description: Book in advance to avoid the long queue in front of this place. The spicy greenbean noodle and shredded chicken salad is a mouth-watering appetiser. Follow that with the yellow-fin tuna with pine nuts, and braised pigâs paw.

venue.name: Tai Wing Wa Restaurant
venue.description: Signature noodle dishes of Chinaâs provinces assemble here in this tiny diner. Yunnanâs âcross bridge rice noodleâ, Hunanâs sour and spicy noodle, Sichuanâs âhelly spicyâ noodles, and Lanzhouâs Muslim noodle with beef can be found under one roof. The âbanditiâ grilled chicken wings are especially wonderful.

venue.name: Victoria Oriental SuperStore
venue.description: This tiny spot offers more than 20 different flavoured ice creams from the Philippines. They say the ice cream here has less sugar and contains more fruit chunks. For those looking for something less ordinary, try a scoop of durian, coconut, or avocado flavoured ice creams.

venue.name: Wing Lai Yuen Sze Chuen Noodles Restaurant
venue.description: This place serves simple and humble Sichuan classics: spicy dan dan noodles, mouth-watering steamed chicken with chili sauce and stir-fried tofu in hot sauce to name a few. For dessert, the crispy Chinese deep-fried red bean crepe is recommended. Perfect spot for a late-night dinner.

venue.name: A Petisqueira
venue.description: This outpost offers Portuguese fare with a focus on seafood. All grilled dishes are cooked over a charcoal grill, and donât skip the delectable fresh cheese course. Be sure to wash it all down with Portuguese wine.

venue.name: Mango Tree
venue.street: Shop 2813, The Shoppes at Four Seasons Macao
venue.description: Handcrafted plates and tableware from Northern Thailand villages and impressive flower displays create an exotic setting. Pick from one of the many signature dishes, including grilled free-range chicken in Thai herbs or stir-fried crab in curry sauce.

venue.name: Red 8
venue.street: Wynn Macau, Rua Cidade de Sintra
venue.description: If a 5am bowl of noodles will keep you going on the gambling floor, then this is the power food youâll need to pilgrim on. Northern Chinese roast meats, dumplings, and congee will give you the extra boast need to win back your losings.

venue.name: Intersection of Bowen Road and Bowen Drive
Pak Tam Chung Public Car Park
Jockey Club Creative Arts Centre, Lumenvisum, L2-13 and L3 Gallery
Tseun Wan Town Hall, Cultural Activities Hall
Chinese Antiquities Gallery, Museum of Art
Chameleon Workshop
venue.street: 2B Yan King Court, 119-121 Queen's Rd East

venue.name: Academy of Visual Arts, Hong Kong Baptist University
Exhibition Gallery of Civic and Municipal Affairs Bureau
Mirror Hall, Dom Pedro V Theatre
Hong Kong Arts Centre, Shouson Theatre
10 Chancery Lane Annex
venue.street: 6/F Chai Wan Industrial City Phase 1, 60 Wing Tak Rd

venue.name: The Hong Kong Golf Club, Fanling
Dr. Sun Yat-sen Museum, Exhibition Hall
Luen Wo Hui Sports Centre
venue.street: 3/F, 9 Wo Mun St, Luen Wo Hui

venue.name: Sanshou Training Hall, Lei Yue Mun Sports Centre
Stage One Art Space
venue.street: Unit 26, G/F, Block A, Wah Luen Industrial Building, 15-21 Wong Chuk Yeung St

venue.name: Artist's Commune, Cattle Depot Artist Village
University of Hong Kong, Loke Yew Hall
Hong Kong Arts Centre, Main Entrance
CotaiArena, The Venetian Macau Resort Hotel
University of Hong Kong, T.T.Tsui Gallery
Xlcreation
venue.street: 10B Man Kei Factory, 48-48D, Av. do Coronel Mesquita

venue.name: Macau Cultural Centre
venue.street: Av Xian Xing Hai, s/n, NAPE

venue.name: Hidden Agenda Live House
venue.street: 1A, Choy Lee Industry Building, 46 Chun Yip St

venue.name: Hong Kong Cultural Centre, Piazza Area C
Sheung Wan Civic Centre, HKRep Blackbox Theatre
Artist Commune, Cattle Depot Artist Village
Sheung Wan Civic Centre Lecture Hall
Hong Kong International Trade & Exhibition Centre, Star Hall
Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Jocky Club Auditorium
Avant Garde Art Gallery
venue.street: Rm 1020, 10/F, Horizon Plaza, 2 Lee Wing St

venue.name: Depart from Central or Tsim Sha Tsui
Start at Kowloon Park, finish at Golden Bauhinia Square
Pinto Livros
venue.street: 1A Veng Heng Largo do Senado, no. 1

venue.name: Exhibition Gallery, the Taipa Houses Museum
Museum of Art, Special Exhibition Gallery
9/F The Hong Kong Federation of Youth Groups Building
Lyric Theatre Academy of the Performing Arts
Stanley Ho Sports Centre
venue.street: On Sha Wan Drive, Sandy Bay

venue.name: Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Jockey Club Auditorium
Il Bel Paese
venue.description: This is the little brand that could. Hong Kongâs home-grown Italian deli just opened a branch on Hennessy Road that has a dining room upstairs for lunch and casual dinners. Expect great Italian comfort food such as lasagna and spaghetti and meatballs. The grocery section and prepared-food counter have been expanded.

venue.name: 1st Floor Gallery, Macau Museum of Art
G.O.D. Street Cultura Museum, Jockey Club Creative Arts Centre
Scratch, Jockey Club Creative Arts Centre
Input/Output
venue.street: U/G, Tung Yiu Commercial Building, 31A Wyndham St

venue.name: Too Art, 2/F, Hong Kong Arts Centre
East Kowloon District Residents' Committee Headquarters
venue.street: 5/F, 32-34 Choi Hung Rd, San Po Kong

venue.name: Venue TBC to ticketholders via Facebook or SMS
Random Art Workshop
venue.street: Unit 1203, 12/F, Island Beverley, 1 Great George St

venue.name: The China Club
venue.street: 13/F, The Old Bank of China Building, Bank Street

venue.name: Grand Hall, Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre
Hong Kong Club, Windsor & Edinburgh Rooms
Shek Kip Mei Park Sports Centre
Tuen Mun Town Hall, Cultural Activities Hall
Sushi Shin
venue.description: When three of Kenjoâs apprentices left to start their own restaurant, we got excitedâŠ The young chefs had something to prove, and a legacy to uphold. So they try harder than ever beforeâŠ Okay, the menu is virtually identical to Kenjoâs, including the sashimi and sushi set with palette cleansers in-betweenâŠBut their seared sea scallop wrapped in nori is well worth requestingâŠ A second musty-try item is their chopped toro hand-rollâŠ A word on tradition: if you are seated at the bar, itâs good form to offer a glass of sake to the chefs if you are having some yourself.

venue.name: Bang Bang Pan Pan
venue.description: At Bang Bang Pan Pan itâs OK to play with your foodâŠ Diners choose whatever combination of fillings they likeâŠ You are given bowls filled with your ingredients plus chopped cabbage, onions, and an egg and flour slurry. Mix them together and pour it onto the hot plateâŠ Bang Bang Pan Pan is just plain fun.

venue.name: Bo-LoâGne
venue.description: Hmmm, Japanese baker makes Danish bread. Could it work? Maybe. The deliberating was over when we smelled glorious scents coming from this bakery and we just had to try some. Expect milky soft breads in flavours such as chocolate, strawberry and marmalade.

venue.name: Lan Fong Yuen
venue.description: They say the pantyhose milk tea was invented by this chain. This is their latest outlet to open inside Chungking Mansions. The original is a 50-year-old cha chaan teng in a food stall in Central. This new outlet of course serves the same delicious milky tea theyâve been serving for years.

venue.name: Belgos East Mussels & More
venue.description: The cosy intimate décor of Belgos provides the perfect ambiance for a first date or anniversary dinner. While the original restaurant is located in London, the Hong Kong branch offers the same famous delectable mussels cooked in white wine sauce. The impressive selection of imported Belgian beers alone will make the trip worthwhile. Those with a sweet tooth should not miss out on the authentic Belgian waffles. $400.

venue.name: Cafe Y Taberna
venue.description: A Christian café probably isn’t the first place that comes to mind when you’re craving a Hoegaarden during happy hour, but we’re all about trying something different. Customers need not worry about being preached to though, just enjoy their menu of Thai dishes, grilled meats and pastas, as well as gourmet lattes decorated with milk foam. $300.

venue.name: Xiao Tian Gu
venue.description: This very popular dessert camp has found a new location in the West. Known for its watermelon ice and lychee desserts, this will surely please K-Towners.

venue.name: Brown
venue.description: As the name suggests, thereâs a lot of brown dÃ©cor inside this restaurant bar near the Jockey Club. An upscale version of TGI Fridayâs, itâs worth a visit for the array of decently portioned burgers, pizzas, salads and potato wedges. The buffalo chicken wings, fish and chips and brownie desserts resemble those of an American diner. Thereâs also an all-you-can-drink dinner special from 7.30pm-10.30pm for $420 per person.

venue.name: Jashan
venue.description: Well visited for their lunch buffets, this contemporary Indian restaurant is all about freshness. Try the fish tikka and the mud pot lamb curry. The veggie and lamb samosas are served in generous portions, and their bread basket consists of naan, roti and paratha. Finish off with a sugary gulab jamun (milk balls dipped in rose scented syrup).

venue.name: Mori Hachi Yakiniku
venue.street: 3/F, Ying Kong Mansion, 2-6 Yee Wo St,
venue.description: Order a la carte or try a set menu of agedashi tofu, raw salmon wraps and juicy galbi (Korean-style barbecue beef) at this Japanese grill house. Our favourites include the tender sirloin and ox tongue. It tastes even better when you down it with a glass of Asahi or one of the fruity soju cocktails.

venue.name: Nagomi
venue.description: Donât underestimate the small size of this restaurant (only four tables!) The customers here come back for soft shell crab tempura, which is not overly greasy, and the sashimi rice bowl with a colourful assortment of fish. The large chunks of eel on rice and freshly grilled Hokkaido scallops merit two thumbs up from seafood lovers.

venue.name: Prompt
venue.description: The relaxed garden-view restaurant serves freshly squeezed juices and a variety of Chinese and Western desserts as part of its sumptuous buffet. The seafood selection here is huge â escargots, oysters, lobsters, mussels, sushi, and more.

venue.name: The CafÃ©
venue.street: 2/F, Sheraton Hong Kong Hotel & Towers, 20 Nathan Rd,
venue.description: If you love oysters and shrimp, then this casual and contemporary dining roomâs got a special treat for you. From now until the end of October, the seafood buffet features a variety of shrimp and oyster dishes from the US and Australia. Try the oyster tempura and prawn cakes, or go for the traditional prawn cocktails. A must-try is their highlight dish â freshly cooked live pond prawns seasoned with soy sauce, garlic and chili and steamed in a bamboo basket.

venue.name: CafÃ© on the PARK
venue.street: 2/F, The Royal Pacific Hotel and Towers, 33 Canton Rd,
venue.description: Choose from sushi and eel rice to more inventive dishes like Kyushu wild vegetables, hot pot with soy milk, and wasabi white chocolate mousse. Their green tea and red bean soufflÃ© with sake sound intoxicating.

venue.name: Double Star CafÃ©
venue.description: We recommend their desserts more than their entrÃ©es, but if youâre really hungry, try the rib-eye or chicken spaghetti. The best part comes last: go for a mocha cheesecake or tiramisu to top off your meal.

venue.name: Imperial Kitchen
venue.street: 6/F Telford Plaza I, 33 Wai Yip St,
venue.description: This typical Chinese restaurant setting serves savoury Peking duck and juicy, thin-skinned pork dumplings. The appetiser platters include marinated beef slices and jellyfish. Also worth a try is the mouthwatering lamb with soup noodles and spare ribs in sweet vinegary sauce.

venue.name: Lion Rock Bistro
venue.description: Popular for their breakfasts, the Western-style diner serves banana pancakes with chocolate syrup or breakfast sets of toast, scrambled eggs, smoked salmon and chicken. Their dinner entrÃ©e selection includes baked oysters and lamb chops with veggies on the side.

venue.name: Câest Bon!
venue.street: G/F, Maritime Square, Tsing Yi MTR Station,
venue.description: The portions at this diner draped in see-through purple curtains are fancy but satisfying. The seafood platter consists of a good array of lobster, shrimp, scallops, clams and oysters, and the lobster with angel hair pasta is lightly sauced with tomato. The red wine pear is a pretty sight and the double chocolate cake is sinfully sweet.

venue.name: Fung Lam
venue.description: The great thing about this restaurant is how easy they go on the salt and oil. The crispy roasted chicken and the signature fried soft tofu are delicious, as are the large salt and pepper prawns. Enjoy a free walnut soup with sesame rice balls afterwards.

venue.name: Green Cottage
venue.street: G/F, 15A Yung Shue Wan Main St, Lamma
venue.description: Customers like this down-to-earth restaurant for its mushroom and cheese toast and full-on British-style breakfasts. Worth a try are the colourful, cocktail-esque fruit drinks ranging from blueberry juice to ginger honey with Echinacea.

venue.name: Mighty Vegetarian
venue.street: Shop 36, G/F, Transport Plaza, 2-6 Fung Cheung Rd,
venue.description: This vegetarian eatery serves up tasty wonton soup and other meat-free versions of classic Canto cuisine. Donât be fooled by the crispy texture of the âsweet and sour porkâ â it was never part of a pig. They do use eggs, though, but you can ask them to cook without.

venue.name: La Paloma
venue.street: Pousada Sao Tiago, Avenida da Republica, Fortaleza de Sao Tiago da Barra,
venue.description: get a taste of the Mediterranean with the codfish âBilbainaâ with potato cake or the pan-fried sea bass with fried squid here. Set in the 1641 Barra Fort, one of Macauâs most beautiful landmarks, the restaurant is perfect for intimate dining and overlooks the picturesque harbour.

venue.name: Moonwalker
venue.street: NAPE Lote 13, Avenida Marginal da Baia, Edificio Vista Magnifica Court,
venue.description: This bar/restaurant is located in an area sometimes called âMacau's Lan Kwai Fongâ. Expect solid bar food (read: pork sausages with Tabasco), Italian-influenced dishes, and a decent afternoon tea set â ideal on breezy days out by the waterfront. The place turns into a nightclub after 10pm.

venue.name: Harvest
venue.description: Finally New York-style bagels available in Hong Kong in cinnamon, raisin, onion, and âeverythingâ. You can also get American classics such as burgers and fries, barbecue ribs, and assorted mayo-dressed salads such as chicken Waldorf. The interior resembles a cosy country roadside diner complete with gingham curtains.

venue.name: DG CafÃ© and Wine Cuisine
venue.description: So this is what happens when you cross a major electronic retailer with a kitchen and a wine cellar. A classy white-clothed diner with purchasable MacBooks and iPhones. The menu comprises classic western dishes such as Caesar salads, pastas, and mussels in wine sauce. But there is a bit of Japanese influence with their use of wasabi and tempura. The cellar is quite stellar with labels such as Chateau Pavie, Saint Ãmilion, and Chateau Pichon Longueville Comtesse de Lalande heading the list.

venue.name: Bourbon
venue.description: A slice of Americana has arrived in the space formerly occupied by Wildfire. Two items from Middle America are celebrated here: ribs and bourbon. About 40 kinds of bourbon can be enjoyed with finger-lickinâ smoked ribs and chicken, plus all the grease-lovinâ sides.

venue.name: Hak Tai Hin Taiwan Noodles
venue.description: Beef noodle fans rest easy. This noodle shop serves up bowls of tasty sinewy beef in an aromatic broth with slurpy noodles for the non-beginner.

venue.name: CafÃ© Siam
venue.description: This no-fuss diner is perfect for weekday dinners and casual weekend lunches. Classic Thai dishes such as laab, green/red/yellow curries and chicken wrapped in pandan leaves are favourites on the menu. The spices are adjusted to your palate but if you donât say a word youâll get a comfortable âmildâ.

venue.name: Dressed Salads
venue.street: Shop 1, QRE Plaza, 202 Queenâs Rd East,
venue.description: Dressed gives you a new way to eat veggies. Here, you get a starter bowl of greens to load up with your favourite toppings, meat, dressing and more greens if desired.

venue.name: The Globe
venue.description: If you want some English food, this pub has the Teesside favourite, parmo â a combination of cheese, chicken and bechamel sauce. Also on the menu is a bunch of English classics such as all-day breakfast, potato wedges, a variety of salads and more.

venue.name: Jam Bakery
venue.description: Tai Hang is not short of dessert places but Jam bakery is one of a few that serves western-style desserts. Pick up a jar of cute happy-face cookies, a mango dome cake or the store-made jam. It also offers baking classes.

venue.name: Lee Fa Yuen Korea Garden Restaurant
venue.description: Craving some Korean home-style cooking? Served with a generous amount of ban chans (side dishes), the galbi (marinated beef/pork ribs) and japchae (stir-fried vermicelli) will make you think youâre in the land of kimchi. Highly recommended is the stir-fried seafood with vegetables â a combination of sweet and spicy chilli paste with mussels, sliced octopus and baby shrimp.

venue.name: Tivo
venue.description: Donât let the crowd outside this place fool you into thinking itâs just a bar. Inside, white-plate Italian is served in a loud but atmospheric dining room. It recently launched a selection of gourmet pizzas for those bored with the regular margarita. Give the lobster bisque or wagyu gyuu a try.

venue.name: Tsui Yee Tim
venue.description: This no-frills dim sum eatery is busy all day long, with a constant rotation of hungry folk looking for a cheap, tasty meal (most items are under $20). Try the âbig bunâ filled with sticky-sweet BBQ pork or the chicken feet in black bean. Everything is stacked high in old bamboo baskets. Bring tissues.

venue.name: Yue
venue.street: 1/F, City Garden Hotel, 9 City Garden Road,
venue.description: This Chinese diner has had a facelift. With its high ceilings and 9,000 sq ft of space, Yue can seat 330 and has two private rooms. It offers traditional dim sum and a business lunch set with a wide range of Cantonese dishes by chef Kan Chit Ming, including crispy chicken stuffed with minced shrimp and steamed egg white with crab claw.

venue.name: Fong Wing Kee Hot Pot Restaurant
venue.description: The meatballs and fresh oysters are among the best dishes served here, but itâs the spicy satay soup base that keeps the regulars coming back.

venue.name: Ruthâs Chris
venue.description: Call it an old boysâ club: this steakhouse smells of sizzling steaks, whisky and power. The big, juicy rib-eye is its most popular cut and the mid-western beef is aged and seared at 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit. If youâre hungry, the porterhouse is designed for two but could feed four.

venue.name: Superstar Seafood
venue.description: This chain has been doing well in Hong Kong. Choose from a selection of live seafood and have it prepared as you like it. Be sure to ask the captain what catch came in today, and if youâre unsure how you want it prepared, leave it to the kitchen.

venue.name: China Beach Club
venue.description: This western diner serves great seasonal meals such as roast turkey with all the trimmings during the holiday season. Book early for the special Christmas Day lunch, which tends to fill up months in advance. It has unparalleled views of Mui Wo beach.

venue.name: Sai Sha Seafood Restaurant
venue.description: This little restaurant, near the Water Sports Centre , serves a bit of everything, from barbecue to live shrimps, all while doubling as a pub. But the real draw is the steamed scallops with garlic and the clams with black bean sauce. The terrace seating isnât bad either.

venue.name: Sauce Italian restaurant
venue.description: his family-friendly restaurant has a spot for diners seeking a little fresh air. As the name promises, you get well-sauced pastas. Wines are sold by the glass and live music is played on selected evenings.

venue.name: Shakeyâs Pizza
venue.street: Shop 598, 2/F, Zone C, Tai Po Mega Mall,
venue.description: Sometimes only a slice of pepperoni and cheese will satisfy that craving. Luckily, Shakeyâs now delivers all over the territory. Besides pizza, you can order soups, salads, pastas and onions rings. Not great for the waistline but this is pure comfort food.

venue.name: Fatburger
venue.street: Grand Canal Shoppes, The Venetian Macau, Cotai Strip,
venue.description: There must be a reason why the owners decided Macau should be their first Asian location. The Venetian food court seems like the perfect spot for late-nighters and early-morning gamblers to grab some grease and go. The creaminess of the thousand island dressing hitting the beef patty is the perfect combo.

venue.name: L'Arc Chinese Restaurant
venue.description: This inviting Cantonese diner brings Canto classics to Macau. Large family-style tables suit extended families and the quiet dining room is perfect for business lunches.

venue.name: SPOON by Alain Ducasse
venue.description: This place has always exuded bags of playful charm and easy style, and theyâve made sure they stay fresh and fun with their recent subtle refurbishment. As well as sprucing up the furnishings theyâve also introduced vacuum-seal carafes that look like something from a mad scientistâs lab, and so perfectly reflect the always innovative modern French cuisine. Donât forget to try the new Alain Ducasse Champagne too.

venue.name: King & I
venue.street: 4/F, APM, Millennium City 5, 418 Kwun Tong Rd,
venue.description: This Thai-Vietnamese fusion restaurant sits on the quieter side of a shopping mall. The most interesting dish to try is the baked curry chicken with fresh bread, although it takes 30 minutes to make. The king prawns with durian and mangosteen curry are also worth a try. While their desserts are more Western, there is an authentic basil pancake with Thai ice cream.

venue.name: Bazaar
venue.description: Bazaarâs authentic dishes, low prices, and quirky dÃ©cor make you feel as though youâre truly walking along the streets of Cairo. Their kebab and baklava are reliable staples, though their hummus is the best in town.

venue.name: Goccia Ristorante e Bar
venue.description: Following its new facelift, you can be sure youâll mangiare bene at Goccia. Their tuna tartare with crabmeat and olive puree, and Sardinian sea bass in salt crust, hit the high notes.

venue.name: Green T. House
venue.description: You really wouldnât expect such a starkly white restaurant to have such a colourful menu. Green T. House serves healthy and innovative fusion food that incorporates green tea in one way or another â no complaints there. Enjoy the goose liver terrine with a cup of their fantastic tea.

venue.name: Kaetsu
venue.street: Grand Hyatt Hong Kong, 1 Harbour Rd,
venue.description: If you like good sashimi, Saga beef, and a decent set menu, Kaetsu is the temple for you. Though their menu is slightly pricey, the quality is unbeatable and the atmosphere is pleasantly casual.

venue.name: La Pampa
venue.description: Itâs time to steak out La Pampa this season. Specialising in juicy Argentinean sirloin and tenderloin steaks, which are healthier and leaner than the norm, this restaurant will give the dominant US steak joints a run for their money.

venue.name: Saigon
venue.description: Saigon currently has a âsoft spotâ for soft shell crab, and they want you to share the love. Try their Vietnamese rice paper rolls with soft shell crab and fresh orange, or their succulent soft shell crab and egg curry served in a toasted bread box.

venue.name: Spices
venue.street: The Repulse Bay Hotel, 109 Repulse Bay Rd,
venue.description: Spicesâ Southeast Asian cuisine may not necessarily keep you cool in Hong Kongâs humidity, but thereâs something to be said for imbibing a dose of chillies on a burning hot day. For seafood fans, this is definitely the right spot. Dig into their spicy Alaskan king crab meat and pomelo salad, roasted cod with curry crabmeat sauce, and deep-fried marinated salmon wrapped in pandan leaves.

venue.name: The Tearoom
venue.street: 1/F, Sun Hung Kai Centre, 30 Harbour Rd,
venue.description: The perfect spot for some afternoon time with your best girlfriends, The Tearoom uses exquisite eating utensils that make you feel like a British lady. Their bountiful and vast selection of teatime treats can easily make a meal, and will still leave you with spirits â and stomachs â lighter than air.

venue.name: Vero
venue.description: Six words: so good it should be illegal. One sip of Veroâs sinfully rich hot chocolate is all it takes for anyone to become a chocoholic. From raspberry and mint, to caramel and white hot chocolate and other luscious desserts, Vero pretty much covers everything cocoa.

venue.name: Gaylord Indian Restaurant
venue.description: Pamper your belly royally with Gaylordâs new Mughlai menu, which features cuisine from ancient Indian aristocracy. These dishes are largely butter-based and filled with dried fruits, giving them a unique texture and richness. Their stuffed capsicum, a deep fried green pepper with mashed potatoes, corn, and peas, and their homemade cottage cheese in cashew nut and poppy seed gravy are fit for royalty.

venue.name: Le Gouter Bernardaud
venue.description: Letâs face it, Le Gouter Bernardaudâs Marie Antoinette-esque environment was made for indulgence. Their âopen airâ ambiance is vaguely reminiscent of small sidewalk cafes in Paris â just this variation is in a mall. While their country-styled sandwiches and rainbow macaroons are good, their house foie gras burger is simply to die for.

venue.name: Hang Fa Lau
venue.description: Hang Fa Lau is ideal for those who like to end things on a sweet note. Famous for its traditional Chinese desserts, a trip to this popular eatery will give you the sugar rush youâve been craving.

venue.name: Pho â26
venue.street: Shop 224-225, Phase 2 Eat St, Amoy Garden,
venue.description: Australian WagyuâŠ yum. PhoâŠ Mmmm. So what happens when you mix the two together? You get Pho â26âs specialty, Wagyu pho, a delicious and herb-sprinkled concoction that has proven extremely popular with customers.

venue.name: Rice Paper
venue.street: L1 Festival Walk, 80 Tat Chee Rd,
venue.description: Light and tasty, Rice Paperâs Vietnamese cuisine is as delicate as, well, rice paper. Aside from their sumptuous rice paper rolls, we strongly recommend you try their deep-fried soft shell crab and beef brisket casserole in Massaman curry. Make sure you make reservations before going though; it always attracts a huge and young crowd.

venue.name: Shakeyâs Pizza
venue.description: Stay in shape at Shakeyâs Pizza this season with their new âSlim and Trimâ menu, which lets customers keep track of the number of calories and carbs in every dish. Their pumpkin soup with ginger and poached salmon escalope on organic linguine is chock full of vitamins, helping you finish your summer on a refreshing note.

venue.name: Shang Palace
venue.street: Lower Level 1, Kowloon Shangri-La, 64 Mody Rd,
venue.description: Serving the epitome of fine Cantonese cuisine, Shang Palace will have you begging for more. Crowd pleasers dishes include a lobster fillet sautéed with pear in herb sauce, and sautéed scallop with fresh milk, crab roe and crab meat. The large crowds may be an initial turn-off, but the food is worth the wait.

venue.name: Tokoro
venue.description: Tokoro is the restaurant equivalent of a circus. Work up an appetite watching chefs display their cooking talents while preparing specialties, such as steamed egg custard, red miso soup, and homemade udon noodles with lobster tail in a light soy broth. The food will sit in your tummy nicely, so long as you donât mind spending a little extra cash.

venue.name: Tak Cheong Noodle
venue.street: 8-9 Pak Tai St, To Kwa Wan,
venue.description: Arguably one of the best Chinese noodle places in town, Tak Cheong Noodle will have you wanting oodles more. This traditional cha chaan teng makes fish ball noodles using a secret that makes the dish especially chewy and full of texture.

venue.name: The Gallery
venue.street: 26 Tong Fuk Village, South Lantau Rd,
venue.description: One of the cityâs rare South African restaurants (a surprise considering the popularity of barbecue), this laidback spot is perfect for a lazy summerâs day. Munch on their delectable thin-crust pizzas, or some sizzling, grilled Angus steaks, and wash it down the good âole way â with an ice cold beer.

venue.name: Good Taste Seafood Restaurant
venue.description: This humble little place out in the NT is no hillbilly in the restaurant world. Specialising in seafood, one meal here will have Islanders reconsidering their Sunday lunch plans. Their fried crab with crispy garlic, and steamed crab with yellow wine and egg white are seasonal treats, but their fried shrimp with salted egg yolk is available all year round, thankfully.

venue.name: Hak Ka Hut
venue.street: The Trend Plaza, 1 Tuen Lung St,
venue.description: If youâre willing to experience some provincial Chinese cooking, we advise the Hakka cuisine at Hak Ka Hut. Aside from mouth-watering dishes such as baked chicken with puff pastry, deep fried pigâs intestine, and steamed pork belly with preserved vegetable, this eatery also offers very reasonable prices.

venue.name: iCaramba!
venue.street: G/F, Tower A, Discovery Bay Plaza, 2 Plaza Lane,
venue.description: Get ready to rumble at iCaramba. Their cheery dÃ©cor and friendly service will leave you smiling throughout the night, though that may also be due to their great selection of flavoured margaritas. We highly recommend their queso fundito, burritos, and quesadillas.

venue.name: Taj Mahal Club
venue.description: This small restaurant neatly tucked away in the heart of Sheung Shui serves Indian fare that is colourful and authentic. Mix up some freshly baked naan bread with some thick and spicy curry, and try not to get too addicted to their creamy mango lassi.

venue.name: Wave Bar & Grill
venue.street: Level 3, Hard Rock Hotel, City of Dreams, Estrada do Istmo,
venue.description: Hard Rock hotels have always been notorious for their pool parties, and at Wave bar and grill, this is where people lose their heads â and tops. With oysters from the raw bar or icy cold beers from the tap, this spot is making a splash.

venue.name: CafÃ© Matchbox
venue.description: One of the best lunch deals on Hong Kong Island, diners get a meal for as little as $33 dollars for a set menu. And for $39 you receive a chicken pot pie in pea soup, a stack of banana and walnut hot cakes and a drink. All surrounded by rather kitsch décor. We’re putting this place on our regular rotation. $80.

venue.name: Hot Dog Dot
venue.street: G/F, Paradise Square, 3 Kwong Wa Street
venue.description: This place is the Miami Vice of hot dogs. Painted in corals, aqua blues and sunny yellows they serve dogs with an attitude. They also have mini burgers and massive, fat chips with cheesy, cut-up hot dog on top. $40.

venue.name: Tajimaya Teppanyaki Restaurant
venue.description: Watch their chefs disassemble a Jurassic-sized spiny lobster in front of you on their teppanyaki table. The “roe” or guts are used to flavour rice. Forget the calories, as this is such good place to eat. Sushi, sashimi, udon and tempura are also all available, but it’s the teppanyaki you should stick to. $600.

venue.name: Sushi Shin
venue.street: Shop 1-2, Wing Hing Court, 110-114 Tung Lo Wan Rd,
venue.description: One of the chefs went missing from Kenjoâs and ended up opening his own place in Causeway Bay offering the same great sushi and fun atmosphere. And now that weâre comparing, the same price point as well. Expect to pay around $1,000 per person to have your raw fish cravings properly sated.

venue.name: Hanagushi
venue.description: Though famous for its yakitori (46 different kinds), Hangushiâs food is not quite as authentic as its traditional room setting suggests. Nonetheless, theyâve got decent fresh sushi and silky smooth agedashi tofu. If you go on a day when their special fish soup is served, youâre in luck â itâs milky and uber-fishy deliciousness.

venue.name: Henryâs Kitchen
venue.description: For those who like their foie gras crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside, this is the right place to go. Their grilled New Zealand salmon fillet with herb and grained mustard is lightly salted and fresh. But the freshness doesnât stop there. Try their Caesar salad â its crunchy romaine lettuce and Parmesan slices make it extraordinary.

venue.name: Mackie Kitchen
venue.description: Apart from the a la carte menu, Mackie Kitchen offers set dinners, starting with a soup of the day and a salad: choose from the parma ham in balsamic vinegar or smoked duck breast in sesame dressing. For entrÃ©es, they have a worldly selection of New Zealand lamb, US pork chops or Italian spaghetti. If youâre just going for coffee or tea in the afternoon, the French toast with caramel sauce adds a sweet touch for snack food.

venue.name: World Peace CafÃ©
venue.description: Who says good food has to be flavourful? Relax your taste buds and enjoy a healthy, mild vegetarian tofu and mushroom burger at this western alternative to eating âjaiâ at Wong Tai Sin. Their mango smoothie doesnât scream sweet, but thereâs a mango aftertaste to it. Also take a look at their vegetarian snacks, tea, and Buddhism books for sale.

venue.name: Golden Hall Dessert
venue.description: If youâre up for a more local outing with no English menus, this dessert house has some healthy-looking and colourful pictures of their goodies on the wall, so just point to order what you want. Though theyâve got Malteser truffles, syrup-showered shaved ice, and traditional Chinese desserts, their cutely-shaped assortment of flavoured jellies â peach, grape, green tea, chrysanthemum, rose, strawberry and more â are worth a step in alone.

venue.name: Jaspas
venue.description: This cafÃ© serves up a fusion of western foods. Skip the tenderloin, carbonara and tandoori chicken pizza and jump straight to the banoffee pie, a luscious mixture of tiramisu on the top and sliced bananas plus caramel at the bottom. And if thatâs not sweet enough, dig in on their Malteser cheesecake or chocolate soufflÃ© with a melted chocolate middle.

venue.name: Shang Palace
venue.description: The luxurious feast includes braised sharkâs fin with hairy crab roe and crab meat as well as snow pea sprouts with shredded snake. The dishes are complemented with Chinese yellow wine and followed by hot ginger tea with red bean and lily bulbs. Thereâs also an a la carte menu featuring a variety of hairy crab and snake dishes.

venue.name: Akamaru Noodles Factory
venue.description: With dozens of hot and cold udon to choose from, this Ajisen look-alike accomplishes what all good Japanese noodle shops invoke: a good slurp. Their lightly salted udon are chewy and dense and while their chicken wings and tamagos are frugally portioned, they are just side dishes. Try their skewered chicken and egg on rice if youâre not in the mood for noodles.

venue.name: Crystal Lotus
venue.description: The magic begins as soon as you walk into this crystal-filled, lotus-themed diner with a digitised koi pond gracing the entrance. Try the well-smoked and tender toffee duck breast or the Goldfish in Lotus Pond fish dumplings. Finish off with a sweet and warm double-boiled Chinese pear or a mango-yolk glutinous rice roll. Some items require advance booking.

venue.name: Fung Ying Seen Koon
venue.description: Hong Kongâs largest Taoist temple offers some good vegetarian food in their simple dining room. Try their hot and spicy bean curd or deep-fried taro rolls with rice and congee. They also have set meals for two.

venue.name: Kitoro Japanese Restaurant
venue.description: With plates of sushi, sashimi, raw oysters, and octopus, Kitoro is a paradise for lovers of raw things. But if you prefer your meals cooked, the eel fried rice and ginger pork with veggies resemble your Japanese mumâs home cooking. Be aware of the price range though â their daily special sashimi is more than $200.

venue.name: Lamma Hilton Shum Kee
venue.description: Situated on the waterfront, this outdoor venue offers delicious seafood and siu mei. Taste the powerful wok flavour in the steamed scallops with smashed garlic, the baby lobster in onion sauce, and the roasted chicken. Also worth trying are the clams in black bean sauce, a tasty and satiating version of this common dish. The casual, down-to-earth surroundings are perfect for families and group gatherings.

venue.name: Ming Yuen Seafood Restaurant
venue.description: Sai Kung is well-known for seafood, and this place has got plenty of it. Stir-fried bamboo clams, braised oysters with red wine, and jumbo mantis prawns are some must-tries from their sea of tasty crustaceans. Seafood allergy? You can always opt for their sweet and sour pork and crispy roasted duck.

venue.name: Panda CafÃ©
venue.description: Go global as this contemporary dining room offers an international dining buffet. Choose from a variety of appetizers, desserts, and entrÃ©es, from European scallops to Vietnamese pho. Children eat at reduced prices.

venue.name: Dom Galo
venue.street: Av. Sir Anders Ljungstedt R/C, Edificio Vista Magnifica,
venue.description: Whatâs the secret to their succulent and super tender roast suckling pig? They use sucklings that are around 20 days old and have never been fed on anything but their motherâs milk. A quarter pig starts at MOP100. Their seafood paella, fried cod, and African chicken are also worth a try.

venue.name: PlatÃ£o
venue.description: his cute courtyard has hosted many a romantic meal for visiting couples. The food is casual and so is the service, so donât even think of coming here if youâre in a rush. But then, why wouldnât you want to linger in such a pretty spot?

venue.name: Bistecca
venue.description: This is no ordinary steak house; itâs an âantiqueâ Italian butcher shop that will grill your meat to your liking. The domenico cut is celebrated here in all its glory, along with steaks from Australia and the US. The owners brought in a famous butcher from Florence to consult on the cuts of beef and you can take the steaks home as well.

venue.name: Duetto
venue.street: 2/F Sun Hung Kai Centre, 30 Harbour Rd
venue.description: Viceroy may have closed but the memory lingers. It reopens as Duetto this month, serving the curries we love but with an Italian twist. The stunning outdoor deck with unobstructed views of Victoria Harbour is perfect for weekend meals.

venue.name: Verve Bar and Grill
venue.description: The concept here is Mediterranean meets European meets Asia. The flavours of all three combine on the grill at this new Soho spot, which has taken over the Alfredo diner. Expect Wagyu surf and turf, main course salads and, of course, a mixed grill. Good stuff from the owners of Tequila down the hall.

venue.name: Isola
venue.description: This restaurants needs no introduction. Helmed by Gianni Caprioli, former chef for the Fiat boss in Italy, it takes us through the landscape of Italy, importing only the best the country has to offer. Add stunning harbour views in a gleaming white interior and youâve got magic.

venue.name: Liu Yuan Pavilion
venue.description: Listed in every Hong Kong guide book, this much-loved Shanghainese diner is always filled with tourists, yet locals still brave the crowds to sample its specialties. Try the Shanghai crabs or the smoked eggs. The pan-fried pork buns are juicy, even without all that oil.

venue.name: Perfume River
venue.description: A retro den of linoleum flooring, formica tables and fluorescent lighting, Perfume River passes the litmus test of good cheap eats. This Vietnamese restaurant ladles out bowls of hearty pho. Also worth a try are the garlicky fried chicken wings, the Vietnamese-style curry and the steamed pork and mushroom rolls. Spring rolls are served with a heap of lettuce, mint and basil.

venue.name: Manouche Grill
venue.description: This new-ish Lebanese restaurant does mean grilled beef, chicken and lamb skewers. For something less carnivorous, the hummus with pita is made fresh daily.

venue.name: Scala
venue.street: 11/F, Renaissance Harbour View Hotel, 1 Harbour Rd,
venue.description: This restaurant addresses the areaâs lack of venues for a business lunch or dinner. Located on the 11th floor of a hotel adjacent to the convention centre, the intimate Italian spot is ideal for business meals and romantic outings alike. The dishes are Hong Kongâs take on Italian food but the wine list represents great value.

venue.name: Spoil CafÃ©
venue.description: RICH PICKINGS Get ready to be spoiled in small but tasty portions. Try the larger plates of linguine with clams or the wild mushroom risotto if you are hungry. More popular is the rich chocolate cake. The wine selection is limited and a $100 corkage fee applies.

venue.name: Sun King Kee Noodles Shop
venue.description: This family-owned eatery near the mouth of the Central wet market is renowned for its fish-slice noodle soup. Add fish balls, rich beef brisket or crispy fish skins and the simple broth turns into a tasty meal. The pungent Chiu Chow chilli sauce is so good, customers used to smuggle it out in their handbags until the owners got savvy and started selling it at $40 a jar.

venue.name: The Chippy
venue.description: Itâs getting hot in this basement. Try the hand-cut chips smothered in onion gravy â one order wonât be enough. And thereâs more than fish and chips; this snack shack also serves scrumptious burgers and a complete traditional English breakfast. Worried about your arteries? The gymâs just down the road.

venue.name: Dai Kee
venue.description: This looks like a typical cha chaan teng, only cleaner. Here, the Leung family serves its iconic dish â Zhongshan-style rice vermicelli. The chewier-than-average noodles are ground then stretched in the familyâs factory. Also worth a try are the sweet puddings.

venue.name: Miu Fat Chai
venue.description: The squid here looks and tastes like the real thing and the same goes for the âbeefâ on a stick. Meat lovers wonât feel like theyâre missing a thing.

venue.name: Niji Bistro
venue.description: apanese-style omurice (fried rice wrapped in an omelette) and Japanese-style Italian pastas are popular at this casual restaurant. Also try the salads with seven dressing options and finish off with a whipped cream coffee or a smooth chocolate mousse.

venue.name: Nomads
venue.description: Eat to your heartâs content at this Mongolian-style buffet, where the chef cooks the ingredients you choose. Make your own entrees and pizzas with a fresh selection of meats, veggies and sauces. The wool-covered chairs and bow and arrow decorations give a casual, almost wild, ambience.

venue.name: Stick Stickâs
venue.street: Near exit A, Kowloon Bay MTR,
venue.description: Originating from Tokyo, the waffles here are crunchy little delights. Choose from 12 fillings, including mango-chocolate, strawberry-blueberry and green tea.

venue.name: Buddha Hut
venue.street: 245 Amoy Plaza Phase 2, 77 Ngau Tau Kok Rd,
venue.description: This fast-food restaurant is a vegetarian version of CafÃ© de Coral. Try the chewy âchar siu fanâ and mushroom rolls or go for the colourful assortment of cakes. The mixture of light brown and creamy walls creates a comfortable, relaxed ambience.

venue.name: Island CafÃ©
venue.description: This is Disco Bayâs only pan-Asian cheap ânâ cheerful eatery. Expect crowd-pleasers such as Chinese, BBQ, Thai, Malay and Indonesian dishes plus cha chaan teng beverages and budget-conscious set menus. The green curry pork neck rivals any on the island.

venue.name: Golden City Seafood Restaurant
venue.street: Shop 3015, Sunshine City Plaza Phase 4, 18 On Luk St,Ma On Shan
venue.description: To promote the SARâs Eat Smart campaign, the chefs here make everything simple and healthy. Try the meat platter and siu meis. A big thumbs-up goes to the tasty roast duck.

venue.name: Pousada
venue.description: The porco a Alentejana, or pork tenderloin with clams, and the whole suckling pig are mouth-watering creations. The atmosphere is romantic and the balcony overlooks Pak Sha Wan.

venue.name: Shanghai Kitchen
venue.description: If the queues are always out the door, it must be good. This King Parrot group establishment looks like a brighter version of Dragon-i in a mall. The list of must-tries is extensive, from hot and sour noodle soup to spare ribs with rosa vinaigrette. Shanghaiâs renowned steamed pork dumplings are not to be missed either.

venue.name: Afrikana BBQ Restaurant and Lounge
venue.description: Located at Fishermanâs Wharf, this African diner is like a theme park and goes way beyond the usual Macanese/Chinese food spectrum. Give the grilled whole lamb a go or try the buffet so you can sample what African cuisine has to offer. Chinese dishes are available.

venue.name: Galo
venue.description: This two-storey house in Taipa village makes for a romantic dining experience. Itâs informal and the galo, or âroosterâ in Portuguese, features heavily in the decor. The menu includes a mixture of Shanghainese and Portuguese dishes such as Macau crab.

venue.name: Baptist University, Lam Woo International Conference Centre
Madame Tussauds Hong Kong
venue.street: Shop P101, The Peak Tower, No. 128 Peak Road

venue.name: Canadian International School of Hong Kong
Shop Nos. B46-B48 in 1st Basement, Site 11
Meet at Pacific Coffee Company, Shop 1022, IFC Mall, 8 Finance St, Central
March starts at Southorn Playground (Wan Chai, MTR exit B)
Thai & Grill Restaurant
venue.street: Grand Hyatt Hong Kong, 1 Harbour Rd,
venue.description: The Bangkok-born restaurant boasts subtly complex Thai dishes such as chicken coconut soup, prawn red curry, Thai fried noodles, and mango sticky rice, to name just a few. Sounds like game time to us.

venue.name: University Museum and Art Gallery, HKU
The Vine Centre
venue.street: 2/F, Two Chinachem Plaza, 135 Des Vouex Rd, Central

venue.name: Stanley Ho Space Theatre, Space Museum
Lower Cheung Sha Beach, Lantau or Cheung Chau Island (wind-forecast pending)
Sino Groupâs âArt in Hong Kongâ
HKICC Lee Shau Kee School of Creavity
Island Shangri La Hotel, 39/F, Atrium I & II
Hall 5GF, Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center
Hall 1, Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre
Thematic Gallery 1&2, Hong Kong Heritage Museum
Chao Shao-an Gallery & Thematic Gallery 4,Hong Kong Heritage Museum
Red Square Gallery
venue.street: Shop G107B, The Repulse Bay Shopping Arcade, 109 Repulse Bay Road

venue.name: Thematic Exhibition Gallery, Hong Kong Heritage Discovery Centre
CUBIC Macau
venue.street: 2/F AIA Tower, Nos 221A-301 Av Comercial de Macau

venue.name: Dymocks
venue.street: Shop 104b, 1/F Block A, Discovery Bay Plaza

venue.name: Sham Shui Po Sports Ground
venue.street: Hing Wah Street & Cheung Sha Wan Rd

venue.name: The University Museum and Art Gallery
SiLouGongChang
venue.street: Flat B, 4/F, Lee Ka Industrial Bldg, 8 Ng Fong St

venue.name: Fung Ping Shan Art Gallery, HKU
HKCO Rehearsal Hall, 7/F, Sheung Wan Municipal Services Bldg
ToTTâs
venue.description: Sunday brunches are about endless trays of good eats and free-flowing Champagne refills. Pair that with one of the best views in Hong Kong, and you’ve got a winning combination. Enjoy their freshly shucked oysters and caviar, sushi and sashimi, foie gras station, cheese station, desserts and free-flowing Mumm Champagne. $900.

venue.name: Mitake Yakiniku
venue.street: G/F, Kam Shing Mansion, Stage 10, Taikoo Shing
venue.description: This Japanese grill restaurant offers a selection of 40 plus meat, seafood and veggie selections all seared in front of you (in a smoke-free environment). For a less expensive meal, itâs worth trying their specially priced lunch set menu. $350.

venue.name: Nepal
venue.description: This bustling Soho restaurant is a godsend for vegetarians, with the spiced eggplant dish proving a firm favourite. Thereâs something for meat lovers too â in fact a hefty portion of lamb stew in almond gravy might even be enough to turn some of those veggies to the dark side. $500.

venue.name: Grissini
venue.description: The panoramic view of the harbour definitely makes Grissini worth a visit, but what really seems to keep customers coming back are their long warm bread sticks served with olive oil and balsamic vinegar. $1,200.

venue.name: West Kowloon Waterfront Promenade & Cultural Centre Piazza
The Grand Hyatt Hotel Hong Kong
XL Creations
venue.street: 10/F B, Man Kei Industrial Building, 48-48D Av Coronel Mesquita

venue.name: Compass Room, Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club
The City University of Hong Kong
Australian Chamber of Commerce Seminar Room
East & West Room, Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong
Lecture Theatre 16, The City University of Hong Kong
Rayson Huang Theatre, University of Hong Kong
C.K.Tse Room, Chung Chi College Library, Chinese University of Hong Kong
Chung Chi College Library, Chinese University of Hong Kong
Lady Shaw Hall, LT1, Chinese University of Hong Kong
Wei Hing Theatre, The City University of Hong Kong
Man Wah Restaurant, Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong
Hong Kong City Hall, Recital Hall
Convocation Room, University of Hong Kong
Metro Books, Commerical Press and Parentheses
Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts
Lobby of Hong Kong Arts Centre
University Museum and Art Gallery Hong Kong
Cubic
venue.street: 2/F AIA Tower, 251A-301 Av Comercial de Macau

venue.name: JWT Kids Gym
venue.street: Tseung Kwan O Center, Shop 202, Park Central, 9 Tong Tak Street

venue.name: Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware (1/F)
venue.street: Cotton Tree Drive (Inside Hong Kong Park)

venue.name: G/F, Macau Cultural Centre
venue.street: Av Xian Xing Hai, s/n, NAPE

venue.name: Albergue Gallery
venue.street: 8 CalÃ§ada da Igreja de S. LÃ¡zaro

venue.name: In front of the ZAiA Theatre, The Venetian Macau Resort Hotel
Cotai Arena, The Venetian Macau Resort Hotel
Multimedia Theatre, HKICC Lee Shau Kee School of Creativity
HKICC, Lee Shau Kee School of Creativity
Mischmasch Gallery
venue.street: Unit A, 18/F Shing Hing Commercial Bldg, 21-27 Wing Kut St

venue.name: MobArt @ ÄpÃ¶ch Coffee Bar and Desserterie
Thai Lemongrass
venue.description: Thai Lemongrass offers a range of regional specialties, the fried soft-shelled crab with garlic and chilli are delicious and the Pad Thaiâs not bad either. A great spot for a quick lunch. $250.

venue.name: Va Bene
venue.description: A genuine Lan Kwai Fong institution â the huge portions and fresh ingredients keep the regulars coming back (as does the delicious chocolate mousse). Other recommendations are the pasta pockets with meat ragout and the beef carpaccio. $900.

venue.name: Ah Yat Harbour View Restaurant
venue.description: This newcomer to iSquare shares the same amazing city views as the other top floor restaurants in the lot. The menu is filled with delectable dishes from the Guangdong region. Savoury buns, vegetarian duck, and dim sum items are served with the great Batman view. $1,000.

venue.name: Only Buonasera
venue.description: As a Southern Italian eatery the food is much lighter here than at its North Italian counterparts. Seafood takes centre stage and is best experienced by ordering the mixed Adriatic appetiser. $600.

venue.name: Unkai
venue.description: This is the spot to come to for traditional Osaka cuisine. Order the Wagyu beef shabu shabu and wash it down with a glass of sake - the choice of Japanese wines is plentiful. $1,800.

venue.name: Whisk
venue.description: Whisk is all about fine dining. The trendy monochromatic interior and international gastro fare have upped this joints credentials despite the fact that it hasnât been open for long. Justin Quek of Singapore culinary fame is behind the menu. Word on the grapevine says the flaky apple tart is especially good. $2,000.

venue.name: Avanti
venue.street: G/F, Regal Riverside Hotel, 34-36 Tai Chung Kiu Road
venue.description: The laidback setting and live music make this an easy place to while away the hours. The menu is well edited and features a selection of pizzas, pastas and other Italian fare. The pan fried lamb chop with anchovy sauce is very good. $600.

venue.name: Steamers Bar
venue.description: Steamers is a favourite amongst locals for its hearty full English and equally good Sunday roast. Both dishes sell out quickly, so be sure to arrive nice and early, grab a table in the courtyard and soak up some rays. $200.

venue.name: Tung Kee
venue.description: This Chinese seafood restaurant is located right on the pier, so it worth grabbing a table on the patio in order to make the most of the harbour views. Although itâs often packed, Tung Kee is a good place for parties, as they offer set meals for groups of two to twelve. $550.

venue.name: 3 Monkeys
venue.street: The Venetian, Estrada da Baia de N. Senhora da Esperanca, The Cotai Strip, Taipa
venue.description: This is one for the kids. Step inside the jungle themed restaurants and pick and choose from the extensive range of cuisines: Mexican, Italian, American and Asian are just a few of the international treats in store. Plus there are a range of halal and vegetarian items on the menu too. MOP450.

venue.name: The Kitchen
venue.description: Whilst steak is certainly the main attraction here, the salad and sashimi bars deserve an honourable mention too. The informal vibe is heightened by dinersâ proximity to the chef who works in an open kitchen and will advise you on the best way to cook your meal. MOP500.

venue.name: CafÃ© Zen
venue.street: Futian Shangri-La, 4088 Yi Tian Road, Futian District
venue.description: A family who eats together stays together. At CafÃ© Zen, enjoy their âbuy three, get one freeâ promotion. Enjoy a buffet of sashimi and other delights with free-flow draught beer. RMB800.

venue.name: The Penthouse
venue.street: Grand Hyatt Shenzhen, 1881 Baoan Nan Road, Luohu District
venue.description: The top floor of the Grand Hyatt houses a 109-seat venue offering teppan hot plates, a illuminated bar and a charcuterie. They also have a large single malt selection. RMB500.

venue.name: Coast
venue.description: This Australian-themed restaurant is relaxed and sophisticated with a touch of Zen thrown in too. The place has been designed with sustainability in mind using recyclable wood and other green materials. The menu offers a diverse range of Aussie-inspired selections with an equally impressive Australian wine list. $900.

venue.name: Hong Kong Lao Shang Hai Restaurant
venue.street: UG1, Novotel Hong Kong Century, 238 Jaffe Road
venue.description: This old-style restaurant is consistently popular with Hongkongers. The Shanghainese soup dumplings are the perfect balance of skin and filling. A good place for lunch with colleagues as well as for big dinners with friends and family. $300.

venue.name: Island Seafood & Oyster Bar
venue.description: Situated on what is affectionately known as Food Street in Causeway Bay, this little outdoor cafÃ© offers some of the freshest seafood and most succulent steaks. The staff are also unerringly friendly and helpful when it comes to recommendations. $1,000.

venue.name: Katong Laksa Prawn Mee
venue.description: This restaurant is tiny, but the smiling man at the door is always happy to find a spot for you to squeeze into. The menu offers an array of noodles and side dishes that are well seasoned, making the flavours linger on your palate. The simple noodles and drink set is great for when you need to grab lunch. $100.

venue.name: Prawn Noodle Shop
venue.street: Shop 201, 2/F, Grand Millennium Plaza, 181 Queen's Road Central
venue.description: The laksa is a savoury treat thatâs a portion to keep you content for the rest of the afternoon. The service is fast and efficient, but not hostile, and the row of window seats allow for people-watching while you eat. $100.

venue.name: La Taverna
venue.description: Tucked way back on Ashley Road, this restaurant evokes a proper Italian atmosphere that is a good accompaniment to an authentic meal. The set dinner menu offers a wide selection with each course well prepared. $600.

venue.name: Olive Greek & Middle Eastern
venue.street: Shop R008, Elements Mall, 1 Austin Road West
venue.description: The neutral tones of the dÃ©cor makes this a perfect place for casual chatter with a friend over a selection of Greek and Middle Eastern dishes that are generous in portion and spices. $700.

venue.name: New Kotobuki Japanese Restaurant
venue.description: The food here stands out, but the location certainly doesn’t. The head chef is in a class of his own, and has been cooking in Hong Kong for the past 30 years. The food is always fresh and as authentically Japanese as you’ll get anywhere, and if you give them free rein with your cooked dishes, you’re unlikely to be disappointed. $250.

venue.name: Tai Ping Koon Restaurant
venue.description: A favourite among the locals, the food here is consistent and plentiful. Their signature dishes are the roasted young pigeon, TPK dry fried rice noodles with beef and Swiss sauce chickens wings. Even if that’s all you ever order when you’re here, you’ll still leave happy every time. $350.

venue.name: Chung Shing Thai Restaurant
venue.street: G/F, 69 Tai Mei Tuk Village, Ting Kok Road
venue.description: This Thai restaurant may be out of the way for many, but the food is well worth the trip. Their crepes go perfectly with the assorted curries, and the tom yum goong soup is spicy and full of enticingly aromatic ingredients. Even though the seating may be a little cramped, the friendly neighbourhood feel and outdoor tables make up for it. $200.

venue.name: Le Bristol
venue.street: Shop R5, G/F, Marina Magic Shopping Mall, Gold Coast
venue.description: This cosy French restaurant at the Gold Coast has a decent set menu, and an enviable waterfront location. Go casual with a sandwich or plump for their roasted chicken and pastas. $600.

venue.name: Lucky Cafe
venue.description: There’s nothing fancy about this place, but the food is good and the service is fast. Don’t be fooled by how little it looks from the outside though; there’s a whole other floor upstairs that testifies to how popular this cha chaan teng is. Particularly good are the Singaporean fried rice noodles and the signature red bean ice. $60.

venue.name: Pokka Cafe Grill Specialist
venue.street: Shop 115, 1/F, New Town Plaza Phase 1, 18 Sha Tin Centre Street
venue.description: A cute little fusion restaurant that offers a blend of Japanese and Italian cuisine, their combinations may make you wonder if they’re a little nuts, but rarely are dishes actually bad. Their pastas are consistently good and their coffee is strong and aromatic. Save enough room for dessert. $350.

venue.name: Praia Grande
venue.street: G/F, 10A Praca Lobo D'Avila, Avenida Praia Grande
venue.description: With its wrought-iron windows and arched doorway, Praia Grande brings a bit of old Lisbon to Macau. For hungry diners, give the Portuguese clams a go or the “rich paella” filled with prawns, squid and fish is always an excellent and satisfying choice. MOP1,200.

venue.name: Temptations
venue.description: Start with the raw bar, then go for a little African chicken then keep working your way down the buffet line. Stuffed is an understatement. MOP800.

venue.name: The Exchange
venue.street: Sheraton Shenzhen Futian Hotel, Great China International Exchange Square, Fuhua Road, Futian
venue.description: Every Saturday, Mumm’s champagne is free-flowing and there is a lavish Chinese and European buffet to feed everyone from toddler (children under five eat for free) to grandma. There’s also a children’s play room so parents can enjoy the food in peace. RMB800.

venue.name: Papa John's Pizza
venue.description: Like any good franchise business, this popular US pizza chain thrives on consistency, and their Shenzhen outpost serves up pepperoni pizza that tastes pretty much the same as if you had it in suburban America. Also worth sampling is their spicy chicken wings and garlic bread sticks. RMB200

venue.name: D17 Seafood Bar & Grill
venue.description: Designed for luxury as well as comfort, D17 Seafood Bar & Grill calls to mind the feel of a luxurious yet comfortable apartment. Their cuisine is continental fare with a good dash of Japanese influence, and a must try is their foie gras bon bon: 72 per cent cocoa with a bit of foie gras, 100 per cent delish. $450.

venue.name: DAP JP.Wine.Dine
venue.description: They deliver imaginative creations designed to evoke the perfect blend between Japanese and European foods. The soupy chicken consommé heaped with chunks of crabmeat dumpling, and the tofu with marbled prime rib-eye steak with pumpkin tempura are among their signature dishes. $900.

venue.name: EXP
venue.street: Shop 23, UG, Festival Walk, 80 Tat Chee Avenue
venue.description: Taking the best elements from Japanese, Italian, French, Thai and Chinese cuisine, EXP dishes take a little inspiration from each culture and fuses them together into one tantalising dish after another. Their noodles and pizza collections are particularly inventive and definitely worth a try. $200.

venue.name: Fusion Gourmet
venue.description: A comfortable restaurant with a slight wine cellar feel to it, diners sit at a long table in the middle surrounded by wine and produce that they can choose from to put together their fusion meal. Try the whole seabass served on tomato relish, but leave room for at least one of their unbelievably tempting desserts. $600.

venue.name: Lotus Restaurant and Cocktail Lounge
venue.description: This cosy lounge slash restaurant marries the fragrant herbs and spices of Thailand with the smooth and savoury flavours of Australian seafood and meats. Signature dishes include their Massaman curry of lamb shank with roasted peanuts, tamarind and shallot potatoes. $500.

venue.name: San San Trois
venue.description: The presentation of the food may look very Japanese, but look closer and you’ll notice that what looks like spaghetti in truffle sauce is really udon, and what appears to be your average sushi is actually their signature foie gras sushi that has yet to disappoint. $500.

venue.name: Ginza Bairin
venue.description: The rosu katsu don is a gourmet version of the omnipresent deep-fried black pork fillet with pan-fried egg on rice with ‘secret sauce’… The sweet soya base is aromatic and the soft egg cooked just right. However, the pork falls short of expectations; instead of a melt-in-your-mouth tenderness, it’s a bit on the dry side... For reasonable prices in a relatively upscale mall in Tsim Sha Tsui, it’s a good choice, though it will not rock diehard connoisseurs. Meal for two: $400.

venue.name: Mist?
venue.description: Nothing is more rewarding for foodies than when a chef is obsessed with a dish… There are only five or so items to choose from here and five different stocks, including soya, shio (salt), ume (plum) shio, miso and karemiso (spicy miso)… There are different grades of noodles, ranging from thin to thick, like Italian pasta… The karemiso base is similar, this time with the addition of miso and Japanese chilli. Sweet, with a slightly spicy edge. Meal for two: around $400.

venue.name: Ambrosia Oyster & Grill
venue.description: This is one of the many restaurants to open in fresh-out-of-the-wrapper iSquare. Here, clams and oysters on the half-shell are displayed on a mini-mountain of shaved ice, seared foie gras and great chops. If you have vertigo, ask for a table towards the centre of the dining room, otherwise you’ll be teetering at the edge of Kowloon. $1,000.

venue.name: Brother and Sister
venue.street: Basement, Emperor Jewellery, Shop B-02, 1881 Heritage, 2A Canton Road
venue.description: Gilbert Yeung is at it again, this time with sister Cindy. Located in the basement of the Emperor Jewellery boutique (owned by Cindy), this café is perfect for shoppers who want a quick bite in between shopping sprees. There’s also a stacked bar if you feel a martini is conducive to buying diamonds. $600.

venue.name: Feast
venue.description: Inside the shiny new East Hotel lives a long buffet table serving the best of Asian and Western cuisines. Thin-crust pizzas and tasty pastas can be found on their a la carte menu. Note this is East Hotel’s all-day dining venue and much of the menu is dedicated to delivering something for everyone. $600.

venue.name: Golden Flower
venue.street: Wynn Macau, Rua Cidade de Sintra, NAPE
venue.description: Wynn Macau has launched Golden Flower after a two-year search for mainland China’s best chefs and a multimillion dollar renovation. Master Liu and his seven culinary protégés present authentic Tan cuisine from the Qing dynasty in this opulent dining room. MOP1,000.

venue.name: Rock Salt
venue.description: Stanley might be filled with themed restaurants, but none quite so dedicated to fresh seafood with fabulous views to boot. Signature dishes include salmon and kingfish tian, king prawn capellini and the signature blue-eye cod. And as the name hints, a choice of three rock salts is available at every table. $650.

venue.name: Ã la umai
venue.description: Situated on the top floor of a dubious-looking commercial building in Tin Hau, you’d never think that à la umai has one of the best harbour views in the city. Luckily, the food is just as impressive, with a menu that spans fresh seafood and sashimi to 360-day grain-fed Australian steak. $700.

venue.name: Habibi
venue.street: 1/F, Grand Progress Building, 15-16 Lan Kwai Fong
venue.description: They’ve moved from their Wellington Street location to their new spot in Lan Kwai Fong recently and took first-floor space above Tuscany by H. The menu features shareable Middle Eastern fare, and if you are small party, do share the hot and cold mezze. $300.

venue.name: Habibi CafÃ©
venue.description: Black and white Egyptian movies play on little television screens in this Middle-Eastern themed diner. Lots of Kosher items are on the menu from hummus to tabbouleh. Be sure to have a cup of their fresh mint tea. $150.

venue.name: Gitone Fine Arts Limited
venue.street: G/F, Shop GB 27-28, Lei King Wan, 45 Tai Hong Street
venue.description: Every evening, this art and ceramics gallery is transformed into a Shanghainese private kitchen. The meal includes eight appetisers and eight main dishes, making up a long night of tasting adventure. Diners have the option of signing up for pre-dinner ceramics and painting workshops. Reservations are absolutely necessary, and a minimum party of four is required. $400 each.

venue.name: Peking Restaurant
