venue.description: Experience authentic Beijing cuisine at affordable prices, where the Peking duck is always a hit with the diners. Bear in mind that low prices usually come with sub par service, but the good food should be able to help you to forget all about that. $250.

venue.name: Robatayaki
venue.street: G/F, Two Harbourfront, 22 Tak Fung Street
venue.description: The Japanese barbecue menu at Robatayaki features a good selection of surf and turf, as well as veggies. Sushi, sashimi and sake are also available to accompany the grilled dishes. They also offer a ‘Sumo’s Choice Lunch’ on weekends at a fraction of the cost for dinner. $1,000.

venue.name: Plantain Leaf Delights House
venue.street: Shop 20D-E Tsang Fook Garden, Yeung Siu Hang Village
venue.description: Locals love to congregate here for their fix of Thai pineapple fried rice, tom yum goong and curry. The restaurant also features an outdoor dining area, great for the warmer months. $180.

venue.name: Vi
venue.street: G/F, Regal Riverside Hotel, 34-36 Tai Chung Kiu Road
venue.description: Vi, which means taste in Vietnamese, incorporates both Thai and Vietnamese delicacies on the menu such as pumpkin seafood soup, red curry seafood and prawn crackers. Snag a table with a riverside view on a sunny day for an optimum meal with a view. $400.

venue.name: Copa Steakhouse
venue.street: 3/F, Sands Macao, 203 Largo de Monte Carlo
venue.description: The open kitchen provides diners with pre-dinner entertainment as they watch the chefs prepare their juicy, tender steaks. Warm, earthy hues and soft lighting make you forget all about the bustle of the gambling floors below. MOP900.

venue.name: Restaurante Birmanes Nga Heong
venue.street: G/F, 27F Rua De Fernao Mendes Pinto R/C, San Kiu
venue.description: If you’re tired of the same old Macanese-Portuguese fare, head to Rotunda de Carlos da Maia for some cheap and cheerful Burmese comfort food. This local favourite does great Burmese fish noodles and creamy chicken curry. Wash it all down with their homemade black soy milk. MOP100.

venue.name: Cabin BBQ
venue.street: Honey Lake Holiday Village Amusement City, Futian District
venue.description: Famous for being co-founded by President Obama’s half-brother, Mark Ndesandjo, Cabin BBQ is not for those who have been spoilt by air conditioning as it’s down-home, smoky, outdoor dining here. Cabin BBQ is all about eating lots of meat on sticks and downing excessive amounts of beer. RMB120.

venue.name: Barolo
venue.description: Hong Kong's Little Italy on Wyndham Street stretches onto Hollywood Road with the opening of Barolo. This cosy spot under the escalator is a mid-price alternative to the more upmarket eateries up the block. Northern Italian cuisine is shown off in Barolo's pesto, warm octopus salads, fish tartar, and grilled steaks with balsamic. $600.

venue.name: The Chinese Restaurant
venue.street: Hyatt Regency Hong Kong, 3/F, 18 Hanoi Road
venue.description: The setting is a 1920s tea house, with updated plush interiors, serving the best of Cantonese and regional Chinese cuisines. They have one of the best dim sum deals in the city, where $198 buys an all-you-can-eat lunch with six courses and over 20 dishes to choose from. $800.

venue.name: JoJo's Kebab
venue.description: Hollywood Road now has a late-night kebab joint to absorb all that alcohol. This spot serves chunky flame-grilled meats with all the hot sauce one can take in a sandwich, until 4am. $100.

venue.name: Woo Tung Yakiniku
venue.description: We're sad tp see Dinging Wok go, but in its place is a new yakiniku joint that is making the neighbourhood smell really good. Sure the thinly sliced pork belly and short rib sitting in marinade looks more like Korean barbecue to us, but no one's complaining. $500.

venue.name: CinecittÃ
venue.description: Named after the storied Rome studio, this romantically lit restaurant makes the most of the theme with a big screen showing Italian films. Serving modern Roman specialties and traditional Italian fare, Cinecittà also features a striking glass-walled wine cellar and centerpiece bar. $1,000.

venue.name: The French Window
venue.street: Shop 3101, 3/F, Tower 2, IFC Mall, 8 Finance Street
venue.description: Take pleasure in the stunning views of the harbour from inside an equally stunning restaurant. You can order their finest French dishes served with a modern twist either a la carte or as part of a set menu. Of course, such a first-rate meal would not be complete without near-perfect wine pairings. $2000

venue.name: La Baita
venue.description: Trattoria by day, proper Italian fine dining by night, this new kid on Queen's Road East serves up creamy polenta, tuna tartar, seafood soup, pizzas and sautéed pork cheek. $1,000.

venue.name: Xen Coffee
venue.street: Basement K-12, Manly Plaza, 995-997 King's Road
venue.description: This shop employs the halogen-powered siphon method to prepare coffee which is always in use because of its slow drip - every cup takes about five minutes to prepare. Not the most efficient way to brew, but its smoothness (or rather lack of bitterness) keeps the regulars coming back. The owner wants to start the "slow coffee" movement where people can come in, relax and stay for a long brew. $60.

venue.name: Al Pasha
venue.description: Be transported to a world of Middle Eastern mystique as you sample the flavours of the Silk Road. Specialty dishes include ostrich, horse and rabbit meat. Belly dancers and a resident DJ perform nightly to accompany your culinary adventure. $600.

venue.name: Steik World Meats
venue.description: If you’ve ever wondered how Scottish beef tastes or want to compare Japanese, Australian and US wagyu all on one platter, then Steik (spelled the German way) has the answers. Inside, a contemporary dining space also showcases wines from around the world. $1,200.

venue.name: Tak Lung Restaurant
venue.street: 25-29 Hong Keung Street, San Po Kong
venue.description: A worthy winner of Time Out’s 2009 dining awards, Tak Lung serves traditional favourites that have been overlooked by modern Cantonese kitchens. Signature dishes include ‘gold coin chicken’, ‘stuffed goose feet’ buns and fish stock poached pomelo skins in shrimp roe sauce. $250.

venue.name: Yagura
venue.street: G/F, Eaton Hotel Hong Kong, 380 Nathan Road
venue.description: Stylish granite and marble coupled with dark wood deck out this modern izakaya-style restaurant. Signature dishes include the 999 fired spicy tuna roll and aburimono (grilled dried blowfish) and wagyu foie gras roll. An impressive drinks cabinet stocks over 25 sakes and shochus, including Yagura’s own private sake label. They even have their own Facebook game. $700.

venue.name: Bookworm CafÃ©
venue.description: A favourite among Lamma residents and visitors alike, Bookworm not only cooks up tasty, vegetarian comfort food, it also serves as a second-hand bookshop. The menu lists plenty of salads, sandwiches and meat-free burgers to enjoy in a relaxed atmosphere. $150.

venue.name: Oyster Plus
venue.street: Shop 67, Yee Fung Garden, 38 Ma Tin Road
venue.description: Tucked away in Yuen Long sits this unassuming oyster bar, which has been serving happy customers since November last year. Along with oysters and seafood, they offer a small menu of Spanish tapas, salads and French-style desserts. $800.

venue.name: Zi Yat Heen
venue.street: Lobby, Four Seasons Cotai Strip, Estrada da BaÃ­a de N. Senhora da EsperanÃ§a, S/N, Taipa
venue.description: Dim sum is taken to a whole new level thanks to the creative presentation and the inventive addition of exquisite ingredients to traditional recipes. There’s a reason why Zi Yat Heen was awarded two Michelin stars, but you should go and check it out for yourself. MOP1,000.

venue.name: Ba Shu Feng
venue.street: Sangda Community, 405 Zhenxing Road, Futian District
venue.description: A popular chain of Sichuan restaurants in Shenzhen, Ba Shu Feng serves all kinds of tongue-numbing specialties from China’s western region. Milder dishes are also available for chilli wimps. Long queues are often spotted in front of the restaurants, so reservations are highly recommended. RMB150.

venue.name: Dan Gui Xuan
venue.description: Just across the border from Lo Wu, Dan Gui Xuan is especially popular with hungry Hong Kong day trippers. Expect to have to wait in line before sitting down to generous portions of steaming-hot dim sum and Peking duck. RMB200.

venue.name: Laurel
venue.street: 1/F, Portofino Club House, OCT Xiang Shan St.
venue.description: Dine at this reasonably priced fine Chinese dining establishment created by one of the most notable restaurant groups in the mainland. There are three branches in the area, but we recommend the Portofino Club House location complete with outdoor seating, which is ideal for a peaceful lunch in the sunshine or for a casual business meeting. There are many Chinese restaurants to choose from here, but we like this one for their food and wine pairings. RMB 400.

venue.name: Torishin
venue.description: We cannot believe there is an entire restaurant dedicated to chicken. As such, you really won’t be able to find any other meat here. The selection includes yakitori, chicken meat balls, chicken liver, chicken salad, and even grilled chicken backside. $550.

venue.name: Cuc Vietnamese Restaurant
venue.description: With no visible signs leading up to this private kitchen, it’s a surprise anybody knows about this place. The usual suspects of spring rolls and soft shell crab rice paper wraps are on offer, but the flaming coconut shrimps and the mini bowls of spicy noodles are the crowd pleasers here. Reservations are absolutely necessary. $650.

venue.name: Hunan Garden
venue.description: Hunanese cuisine has been slow to catch on in the city, which is baffling given the popularity of the equally spicy Sichuan fare. For those whose taste buds are looking for a fiery chili ride though, Hunan Garden serves authentic dishes such as Hunan deep-fried prawns in chili sauce, fish fillets with fried mince bean, as well as new hot casseroles. $400.

venue.name: Soland
venue.description: Vegans have been raving about this secret spot for years. Soland serves a set menu of wholesome food, beginning with a big bowl of soup, followed by a main usually comprising of pasta or rice, accompanied by fresh salad and slices of pumpkin. The healthy dishes are bound to leave you full, but not bloated. Note that Soland only opens Monday to Friday 12pm-3pm and reservations are recommended. $130.

venue.name: Xi Yan Private Dining
venue.description: Masquerading under the label of a private kitchen, Xi Yan is in reality quite spacious and does not have the cosy ambiance one might expect. However, Jacky Yu, designer-turned-celebrity chef, has done a great job with his modern interpretation of traditional Chinese cuisine. The set menus include such staples as spicy Sichuan chicken, homemade cold bean curd and braised pork belly. Reservations are required. $1,000.

venue.name: Long Men Lou
venue.street: Nan Lian Garden, 60 Fung Tak Road
venue.description: Located in the picturesque Nan Lain Garden as part of the Chi Lin Nunnery, Long Men Lou serves inspired Chinese vegetarian dishes that don’t rely solely on starchy taro. Favourites include the dim sum menu at lunch, pine seed, ginger and mushroom fried rice and veggie dumpling noodles. $300.

venue.name: T'ang Court
venue.description: Named after the Golden Age in Chinese history, the T’ang Dynasty, the restaurant is furnished lavishly in extravagant burgundy and gold tones. The extensive menu includes signature dishes like stir-fried lobster with spring onions and shallots and golden-fried stuffed crab claw, and the more expensive bird’s nests and abalones. Indecisive diners can opt for the prix fixe menus with a set dinner for two available for $900. $1,000.

venue.name: Kwai Kwai Hong Restaurant
venue.description: The Cantonese like to think they roast the best suckling pig in the culinary world, and Kwai Kwai Hong is doing a good job of maintaining this image. A word of warning for the faint of hearted: the entire pig is presented on a bed of fried rice, complete with face, legs and tail. Other signature dishes include the slightly less brutal lotus root cake and sweet vinegar spare ribs. $250.

venue.name: Paisano's
venue.description: The good news is homesick New Yorkers can now get a slice of pie just like their home city makes it. The bad news is you’ll have to trek over to Sai Kung to get your fix. But with fresh pizza dough and sandwich bread that’s made fresh in store on a daily basis and a stone oven to boot, we think it’s worth it. Adventurous pizza gluttons can sign up for the 24” challenge – finish the large pizza in under 30 minutes with a friend and it’s on the house. $150.

venue.name: Oja Sopa Da Fita Cheong Kei
venue.street: 68 Rua da Felicidade, Avenida de Almeida Ribeiro
venue.description: A Macau institution, locals and visitors alike queue up here for the fresh noodles. The most popular dish is the wonton noodles with shrimp roe, as is the fried fish balls and pig’s trotters. Just don’t linger around after you’ve finished eating, unless you want to attract impatient stares from the queue of hungry people. MOP80.

venue.name: Chamate
venue.street: Shops B1-001-002, Kingglory Plaza, 2028 Renmin South Road, Guomao, Luohu
venue.description: Styled as both as a fast food joint and a teahouse, Chamate offers a wide range of Taiwanese meals and snacks. As the name of the restaurant suggests, tea is the main attraction here, with choices that span from simple milk tea to the more exotic sounding rose and ginseng tea, or hot fruit tea, made with real fruit flesh. RMB150.

venue.name: Yu Yuan
venue.street: 4/F, CITIC City Plaza, 1095 Shennan Middle Road, Futian
venue.description: You can’t go wrong with wallet-friendly Shanghaiese when looking for an inexpensive meal in Shenzhen, and long queues are usually indicative of good food. Popular dishes include the crab roe and egg white – presented in an egg shell, sweet and sour deep-fried fish and drunken chicken. RMB350.

venue.name: Bonheur
venue.description: A local gem in Sheung Wan, Bonheur is known for serving quality French cuisine at relatively affordable prices in an unpretentious setting. A prix-fixe three or four course menu serves a no-nonsense selection of appetisers, entrees and desserts. Pan-seared foie gras in lychee liquor sauce and mango mille feuille top are popular choices. There is no corkage fee. $800.

venue.name: Enoteca
venue.description: Enjoy Mediterranean cuisine at this cosy wine and tapas bar. With a large, open patio front, Enoteca is perfect for casual drinks and sharing Greek, Morrocan and Italian snacks while enjoying a nice selection of wines by the glass. $500.

venue.name: Kwai Tak Vegetarian Restaurant
venue.street: Shop B, 1/F, Fung Ming Building, 140 Wan Chai Rd
venue.description: A popular spot with vegetarians, this private kitchen offers a fixed menu of all veggie dishes. With dishes spanning from California rolls to sweet and sour creations, the menu is a medley of Japanese, Southern and Northern Chinese cooking and Western-inspired dishes. Reservations are absolutely necessary, and a minimum party of two is required. $400.

venue.name: Ramen Sanpachi
venue.description: This noodle joint serves ramen flown in from Hokkaido and cooked to perfection. Ramen is the main bread-winner here, but if you’re not in the mood then Sanpachi also serves a selection of rice and side dishes. Watch out for the long queues during peak hours. $120.

venue.name: San Xi Lou
venue.description: Challenge your taste buds and see how much spice you can handle by ordering the stalwart chili and pepper chicken. Yin yang hot pots are also available for anyone who wants to get in on the action with a milder broth. Reservations are highly recommended. $450.

venue.name: CafÃ© Iguana
venue.street: Shop R004, Civic Squre, Elements, 1 Austin Rd West, Tsim Sha Tsui
venue.description: Decked out in vibrant reds, oranges and greens, Café Iguana serves up food and cocktails that are just as vivacious. For those looking for a bit of spice in your life, try the chili-infused tequila, followed up by a Bloody Mary chili-flavoured chaser. Fajitas are a must in any Mexican restaurant, so order some here and admire their tailor-made all-in-one set with a drawer to hold the tortillas. $400.

venue.name: Chong Fat Chiu Chow Restaurant
venue.description: The place may look completely run-down, but that’s part of its charm. The menu is plastered all over the walls and includes typical Chiu Chow dishes such as steamed dumplings, oyster omelette and braised goose with beancurd. Worth a visit if you’re in the area, but make sure you have a friend with you who can read Chinese. $120.

venue.name: Romankan Yokohama
venue.description: The foodie community has been abuzz with the latest tonkatsu import from Japan, Romankan Yokohama at I-Square. Similar to Tonkichi, part of the fun here is that diners are given a bowl of sesame and a grinder so they make their own sauce. $350.

venue.name: Shang Shang Shanghai Cuisine
venue.street: Shop L407, Level 4A, Langham Place, 8 Argyle St
venue.description: With a name like this, there are no prizes for guessing what’s on the menu here. Expect all the usual suspects like Shanghainese stir-fried thick noodles, tam tam noodles, sweet and sour fried fish and more. The xiao long bao is juicy, with skin that’s not too thick nor too thin – exactly the way it should be. $250.

venue.name: The Steak House
venue.description: This restaurant takes steak seriously and offers high levels of attention to detail, from the selection of gourmet knives to the exotic salt and mustard pairings. The choice of beef includes Japanese and Australian Wagyu, and USDA-certified prime beef. Other meats include rack of lamb from Colorado and Dutch veal. The wine bar also features over 450 international wines. $1,500.

venue.name: Loaf On
venue.description: Having been subjected to the intense scrutiny of those wise reviewers at Michelin, this Sai Kung seafood restaurant is now the proud owner of a single star. Mantis shrimps, crabs and scallops are must order dishes, but the salted fried chicken and seafood soup are also popular. $450.

venue.name: Luca
venue.street: 64A Lung Mei Tsuen, Ting Kok Rd
venue.description: Al fresco dining is hard to come by in this city but Luca is worth the trek to Tai Po. The usual pizza and pasta dishes can be found at this secluded Italian joint, and the menu is updated frequently. It’s perfect for a romantic date out of the city. $450.

venue.name: Nyonya Indonesia Restaurant
venue.street: G/F, Shop 7, Hong King Garden, 7 Tsing Sin St
venue.description: Should you ever find yourself stranded in Tuen Mun and pining for Indonesian food, head over to Nyonya and gorge yourself silly on gado gado and nasi goreng. Prices are reasonable and the service is superb. Set dinners are available every evening for $128 per person plus service charge. $300.

venue.name: Sha Tin 18
venue.description: The show kitchens offer diners a front row view of the chefs cooking up Northern Chinese and Cantonese dishes. Signature dishes include Peking duck from the barbecue kitchen, Houjie fish cakes from the wok kitchen and both traditional and inventive Chinese desserts from the dessert kitchen. $800.

venue.name: Aux Beaux Arts
venue.street: MGM Grand Macau, Av Dr Sun Yat Sen, NAPE
venue.description: Macau didn’t inherit the European sidewalk café way of life from its former colonists, but they can play pretend by building a terrace complete with European architectural façades in a casino resort. The seafood platter and fillet of beef Rossini are popular choices, and an extensive wine list is available. MOP1,000.

venue.name: O Porto Interior
venue.description: Just down the road from the famous A Lorcha and Litoral, O Porto is a comfortable restaurant offering inexpensive fare. Choose from an array of dishes including African chicken, cohinillo and Macanese crab curry, and wash it all down with some Portuguese beer. MOP400.

venue.name: Clover Restaurant & Bar
venue.description: Specialising in European style cuisine, Clover offers a vast variety of entrées including roasted suckling pig, fried grouper fillet with tomato salsa and braised lamb shank in red wine. Diners can enjoy their meal in the dining room or out on the patio. RMB300.

venue.name: Liu Qian Guan
venue.street: Dongmen Branch of Shenzhen Maoye, 2047 Mid Dongmen Rd, Luohu
venue.description: The restaurant is famous for its pork bone stew, but other dishes such as spinach balls and stir-fried pork are also worth ordering. If you’re looking for something a little different, try the sweet papaya dessert and iced Chinese vegetables. RMB120.

venue.name: Akira Kushiyaki
venue.description: Their Japanese grill offers a great selection of meat, as well as seafood and veg all seared in a smoke-free environment. We especially love the beef tenderloin, bacon wrapped asparagus, scallops and sweet potato, best washed down with ample servings of sake. $550.

venue.name: iPreciation
venue.street: Shop LG3, Jardine House, 1 Connaught Place

venue.name: 2P Contemporary Art Galley
venue.street: Shop 5, G/F, Poga Building, 6-20 Po Tuck St

venue.name: Soccer pitch, Pak Tai Temple Playground
Re:spect Magazine
venue.street: Unit 1104, Chai Wan, Industrial City Phase 2, 70 Wing Tai Road

venue.name: CafÃ© Gray Deluxe
venue.street: 49/F, The Upper House, Pacific Place, 88 Queensway
venue.description: Marking Gray Kunz’s return to Hong Kong, the restaurant offers a menu of European classics such as steak tartar and sea bass in ginger bouillon. Perched on top of The Upper House on the 49th floor, meals are complemented by the great views of the harbour. $1,200.

venue.name: Hung's Delicacies
venue.street: Shop 4, G/F, Ngan Fai Bldg, 84-94 Wharf Rd
venue.description: Even before it was blessed with a Michelin star, Hung’s has always been loved by the locals for its soy sauce-braised snacks. This Chui Chow restaurant is most famous for its duck tongue, goose feet and sliced goose. Expect queues around the clock. $180.

venue.name: Point Pie
venue.description: This tiny restaurant offers a good selection of meats, oysters and other seafood, but the must-order item is the grilled Australian lamb. The private room upstairs would make for a pleasant, romantic meal for special occasions. $900.

venue.name: BaShe Peasts The Entire Fish
venue.description: No, we don’t understand what the name is about either, but that’s no reason to discount this Sichuan restaurant. What we do know though is that they do a great grilled mud carp, Sichuan-style. The fish comes in a tray of broth filled with chillies, leeks and peppers, but if you can’t handle the mouth-numbing spice, a milder broth with preserved vegetables is available. $250.

venue.name: Chai Rung Thai Food
venue.description: Shrimp sashimi, boiled cockles and grilled chicken are the most frequently ordered dishes, but we think the main attraction is the grill and hotpot combo. This culinary creation consists of an elevated, sloped charcoal grill surrounded by a moat of broth. A ball of beef lard sits on top, which lubricates the grill and gives the meats an extra flavour. The meat juices then trickle down into the broth, making it perfect for cooking the meatballs, veggies and vermicelli. $200.

venue.name: Go Koong Korean Restaurant
venue.description: The best thing about Go Koong is the generosity of the banchan. With as many as ten appetisers, diners can make a meal out of these tasty treats alone. Worth ordering are the steamed pumpkin with beef ribs and homemade buckwheat noodles in clear beef broth. $550.

venue.name: Chan Kun Kee
venue.description: A popular late night snack haunt, this dai pai dong serves up delicious Cantonese dishes including roast pigeon, spring onion oil chicken and lots of noodles. A wide selection of seafood is on offer also, such as deep-fried oyster cake, mantis shrimps and garlic steamed scallops. $120.

venue.name: Chef Wellyâs Kitchen
venue.description: The most interesting item on the menu is, without a doubt, the strawberry baby back ribs. For those who like to keep their fruit and meat apart, this little café also does a good rack of lamb. $400.

venue.name: Kwan Kee Beef Balls & Pork Knuckles
venue.street: 5 Luen Cheong St, Luen Wo Hui
venue.description: When the restaurant includes beef balls and pork knuckles in its name, you know they’re serious about them. This specialty joint is so popular for the aforementioned items that it’s not uncommon for them to be sold out by 4pm. So you know what to do. $50.

venue.name: Yin Yue
venue.description: Book a table at Yin Yue for your weekend dim sum. The tables are generously spaced, which means it’s kid-friendly, and you don’t have to shout to compete with your neighbour’s conversations. All the traditional dim sum is on the menu, as well as some modern creations like the blueberry char siu puff and baked cheese and salmon tart. $300.

venue.name: Banza
venue.description: Drop by for some Portuguese classics such as pig’s ear salad, grilled sardines or braised ribs. Can’t decide what to order? You can always let the owner, Banza, choose for you. MOP600.

venue.name: Mezza 9
venue.street: 3/F, Grand Hyatt Macau, City of Dreams, Estrada do Istmo
venue.description: Like it's Singapore cousin, Macau's Mezza 9 has different cooking stations dedicated to Southeast Asia. Sit indoors or al fresco in the zen décor conceived by super designers Super Potato. MOP1,000.

venue.name: Liu Yuan çåé£¯åº
venue.description: Is there anyone who doesn't love Shanghainese? Order the lion's head meatball, sheng jian bao, chicken wonton soup and deep fried fish in sweet and sour sauce. The eggs aren't half bad either. RMB250.

venue.name: Man Ting Sichuan Hot Pot æ»¿åº­è³å·èç«éå
venue.description: Despite having hot pot in its name, this is not where the restaurant excels. Instead, order their signature mouth-watering chicken, a must-have at this Sichuanese restaurant. Also worth trying is the carp in fiery broth, where diners use ladles to scoop up slices of fish from a sea of mouth-numbing chillies. RMB150.

venue.name: Lin Heung Kui
venue.description: Being the sister restaurant of Lin Heung Tea House, this place is obviously just as well known for its dim sum so expect crowds. More or less the same as its older sibling with the old school décor and dim sum trolleys, but at least you don’t have to fight for your food here. $200.

venue.name: VeggieSF
venue.description: This place has brought a breath of fresh air to the American dining scene of gigantic servings of meat, as found at Dan Ryan’s, Tony Roma et al. The 1950s American memorabilia dotted around the place gives the restaurant a fun, yet cosy atmosphere. Order the carrot and ginger soup and beetroot paté open sandwich to get your five-a-day. $350.

venue.name: Wun Sha's Kitchen
venue.description: A large chandelier and circular archways lend this swanky Tai Hang restaurant an air of elegance. Diners come for their creative reinventions of traditional Chinese dishes, such as steamed winter melon balls in superior broth, smoked eggs and smoked chicken in soy sauce. $400.

venue.name: Yo Bago
venue.description: Some people take their bagels seriously, and these people can be found at Yo Bago. A large selection of bagels and cream cheeses are available, but more impressive are the towering sandwiches filled with all sorts of fresh veggies and deli meats. For all you crazy Canadians out there, they also serve Tim Horton’s coffee. $80.

venue.name: Fish Maw King è±è å€§ç
venue.street: Shop B, G/F, 12 Lai Wan Rd, Mei Foo Sun Chuen
venue.description: Chinese cuisine has long considered fish maw to be a delicacy and a source of collagen, so it’s only natural that there should be a restaurant specialising in this luxury treat. Eat your way to beautiful skin with a serving of fish maw steak and double-boiled herbal soups. If you’d rather give maw a miss, other Cantonese dishes are also available. But why go to Fish Maw King if you’re not going to try it? $400.

venue.name: Good Satay
venue.description: Located in an old, dingy shopping and office complex, this place might not look promising from the outside, but it serves up mouthwatering Hainan chicken rice, laksa, and of course, satay. A great alternative to Sabah for Kowloon-side residents. $150.

venue.name: Gyu Jin
venue.description: Temperatures may be on the rise, but that’s never been a reason to stop eating out of a pot of boiling broth. Gyu Jin specialises in Wagyu beef buffets, offering diners the choice between shabu shabu or sukiyaki. $250.

venue.name: Hansung Co
venue.description: Located on a rather suspect street in Tsim Sha Tsui, Hansung Co. lies in the city’s de facto Koreatown. There isn’t a huge variety to choose from on the menu, but that doesn’t stop diners from queuing up for hearty Korean fare on a nightly basis. Worth ordering are the bibimbap, beef stew, pancake and spicy rice cake. $200.

venue.name: Indian Restaurant
venue.description: Hidden in an area littered with Thai eateries is this gem of an Indian restaurant. From korma to vindaloo, this place has something for taste buds of all spice levels. Be sure to dig into the curries with a side of garlic naan. The food is so good that they don’t even need an original name to attract customers. $200.

venue.name: Char Siu King åçå€§ç
venue.street: Shop 39, Riverside Garden, 20 Tai Chung Bridge Rd
venue.description: With a name like this, you don’t even need to look at the menu to decide what you should eat. Have the char siu over rice, with rice noodles or simply on its own. $100.

venue.name: Cru
venue.description: A favourite dining option for weekends in Sai Kung, Cru serves plenty of comfort food like pizzas, pastas, grilled meats and sandwiches. The restaurant also does a great brunch, perfect for catching up with friends on a lazy Sunday. $500.

venue.name: Okapi CafÃ©
venue.description: Dig into a steaming pot of mussels and fries Belgian style. Also on the menu are steaks, lamb chops and beer battered fish and chips. $500.

venue.name: Sun Cheung çææœ®æŽ²æµ·é®®é å®¶
venue.description: Order all the Chiu Chow favourites like soy sauce braised goose, salt-baked fish, fried oyster cake and steamed fish with pickles. The restaurant also has a good selection of seafood in the tanks for diners to choose from. $200.

venue.name: Restaurante Escada
venue.description: A colonial townhouse restaurant, Escada has a quaint little balcony perfect for a cosy dinner for two. Feast on curry prawn, grilled sardines, African chicken and other Macanese delights. MOP400.

venue.name: Square 8
venue.street: MGM MACAU Ave Dr. Sun Yat Sen, NAPE
venue.description: A deluxe café that never shuts, Square 8 brings an extensive range of Asian cuisines all under one roof: dim sum, northern Chinese, Southeast Asian, Macanese, sandwiches, salads, and congee. You name it, they’ve got it. MOP200.

venue.name: The Flavour of South China æ±åå³é
venue.street: Shop B05, Wanxiang Cheng, 1881 Baoâan South Rd
venue.description: Swarms of hungry diners can always be found outside, which must mean the food is worth waiting around for. Order the jelly ham, braised pork belly, lion’s head meatball and sheng jian bao. RMB150.

venue.name: Xinyue Muslim Restaurant
venue.description: A popular Chinese restaurant specialising in Xinjiang cuisine, lamb is the meat of choice for diners here. Lamb features heavily on the menu; ribs, chops, steaks, kebabs, in dumplings and in puff pastries. RMB200.

venue.name: T.T. Tsui Gallery, University Museum and Art Gallery, HKU
Koru Contemporary Art
venue.street: 10/F, Unit 1012, Hing Wai Centre, 7 Tin Wan Praya Rd

venue.name: Hanart Square
venue.street: 2/F Mai On Industrial Bldg, 17-21 Kung Yip St

venue.name: Him Kee Hot Pot
venue.description: Known for their large variety of hot pot ingredients, Him Kee caters to diners who are serious about the freshness of their food. Try their buttery melt-in-your-mouth thinly sliced beef along with the different innovative dumplings on the menu. $400.

venue.name: Malaymama
venue.description: Leave it up to this small noodle shop to give you a taste of some authentic homemade Malaysian cuisine. Both their laksa and noodles with prawn mee will taste like they were freshly prepared just for you in a traditional Malay neighbourhood. $120.

venue.name: Tanyoto Hot Pot
venue.description: The name “tanyoto” actually translates to “fish head” in Chinese, which is exactly what they specialise in. Be sure to order a fish head to throw in your boiling hot pot broth for that extra flavour even if you are not courageous enough to devour it. $250.

venue.name: Tim Ho Wan
venue.street: Shop 8, Taui Yuen Mansion Phase 2, 2-20 Kwong Wa St
venue.description: Since this neighbourhood dim sum spot won a Michelin award, long queues have begun to form every morning, full of anxious people waiting to get a bite of what is considered to be some of the city’s best dim sum. They specialise in steamed dumplings and haven’t budged on their same low prices. $80.

venue.name: Rivervine Keung Seafood
venue.description: Don’t be intimidated by the heavy influx of loud diners in this place, they’re there for some of the best chicken abalone congee and roasted pigeon around Sha Tin. This bustling carpeted restaurant also boasts excellence in service. There is also a good selection of fresh seafood outside to pick from. $200.

venue.name: Shanghai Grandma äžæµ·å©å©
venue.street: Shop 3207, 3 Tuen Lung St, Tuen Mun Town Plaza
venue.description: Easily one of the best Shanghainese restaurants in the city, diners are able to see their food freshly made in a large open window. We especially recommend the signature xiao long baos and hand-pulled noodles. $200.

venue.name: Wo Che Estate Market
venue.description: With its bright lights illuminating the ghostly, deserted neighborhood of Fo Tan, the dai pai dongs here have proven to be the hang out spot for midnight snackers. This nightly food market is truly a haven for locals and visitors looking to feast on greasy large-portioned delicacies for a bargain. $40.

venue.name: Antica Trattoria da Ise
venue.description: Down by the docks in the night club district is this simple and rustic Italian restaurant that serves hearty pastas and pizzas by the pie; a good selection of Portuguese and Italian wines is also available. It is closed every second Tuesday of the month. MOP300.

venue.name: Caravela
venue.street: Kam Loi Bldg, G/F, 7 Patio do Comandante Mata e Oliveira
venue.description: American breakfasts, bakery goods and Portuguese fast food are all found in this back alley gem. MOP100.

venue.name: Laurel Restaurant (Dan Gui Xuan)
venue.description: Great Peking ducks and dim sum in a nice atmosphere in and amongst the bustle of Louhu’s Commercial Centre. Get off the train and you are steps away from a classy Cantonese meal. Book in advance as it tends to get crowded. RMB100.

venue.name: Lotus
venue.description: Lotus opens a new location next to the escalator just in time for al fresco dining weather. This time the walls are blasted open to create and indoor/outdoor drinking spot prime people-watching. This cosy lounge is perfect for those who want to be seen. $500.

venue.name: Jade Garden
venue.street: Shop 803, Grand Century Place, 193 Prince Edward Rd, Mong Kok
venue.description: Every morning this recently renovated dining room is filled with dim sum goers. If you arrive after 10am, be prepared to take a number and wait. $300.

venue.name: Business Enviromental Council
venue.street: 2/F, Jockey Club Environmental Building, 77 Tat Chee Ave

venue.name: Asia-Pacific Aromatherapy
venue.street: Room 1001, 10/F, Java Commercial Centre, 128 Java Rd

venue.name: Pristine Living
venue.street: Room 1005, 10/F, Fu Lee Commercial Building, 14-20 Pilkem St

venue.name: Baptist University
venue.street: Academy of Visual Arts, 51 Kwun Tong Rd

venue.name: The Temptation
venue.street: The Lamma Tower,12-12A Hau Fook Street

venue.name: Stroll
venue.street: Hung Cheong House, 7 Mee Lung St

venue.name: Brasserie on the Eighth
venue.street: 8/F, Conrad Hong Kong, Pacific Place, 88 Queensway, Admiralty
venue.description: This cosy little restaurant with a view is ideal for French fine dining. The atmosphere is intimate yet neither intimidating nor pretentious. The friendly staff will be more than happy to assist you in choosing between the foie gras or seared scallops to start.

venue.name: Chicken on the Run
venue.street: Shop A, LG/F, 1 Princeâs Terrace, Soho
venue.description: If youâre planning a junk trip and are looking for private catering, this is the place to turn to. The tiny but efficient take-away bistro offers salads and roast chicken platters with ingredients imported straight from Australia. Claiming to be the only company in Hong Kong to bring fresh never-frozen free range Australian chickens, they also have an impressive selection of vegetarian dishes to choose from. $100.

venue.name: Seam Eett Taiwan Noodles
venue.street: G/F, 2N Hung Kwong Building, 2 Tung Choi St
venue.description: Hidden behind the tourist-filled stalls of Ladies Market in Mongkok is this small home-style Taiwanese joint. Hop in after shopping to get a genuine taste of Taiwan with their traditional and creative local dishes including deep fried squid balls, braised pork ribs, and rice with minced meat. $120.

venue.name: Pink Salmon CafÃ© & Restaurant
venue.street: G/F, Tang's Mansion, 438 Nathan Rd, Yau Ma Tei
venue.description: As the name suggests this fusion Western and Japanese restaurantâs specialty is salmon. Inside, the walls are lined with a series of salmon art displays. The menu consists of almost any food you can imagine with cooked or raw salmon. Most notable are the pan-fried crispy Norwegian salmon and the salmon with white sauce and baked baguette. $300

venue.name: Munch
venue.description: This dimly lit elegant restaurant features high full length painted ceilings to give a classic European vibe. Enjoy the festive atmosphere of Knutsford Terrace while digging in on the tiger prawns tossed with linguine or duck con fit, topping it off with one of their many French desserts. $500.

venue.name: Amagao
venue.description: It seems that the private-kitchen trend in Hong Kong has become so popular that itâs even spread to Macau. Well, at least at this one place we know of in a little alleyway in Macau. The family-owned Amagao will provide top-notch hospitality as well as some of the best Portuguese food around. MOP 200.

venue.name: Tapeo
venue.street: G/F Lei King Wan, Site A, 55 Tai Hong St
venue.description: A second branch of this popular tapas house opens in Island East by Sai Wan Ho's waterfront. This time diners will get all the goodies from their Soho branch with an extended paella menu for carb lovers. $300.

venue.name: Bistro Bamboo ç«¹éå®¶
venue.description: Among all the trendy restaurants lined up in SoHo flaunting their exotic cuisines lays this hidden gem of a restaurant. Relive the 1960s as you walk down the steps to traditional Chinese wooden furnishings and take a break from Cantonese food and Hong Kong-style Western food with some favourite dishes from Northern China. $450.

venue.name: June Japanese Restaurant
venue.description: Sometimes rotating sushi can be a bit too much hassle after work with the massive crowds and brightly coloured lights. That is when this cosy local traditional Japanese restaurant will be calling your name. Japanese diners here regularly enjoy dinner and lunch sets which include sushi with fresh soba noodles. $300.

venue.name: Ippei-An Noodle House
venue.street: Shop 11, 2/F, Miramar Shopping Centre, 132 Nathan Rd
venue.description: The huge bowls of ramen at Ippei-An are loaded with tons of veggies and a light broth to make the dish healthier, but just as tasty, for ramen-lovers. For friends who are less health-conscious, we recommend the eel pancake and their assortment of Japanese skewers. $200.

venue.name: Patisserie Tony Wong
venue.description: PASTRIES Renowned pastry chef Tony Wong unleashes his passion into his creations after having accumulated 30 years of experience. His signature chocolate truffles and mango napoleons have attracted the young and the old alike who line up outside to get one hell of a sweet taste. $100.

venue.name: Suzuki CafÃ© Company
venue.street: Shop 12, Level 12, Langham Place, 8 Argyle St
venue.description: Most cafes in Hong Kong tend to serve more than cakes and coffee, and this one is no different. This Japanese-style eatery serves a wide variety of unique appetisers, pizzas, and pastas along with sundaes and pastries. $200.

venue.name: Cozinha Pinocchio
venue.description: Just ten minutes from the ferry terminal, Cozinha was opened in 1977 by a chef who has known Portuguese barbequing since his childhood. The most famous specialty dish is their curry crab, and thereâs also a decent selection of wine to complement the fine dishes. MOP320.

venue.name: Honeycomb
venue.street: Floor 3, Zone A, Poly Cultural Center, Haide San Dao, Nanshan
venue.description: The unusual dÃ©cor of this massive loft-like restaurant is made to actually look like the inside of a honeycomb. Sample the Cantonese, Hunan, and Hangzhou dishes in this space age interior. $500.

venue.name: Sheung Shui Centre of Construction Industry Council Training Academy
Xiang Hai Xuan Exhibition Hall, Nan Lian Gardens
Dr Sun Yat Sen Museum, Exhibition Hall
